PETITION.TITLE: Uranium
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled.

The Petition of the undersigned strongly opposes any attempts by the Australian government to mine uranium at the Jabiluka and Koongara sites in the World Heritage Listed Area of the Kakadu National Park or any other proposed or current operating site.
Your petitioners ask that the Senate oppose any intentions by the Australian government to support the nuclear industry via any mining, enrichment and sale of uranium.

PETITION.TITLE: Telstra: Privatisation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Senators, and to the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:
The petition of the undersigned citizens respectfully shows that:
As members of the Australian community, considering:

PARA.TAB: the strategic important of Telstra in the national economy;
the high levels of foreign ownership in the rest of the telecommunications industry;
the growing importance of communications services to the lives of all Australians;
the threat that privatisation poses to the universal availability of both present and future communications services;

PETITION.PARA: We believe that it is in the national interest for Telstra to be kept in full public ownership.

We therefore call on the Federal Government to abandon its proposal to privatise Telstra, the nation's chief telecommunications provider, and to explore alternative means of funding its environmental policy.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Triple J
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned shows that the potential funding cuts to Radio Triple J will drastically affect services and public broadcasts to the youth of Australia.
Your petitioners therefore ask the Senate to retain the current level of funding for triple J.

PETITION.TITLE: Commonwealth Dental Health Program
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

The humble petition of Citizens of the Nillumbik Shire and Surrounds draws to the attention of the Senate that the closure of the Commonwealth Dental Health Program will result in considerable pain and suffering to those people who are Health Care Card holders and their dependents.
Your Petitioners therefore pray that the Senate restore the Commonwealth Dental Health Program for Health Care Card holders and their Dependents in the 1996/97 budget.

PETITION.TITLE: Mental Health Services
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That mental health service consumers and carers are already significantly disadvantaged by the current poor funding of mental health and psychiatric disability support services.
That the 1996 Federal Budget will halve the Medicare rebate where a person visits a psychiatrist more than 50 times in a year.

That people with mental health problems such as chronic depression, eating disorders, dissociative disorders, or who may have suffered childhood abuse require access to long term intensive therapy. Decreased access to service by private psychiatrists will result in increased hospitalisation for those most in need.

That the 1996 Federal Budget will increase the cost of prescriptions for people on the Disability Support Pension. While the cap on the total cost of prescriptions in a year remains the same, people who are already living below the poverty line will be required to pay more from their fortnightly pension until the cap is reached.

That the 1996 Federal Budget will cut $14 million from Commonwealth Mental Health Programs. This funding had been made available to address serious problems and under‐funding in mental health services in Australia.
Your petitioners therefore humbly ask that you will oppose cuts to mental health services and increases in the cost of prescriptions.

SPEECH.PARA: To the Honourable President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

We the undersigned citizens respectfully submit that any reform to Australia's system of industrial relations should recognise the special needs of employees to be protected from disadvantage, exploitation and discrimination in the workplace.

We the petitioners oppose the Coalition policies which represent a fundamentally anti‐worker regime and we call upon the Senate to provide an effective check and balance to the Coalition's legislative program by rejecting such a program and ensuring that:
1. The existing powers of the Australian Industrial Relations Commission (AIRC) be maintained to provide for an effective independent umpire overseeing awards and workplace bargaining processes.

2. The proposed system of Australian Workplace Agreements (AWAs) should be subject to the same system of approval required for the approval of certified agreements (through enterprise bargaining). Specifically, an AWA should not come into effect unless it is approved by the AIRC.

3. The approval of agreements contained in the legislation should be public and open to scrutiny. There should be provision for the involvement of parties who have a material concern relating to the approval of an agreement, including unions seeking to maintain the no disadvantage guarantees.
4. Paid rates awards be preserved and capable of adjustment, as is currently the case in the legislation.
5. The AIRC's powers to arbitrate and make awards must be preserved in the existing form and not be restricted to a stripped back set of minimum or core conditions.
6. The legislation should encourage the processes of collective bargaining and ensure that a certified agreement within its term of operation cannot be over‐ridden by a subsequent AWA.
7. The secondary boycott provisions should be preserved in their existing form.

8. The powers and responsibility of the AIRC to ensure the principle of equal pay for work of equal value should be preserved in its existing form. We oppose any attempt by the Coalition to restrict the AIRC from dealing with overaward gender based pay equity issues.
9. A `fair go all round' for unfair dismissal so that all workers currently able to access these remedies are able to do so in a fair manner, at no cost.
10. Workers under state industrial regulations maintain their rights to access the federal awards system in its current form.
Your petitioners therefore urge the Senate to reject the above proposed reforms to the area of industrial relations.

SPEECH.PARA: `No' to the privatisation of Telstra!
The Coalition government intends to privatise one‐third of Telstra, as the next phase of raffling off our precious national assets, usually for a fraction of their value.

We say `No' to the privatisation of Telstra, and to the privatisation of other state assets built up by earlier generations of Australians. These have been bequeathed to us today as `the public good', and are held in trust by us for generations of Australians yet to come.

Instead of this private rip‐off of public assets, with the loss of jobs and the destruction of the physical economy which accompanies it, the government should implement a 0.1 per cent (one‐tenth of one per cent) tax on the sale of speculative capital: stocks, bonds, derivatives, and foreign exchange. We, the undersigned, pledge to fight to stop this sell‐off of our national asset.

SPEECH.PARA: PETITION
TO THE HONOURABLE THE SPEAKER AND MEMBERS OF THE HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES ASSEMBLED IN PARLIAMENT
The petition of certain citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the House the following circumstances:
Therapeutic Goods Administration Commercial Services

In light of the recent advertisement by the Therapeutic Goods Administration (TGA) intending to provide consulting services to the Therapeutics Industry we, the undersigned, wish to petition the House. We are strongly opposed to any extension of commercial services for the reasons given below.

1. The proposed commercialisation is in direct conflict with the TGA regulatory charter and mission statement. The TGA intends to provide consulting services to the same industry that it is required to legally regulate. The TGA has not identified how it will guarantee absence of conflict of interest in the execution of its statutory duties and its intended commercial services.
TGA's Mission Statement

"To ensure the safety, quality and efficacy of therapeutic goods available in Australia at the standard equal to that of comparable countries, and to ensure that premarket assessment of therapeutic goods is conducted within a reasonable time."

2. The TGA has not identified how its.commercial services will not be underwritten by taxpayers, with respect to cross subsidisation, infrastructure, research facilities, resources, professional indemnity and personnel. For example:
(i) commercial activity might well be given priority over industry regulation in the event of a shortfall in personnel resources

(ii) the notification to industry of intent to provide these services through the TGA News, is an example of cross subsidisation and potential conflict of interest. The TGA News is funded through taxation and represent the policy of TGA to Industry.

3. The TGA has not demonstrated how it will be able to discharge its legal responsibilities effectively with respect to the regulation of commercial laboratory testing services without fundamental conflict of interest. The TGA is required to regulate and licence commercial laboratories and this is done effectively through the provision of expert auditors from the Therapeutic Goods Administration Laboratories (TGAL). The TGAL will be offering commercial testing services in direct competition with the same industry segment it is required to regulate. The TGA will continue to have access to commercial-in- confidence client information, contracts and confidential methods while still regulating its competition.

4. The TGA has recently been accredited by JAS-ANZ to provide certification services to industry for ISO 9001 conformity. JAS-ANZ recognises the likelihood of conflict of interest by its members and specifically precludes the offering of commercial services such as consulting or training, directly by, or via an identifiably related body, by a JAS-ANZ accredited organisation. (JAS-ANZ Policy # 6/94. Relationship Between Certification Bodies and Consultancy)

5. The Kean Report on Australia's Standards and Conformance Infrastructure—1995, strongly opposed the provision of commercial consulting services by JAS-ANZ accredited bodies such as Standards Australia and NATA unless these operations were clearly differentiated and strictly isolated from regulatory or certification activities. The TGA has not identified how it intends to overcome this principle, given that it has a statutory requirement to regulate a sensitive industry and has the authority to refuse licensing or revoke existing licences to manufacturers. The same situation applies to product registration.

6. The TGA has not identified whether its commercialisation will have any impact on its current membership of the EU Pharmaceutical Inspection Convention (PIC) for the same reasons outlined in 5 above. Membership of PIC by the TGA confers substantial advantage to the Australian Therapeutics manufacturers, is the subject of Heads of Government agreements and was gained over many years at taxpayers expense. The TGA has not provided the industry with assurances that the proposed services are not in conflict with PIC policy. In any event the membership, which is a status that adds to the TGA's attractiveness as a consultancy, was gained at taxpayers' expense.

7. The TGA intends, presumably underwritten initially by taxpayers, to compete directly with already existing commercial services. Almost all of the commercial providers are small business or sole traders who have invested capital and provide employment.
8. The Therapeutic Goods industry in Australia is already professionally serviced by many professional consulting, contract testing, product registration and training organisations.

We believe that these fundamental issues require full evaluation before any extension of commercial services are offered either directly by TGA or by any related body. We are however in favour of the TGA offering services to other international regulatory bodies because there is no conflict of interest.

PARA.EMPHASIS: The documents read as follows—
COMMISSIONER'S RULES NO 22, MADE UNDER S.252 OF THE LIFE INSURANCE ACT 1995

SPEECH.PARA: 25 October 1996
Senator the Hon Rod Kemp
Assistant Treasurer
Parliament House
CANBERRA ACT 2600
Dear Minister
I refer to the Commissioner's Rules No 22 made under s. 252 of the Life Insurance Act 1995.

Note 2 of the Rules advises that they commence on the day on which they are made, that is to say 12 September 1996. However, the final paragraph of the Explanatory Statement advises that they commence on gazettal, which the Committee understands was 18 September 1996. If Note 2 was intended to be part of the Rules and the Rules have any adverse effect on any person then they are void under s. 48(2) of the Acts Interpretation Act 1901 . If they do not form part of the Rules then the Rules commence on gazettal and the Note is wrong and presumably void. The Committee would be grateful for your advice.

The final paragraph of the Explanatory Statement advised that the Insurance and Superannuation Commission intends to administer the instrument as if it had taken effect on 1 January 1996. The Explanatory Statement further advised that it was not expected that the changes would affect rights or impose new obligations. It also advised that the ISC had been administering the intent of the rules rather than their literal provisions.
This advice in the Explanatory Statement is a matter of some concern. If the Rules have no adverse effects on any person then they could and should have been made retrospective to

1 January 1996. If there is any adverse effect at all then the solution is to amend the enabling Act to provide for prejudicial retrospectivity. It would, as I say, be of concern if a Commonwealth statutory officer is, or was, administering legislation not according to its provisions but according to what the officer considers the provisions should be. The Committee would appreciate your early advice.
Yours sincerely
Bill O'Chee
Senator Bill O'Chee
Chairman
Senate Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances
Parliament House
CANBERRA ACT 2600
Dear Senator O'Chee
COMMISSIONER'S RULES NO 22—LIFE INSURANCE ACT 1995
I refer to your letter dated 25 October 1996 concerning the above Commissioner's rules.
I sought a response to the matters raised in your letter from the Insurance and Superannuation Commission (the "Commission"), which I have now received.

You are right in pointing out that note 2 to the Commissioner's rules incorrectly states that the rules commence on the day on which they are made. It should have said that they commence on the day on which they are notified in the Gazette. This was an inadvertent error.

However, by virtue of paragraph 46(1)(a) and subsection 13(3) of the Acts Interpretation Act 1901, footnotes and endnotes in statutory rules are not taken to be part of the rules. Hence, the note, although erroneous, has no legal force or operation, and Commissioner's rules number 22 in fact commenced on gazettal, by virtue of subparagraph 48(1)(b)(iv) of the Acts Interpretation Act.

To prevent note 2 from causing confusion, the Commissioner has made a variation of Commissioner's rules number 22 which corrects the note. A copy is enclosed for your information. It will be laid before both Houses shortly.

I also agree with your comments about the final paragraph of the explanatory statement, to the effect that Commonwealth officers must administer the law as it is, not as they consider it should be. I should say that the Commission also agrees with those comments.

By way of explanation for the final paragraph of the explanatory statement, the changes made by Commissioner's rules number 22 to the earlier Commissioner's rules dated 20 December 1995 which they replaced were of a very minor technical nature only, and Commissioner's rules number 22 actually reflected both the original intent behind the earlier Commissioner's rules and the way in which life insurance companies had been applying the earlier Commissioner's rules. The changes to the earlier Commissioner's rules made by Commissioner's rules number 22 did not adversely affect policy holders but in fact, in some circumstances, advantaged them slightly.
However, you are undoubtedly correct in pointing out that the law must be administered according to its letter, and therefore:

(a) the Commission has undertaken to write to all life insurance companies telling them that they must strictly apply the earlier Commissioner's rules until the date on which Commissioner's rules number 22 commenced; and
(b) the Commission has also amended the explanatory statement by removing the offending final paragraph, and will lay the amended explanatory statement before both Houses.
A copy of the amended explanatory statement is enclosed for your information.

In my view, these steps should rectify the problems with Commissioner's rules number 22 that you have identified. Accordingly, if you agree that this is the case, I would be grateful if you would withdraw your notice of motion of disallowance of 6 November 1996.
Yours sincerely
(sgd) ROD KEMP

Dear Minister
I refer to the Export Control (Hardwood Wood Chips) (1996) Regulations, Statutory Rules 1996 No 206. The Committee would appreciate your advice on the following matters.

1. Regulation 8 sets out a number of matters which the Minister may consider before deciding whether to grant a provisional licence. A number of these relate directly to the applicant and information in respect of them would presumably be provided by the applicant itself. Paragraph 8(h), however, provides that one of the matters is the commercial reputation of the applicant. This is a subjective decision and, although it may be appropriate, it would seem necessary, in order to protect personal rights, for the Regulations to provide that the applicant must be notified of any adverse material under this heading, and be given a right of reply.

2. Part 7 of the Regulations provides for extensive rights of reconsideration and review. There is, however, a number of decisions for which these rights do not appear to be provided. These include, for instance, certain decisions under rr.10, 11, 19, 22 and 26. In particular, there does not seem to be reconsideration or review of a decision under r.32 to suspend or vary a licence. Given that original grants and conditions are reviewable, as is revocation of a grant, it would appear that r.32 decisions, which would affect commercial operations and livelihood, should also be reviewable. The Committee would appreciate your assurance that any exclusion from review comes within the relevant guidelines of the Administrative Review Council.

3. Many decisions under the Act must be accompanied by a statement of reasons. However, there is no requirement for a statement of reasons for r.32 decisions. Also, although decisions under r.34 to refuse an assignment of a licence are subject to reconsideration and review, here again there appears to be no provision for a statement of reasons.

4. Subregulation 36(4) provides that the Minister must reconsider certain decisions within 45 days of a request to do so. There are, however, no time constraints on the making of the original decisions which are subject to this reconsideration process. The Committee would be grateful for the reasons for this.

5. Regulation 40 provides that the Minister may delegate his or her considerable powers in this sensitive area to any officer of the Department, no matter how junior. The Committee asks the reasons for this.

6. This set of Regulations deals with important matters and is 28 pages long. The Explanatory Statement is, however, very slight with only a few lines given as background. The notes on individual regulations are also brief. The Committee would appreciate your advice on why the Explanatory Statement for these sensitive Regulations was so short.
Yours sincerely
Bill O'Chee
Chairman
Senator Bill O'Chee
Chairman
Senate Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances
Parliament House
CANBERRA ACT 2600
Dear Senator O'Chee

I refer to your letter of 13 November 1996 to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, the Hon John Anderson MP in relation to the Export Control (Hardwood Wood Chips) (1996) Regulations, Statutory Rules 1996 No 206 (the
Regulations). As Acting Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, I am responding to your letter.

On a general note, the Regulations were drafted in full consultation with industry representatives and in full knowledge of applicants' rights under the Administrative Appeals Tribunal Act 1975, the Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review) Act 1977, and principles of natural justice applicable to administrative decision-making. Further, the Regulations were considered by the Family and Administrative Law Branch, Civil Law Division, in the Attorney‐General's Department prior to their consideration by the Executive Council. It found the proposed Regulations met the Commonwealth's administrative review policy.
In relation to the specific matters raised in your letter, I would like to provide the following advice:

1. In relation to Regulation 8 (particularly paragraph 8(k)), I agree that some subjective assessment may be required to determine "the commercial reputation of the applicant" in relation to the issue of a transitional licence. I also agree it is a matter of natural justice that any adverse material considered by the Minister under this heading should be provided to the applicant with an opportunity to respond before any decision is made. This has been the approach of Mr Anderson in dealing with transitional licence applications to date. I note that failure to observe matters of natural justice would be reviewable (see section 2 below).

Further, the commercial reputation of an applicant could also be a relevant matter the Minister needs to consider in relation to an application under the Regulations for an RFA licence, a degraded forest licence, or a restricted shipment licence. In the same way, any failure to make available adverse material to the applicant for comment prior to the Minister making a decision, could be subject to review.

Finally, if the applicant's commercial reputation is a factor in the Minister's refusal to grant a licence, this fact will be provided to the unsuccessful applicant in the statement of reasons the Minister is required to provide under the Regulations (see Regulations 9(3), 15(4), 21(3) and 25(3)). The veracity of the Minister's reasons in this regard would be open to challenge by an unsuccessful applicant under Part 7 of the Regulations.

2. Apart from the specific Regulations to which you refer (Regulations 10, 11, 19, 22 and 26), I do not believe there are a number of decisions provided for in the Regulations about which there is not a right of reconsideration and review under Part 7 of the Regulations. In relation to those specific Regulations, our legal advice is that, apart from Regulation 10, it is hard to see a person ever needing to exercise a specific right of review.

Under Regulations 11 and 19, the only possible decision the Minister (or delegate) might make is the date on which the licence comes into effect. Likewise, the only decision the Minister might have to make under Regulations 22 and 26 is to which region or regions the licence applies. Whilst it is possible an applicant may be aggrieved by these "conditions and restrictions" contained in the licence, there is a general right of reconsideration and review (under Subregulation 37(2)(a)) of such "conditions and restrictions" imposed by the Minister under Regulations 12, 17, 23 and 27.

In addition to the review mechanisms provided by the Regulations, a person aggrieved by any of the Minister's (or delegate's) decisions may appeal on a question of law to the Federal Court under the Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review) Act 1977.

Whilst it is accepted that the Minister's decision under Subregulation 10(1) would more likely be a decision about which an applicant may be aggrieved, for the same reasons referred to above, it is not considered that a further avenue of review is required.

In relation to Regulation 32 (suspension of licence), any suspension or variation is for a maximum of 28 days and is provided to enable the Minister to further investigate any reasonable grounds he or she has that non-compliance with licence conditions or restrictions has adversely affected, or threatens to adversely affect, the environment. lf during this limited time period the Minister finds the belief may not be valid, he or she must cancel the suspension or variation.

Finally, a person aggrieved by the Minister's (or delegate's) decision to suspend or vary a licence may appeal on a question of law to the Federal Court under the Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review) Act 1977. In such circumstances it is considered that a specific review mechanism is not appropriate.

3. For reasons similar to those given in section 2 above, a statement of reasons is not provided for in relation to Regulation 32. Further, under Regulation 32, the only lawful reason upon which the Minister can suspend or vary the licence is the adverse effect, or the threatened adverse effect, to the environment occasioned by the licence holder's non‐compliance with the licence. This makes the need for a statement of reasons redundant. In any event, a person affected by such a decision could obtain reasons by giving a notice under section 13 of the Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review) Act 1977.

Similarly, although a statement of reasons is not provided for a decision under Regulation 31 to refuse to assign a licence, a person affected by such a decision could obtain reasons by giving a notice under section 28 of the Administrative Appeals Tribunal Act 1975, or under section 13 of the Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review) Act 1977.

4. Subregulation 36(4) requires the Minister to act on a request to reconsider certain decisions made by the Minister's delegate within 45 days of receipt of the request. This is considered to be a reasonable time limit.

However, a time limit on the making of original decisions (whether made by the Minister or the delegate) is not considered reasonable. The decision-maker has obligations under the Environment Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act 1974 and the Australian Heritage Commission Act 1975 (under which there are no time limits imposed on the Minister for the Environment or the Australian Heritage Commission) which may require him to consider comments from the Minister for the Environment and the AHC before a licence application is determined. If the Minister or delegate was forced to consider an application by virtue of a time limit, and did not have the aforementioned advice, he or she would have no choice but to refuse the application.

In any event, applicants may seek a Federal Court order requiring the Minister or delegate to make a decision under subsection 7(1) of the Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review) Act 1977 if the applicant has concerns about the length of time taken.

5. The Regulations include similar powers of delegation as the Export Control (Unprocessed Wood) Regulations (which have been in operation since 1986), and most other regulations within the portfolio. Further, any action or decision by a delegate may be subject to reconsideration by the Minister or subject to review by the Administrative Appeals Tribunal or the Federal Court as described above.

I also note the effect of paragraph 34AB(c) of the Acts Interpretation Act 1901. Under that paragraph, if the Minister delegates a power under the regulations, the power, when exercised by the delegate is taken to have been exercised by the Minister. Therefore, it is in the Minister's interests to delegate only to suitable persons.

6. With regard to your comments about the Explanatory Statement which accompanied the Regulations, whilst certain provisions deal with complex and "sensitive" matters, they are largely self-explanatory and implement the export regime clearly announced by the Government in July of this year.

The Regulations in large part adopt the same form and process provided under the recently disallowed Export Control (Hardwood Wood Chip) Regulations. Indeed, the bulk of the Regulations deal with established processes.

Finally, Parts 2 to 5 of the Regulations (dealing with the four different types of licences that may be granted by the Minister) mainly contain provisions which are repetitive of earlier provisions, and which again require little additional explanation.

I trust my advice on the above matters will address the Committee's concerns in relation to the Regulations, and that the notice of motion to disallow the Regulations, introduced by Senator Colston on 6 November, will be withdrawn.
However, should the Committee require additional advice or wish to discuss the above matters further, I or officers from my Department would be happy to meet with you at your earliest convenience.
Yours sincerely
(sgd) BRUCE SCOTT MP

The speech read as follows—

On 11 November 1996 the proposed referral to the Commonwealth by Victoria of the power to legislate over industrial relations matters in that State was jointly announced by the Honourable Peter Reith MP, Federal Minister for Industrial Relations; the Premier of Victoria, the Honourable Jeff Kennett; the Minister for Industry, Science and Technology, the Honourable Mark Birrell; and the Victorian Minister with responsibility for public sector industrial relations, the Honourable Roger Hallam.

This bill gives effect to the undertakings made that day to provide a simpler, cooperative industrial relations system in Victoria which benefits employees and employers and the wider community. It relies on the referral of relevant matters to the Parliament of the Commonwealth by Victoria's Commonwealth Powers (Industrial Relations) Bill 1996. This will allow the extended operation of the Workplace Relations Act 1996 in Victoria without the restrictions arising from the limits of power available under the Constitution. That wider operation will be in addition to the act's ordinary application.
The Commonwealth and State legislation marks a highly significant point in the evolution of Australian industrial relations. It is also a very substantial step forward in micro‐economic reform.
It demonstrates how State and Federal Governments can fundamentally transform the traditional relationship between their often competing jurisdictions to the immense benefit of the nation.

Just as importantly, such reform helps businesses and workers to enjoy far more productive workplace relationships. The Victorian Government deserves full recognition of its willingness to take such a historic initiative.

For too long, the Australian community has suffered from the collision of the Federal and State industrial relations systems. This rivalry has been at the expense of the efficiency of those systems, with consequent costs not just for the national and regional economies, but also for individual employers, workers and members of the wider community.

This bill marks a transition to a new phase in State and Federal cooperation. The bill will make access to the federal system easier for Victorian industry and workers. The inevitable legalism and complications of industrial relations under the overlapping State and Commonwealth jurisdictions will be dramatically reduced. The artificiality of creating inter‐State disputes to attract the Federal jurisdiction will cease.

In short, these arrangements will do much to give employers and workers in Victoria greater control of their working relationships without the distractions and jurisdictional problems which occur where there are potentially two sets of rules relating to them.

The Government hopes that the cooperation between the Commonwealth and Victoria will encourage other States to take similar action. This, however, is a matter for each State to consider in its own time and circumstances. Even so, there are very encouraging signs that other States also wish to work with us to improve the overall national system and to remove barriers to workplace flexibility and efficiency. This can be achieved by the creation of a single system, with its obvious immediate benefits, just as Victoria is doing, or by the harmonising of laws and practices and the sharing of resources, as we are seeing in other progressive States. In this context, I note the progress made by Queensland in reshaping its industrial relations laws to complement those of the Commonwealth.
All of this keeps the momentum up in the vital task of establishing a better framework for fair and productive industrial relations.
I turn now to the specific provisions of the bill.

Schedule 1 contains the amendments relating to the referral of matters by the Victorian Parliament, which will give wide legislative powers to the Commonwealth Parliament, subject only to a number of limited and specific exemptions in the State legislation from the referred matters. On Royal Assent to the bill, a new Part XV will be created in the Workplace Relations Act 1996. Division 1 of the new Part will provide a framework for additional provisions which will be inserted by proclamation of the remaining items in Schedule 1. This will enable the relevant provisions of this bill to commence with corresponding provisions under the Workplace Relations and Other Legislation Amendment Act 1996.

Division 2 of Part XV will extend the operation of the Commonwealth provisions concerning termination of employment, industrial disputes, certified agreements, Australian Workplace Agreements and freedom of association. These provisions will give the relevant parts of the Workplace Relations Act full operation in Victoria, for all employers and employees within the scope of the referred matters.

Division 3 of Part XV will introduce new provisions, designed to maintain certain entitlements now given by the Employee Relations Act 1992 of Victoria. This is necessary to ensure that there is an effective transition to the Federal system. Neither the Commonwealth nor the Victorian governments would accept a situation where some people were left without proper protection of their basic entitlements. We have agreed on the creation of a safety net of protection for Victorian workers based on that given now by the State legislation. This will ensure that anyone who is not subject to a Federal award or agreement will be guaranteed an enforceable right to an up‐to‐date minimum wage and to certain basic leave entitlements. This will apply both to employees under employment agreements and employees under ordinary contracts of employment.

In particular, the Workplace Relations Act will maintain the minimum conditions of employment which currently appear in Schedule 1 to the Employee Relations Act. These will be contained in a new Schedule 1A to the Workplace Relations Act. The Australian Industrial Relations Commission will become responsible for setting and periodically adjusting minimum wages, for employees not subject to a Federal award, certified agreement or AWA. This adjustment of minimum wages will be within the framework of industry sectors and work classifications which has been determined by the Employee Relations Commission of Victoria.

Again to ensure a minimum of disruption through the change in the system of industrial relations regulation, employment agreements under the State legislation will be given continuing operation.. However, no new agreements of that type will be able to be entered into.

The commitment of the parties to agreements which they have made under the State legislation will be recognised under the Workplace Relations Act, in the same way as for certified agreements and AWAs.
The parties to a continuing collective employment agreement will only be able to take protected industrial action to secure a certified agreement or an AWA when it expires.

The parties to a continuing individual employment agreement will only be able to take protected industrial action for such purposes three years after the commencement of these provisions. This reflects the absence of any provision in the State legislation for the expiry of such agreements. It is also consistent with the life of agreements under the Workplace Relations Act.

These requirements will not apply to employers or employees under employment agreements which have been deemed to exist by the operation of the legislation, for example, after State awards were abolished. Moreover, there will be nothing to prevent parties to any form of continuing employment agreement from agreeing to enter certified agreements or AWAs whenever they so wish.

There will be an Inter‐Governmental Agreement between the Commonwealth and Victoria in relation to the implementation and maintenance of the new arrangements. This is expected to address consultation between the Governments on the operation of the legislative scheme and of the referral generally. The agreement may also address the necessary administrative arrangements, which are still under discussion.
I will briefly refer to the remaining provisions of the bill. Some technical amendments are proposed. These are not related to the referral of matters by the Victorian Parliament.

Schedule 2 to the bill corrects a drafting oversight. The amendments to the Workplace Relations Act 1996 by that Schedule ensure that complementary State laws can confer power relating to the vetting of AWAs on the Commission, as well as on the Employment Advocate and authorised officers.

Schedule 3 to the bill adjusts the commencement provisions of the Workplace Relations and Other Legislation Amendment Act 1996. The amendments enable Schedule 12 of that act (which establishes the no‐disadvantage test) to commence before the commencement of item 3 of Schedule 10 of that act (which establishes Australian Workplace Agreements). This in turn will enable the commencement of Schedule 8 (which makes fresh provision for certified agreements) independently of the commencement of the AWA provisions.
I commend the bill to the Senate and present the explanatory memorandum.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the report.

On 8 May 1996 the Senate resolved to appoint a select committee to inquire into a range of issues relating to casinos. The terms of reference for the committee were quite broad but focused in particular on the tendering process for the Victorian casino licence. The committee advertised, seeking submissions, in early June this year. It also wrote to approximately 100 individuals and organisations, including the Premier of Victoria, and invited them to make a submission.

BREAK.PARA: The Premier's response to the committee was highly uncooperative. He refused to make a submission to the committee and said:
. . . the state of Victoria will assert its executive privilege against actions of the Commonwealth which threaten its autonomy or curtail its capacity to function effectively.

The committee was very disappointed at this response. It might have been expected that the Premier would welcome the opportunity to clear the air, but this was not the case. The Premier's lead was followed by many other Victorian state officials. One could well understand why this would be so.

This lack of cooperation would have made it very difficult for the committee to inquire into the issues the Senate asked it to. The committee was therefore obliged to consider the use of its powers to send for and examine persons and documents. The committee decided to seek advice on its powers, particularly with regard to the summoning and questioning of both present and former members of state parliament, state government officials, cabinet ministers and their advisers.

The committee sought and received advice on its legal position from both the Clerk of the Senate, Mr Harry Evans, and Professor Dennis Pearce from the ANU. They were able to provide the committee with much useful information and I would like to take this opportunity to thank both of them for the assistance they provided to the committee.

However, many of the issues canvassed in their advices have never come before a court. Although some guidance can be gained from previous judicial decisions, it is simply not possible to make a definitive statement about some of the Senate powers.
I will not attempt to set out all of the issues canvassed by the committee here. The advice received by the committee is reproduced in full and is extensively discussed in the committee's report.

The committee conclusions about how legal restrictions on its powers relate to the current inquiry may be summarised as follows. Current members of the Victorian parliament could not be summoned to appear before the committee. The committee may not be able to use its coercive powers in relation to matters which are not within the legislative competence of the Commonwealth. Inquiries directed at paragraph (D)(1) of the committee's terms of reference might fall into this category. That is a significant term of reference that the committee was looking at.

The conclusions also say the committee probably cannot use its coercive powers to compel the answering of questions related to the preparation and presentation of advice to the Victorian government or into its cabinet processes. These legal restrictions placed considerable limitations on the ability of the committee to conduct its inquiry.

The committee also considered the question of comity between federal and state parliaments. It took the view that, in general, and independently of any consideration of the legal position, the following guidelines should be followed by Senate committees:
Current and former members of state parliaments should not be summoned or required to answer questions on matters which relate to their activities as members of parliament or ministers.

Current and former senior public servants, ministerial advisers and members of statutory bodies should not be summoned or required to answer questions on matters which relate to their activities as advisers to state ministers or cabinet on policy issues.
The production of documents which were prepared for the purpose of informing, advising or decision making by state ministers or state cabinets should not be demanded.

Having settled on these guidelines, the committee decided that, while the issues it was pursuing were important, they did not justify overriding those guidelines and establishing a new precedent. As a consequence of the legal issues and the committee's adherence to the principles of comity, the committee decided that it was inappropriate to proceed with any public hearings.

The links between then Premier Bjelke‐Petersen in Queensland and the white shoe brigade in Queensland were a national embarrassment to this country. I was surprised to discover in a sophisticated Melbourne that there is a state of fear and apprehension in that city. The information on the public record is sufficient to establish there is a case to answer surrounding the casino and all the issues that are involved. A proper inquiry will divulge more evidence of the abuse of proper process. There is no question about this. It is clear also that there is an incestuous relationship between the government of Victoria and some entrepreneurs. It is a most unusual thing and reminds one of what happened in Queensland years ago. I was surprised to realise that that exists in a cosmopolitan city like Melbourne, but it does exist.

Unfortunately, the limits on the committee's powers have not allowed us to explore this relationship as we would have liked to, for the reasons that I have explained. Nevertheless, the committee recommends that a full judicial inquiry or royal commission into the tendering process for the Victorian Crown Casino be held, enabling issues relating to probity and the confidentiality of the tendering process to be investigated. That is a significant inquiry. We realise the gravity of that recommendation, but it is the only option any reasonable person who is not blinded by their political prejudice can come to.
Two distinguished former judges have summed up the situation. Both have extensive experience in reporting on casino issues. In his submission, Xavier Connor said:
Hon. Sir Laurence Street AC, KCMG, a former Chief Justice of New South Wales, said that the holder of a casino licence should be `squeaky clean.'

I agree with this and so, I think, do most people who have made a study of casinos. Indeed, the statute, by necessary implication, requires it. Presently I do not see how the Victorian casino authority could possibly have categorised Mr Williams as squeaky clean nor Hudson Conway Pty Ltd while he had a dominant interest in that company. However, in a matter as serious as that, it is important not come to a final conclusion until the other side is heard. Until I have heard what the authority has to say for itself, I prefer to suspend judgment.

That is the position. We were not able to have the inquiry as we would have liked. We were prevented from going to the evidence but there is no question what any reasonable person looking at what is on the public record will think—and of course we now know some of the things that people will raise if they can get a proper inquiry. That is one of the amazing things. Why I say there is a sense of fear in Victoria is that people are frightened to come forward as they have been bludgeoned verbally into not coming forward because they fear for their employment.

So that is the atmosphere that exists at this moment. The only way that it can be resolved is a proper and formal judicial inquiry or royal commission to protect all the people involved, including the people who are being challenged in this case—the entrepreneurs close to the Victorian government—and also ordinary people who believe in the probity of the public service and who want to make sure that in their state the matter of a casino, a most controversial issue at the best of times, is handled in a way that will leave us with dignity, being examined by a proper body. So I commend the recommendation of the committee to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Troeth, Sen Judith

TALK.START.PARA: —I have great pleasure in presenting the government senators' dissenting report on this inquiry, entitled A principled decision to wind up a politically motivated inquiry . From the outset we should understand that with regard to this inquiry there has been, for the first part, no evidence. If, indeed, the committee wrote to over 100 individuals, as detailed by Senator Childs, why did not one single person—or very few of them—decide to come to the committee and present evidence? Why was there no response?

SPEECH.PARA: Certainly there were legal restrictions in the sense that there should not be a compulsion for state parliamentarians or state public servants to necessarily appear before a Senate committee. But we should also go to the fact that most of the evidence provided for the allegations made in the majority report was provided in the Senate on 8 May in speeches made by Senator Carr and Senator Ray. Combined with the speeches of ex‐Senator Spindler, this is the basis on which the majority have decided to make their report.

Those who read the majority report will note that the non‐government senators and minor parties ignored the other terms of reference provided in the committee's terms of inquiry. They simply went for the jugular and decided to make this a political witch hunt into the Victorian government. The main purpose of this inquiry was an attack on the Victorian government. The other terms of reference were simply dispensed with. To say that the committee were not able to deal with them meant that they did not wish to deal with them.

The state government act of 1991 which provides for the Victorian Casino Control Authority makes provision for an inquiry to be conducted at intervals into its processes and operation and, as we have noted in our report, there is at present an inquiry going on into this. The authority embarked on its inquiry several months ago and it invited and received submissions from the public as part of that process. It is expected to report soon. Why, knowing this, would the non‐government parties expect to embark on an inquiry of their own which would simply duplicate the authority's inquiry? There is simply no reason for doing this and their report fails to offer any reason for doing that—and it fails to mention in any way, shape or form that very important provision of the Victorian government.

The government senators' report details the way in which there is no evidence. And, indeed, evidence was promised by Senator Woodley in his press release of 1 October in which he said, `We have a whole raft of documentary evidence to present.' Senator Woodley, where is that evidence? Certainly the committee are not aware of it and we would be very interested to see it. It is curious to see that Senator Woodley chose not to present any of it to the select committee. Several current and former Victorian state Labor members also claimed at various times to have evidence which would be useful to the committee. They or any other person who wished to present evidence to the committee was free to do so—and none did.

Senator Childs, you have had a long and distinguished career in the Senate and you have always been an honourable senator. I am very sorry to see you, as chair of this committee, indulging in such a grubby political exercise and I note the hesitancy with which you presented your report. Possibly this is an indication of the fact that you know that it is fatally flawed in both fact and logic. I am pleased to hear you describe Melbourne as a sophisticated and cosmopolitan city, which indeed it is, but I would point out to you that the government senators simply cannot agree with the principles contained in this report. We describe it as a fatally flawed document. That is the reason we have released a dissenting report.

I applaud the way principles of Senate committee behaviour have been laid out in your report but, unfortunately, the conclusions which you are led to by presenting some of those reasons are simply not borne out. As I said, the main purpose of this inquiry was a political attack on the Victorian government and the inquiry's other purported concerns were simply a facade.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —If this was a political attack—and only that—then certainly we would have had Mr Ron Walker and Mr Williams before the committee for a political exercise. What this report demonstrates is that a Senate committee must abide by the higher principles of the Senate rather than just, as Senator Troeth would allege, political motive. In the 96 years of the Senate it had never been clearly laid down anywhere as to the powers of Senate committees and as to their limitations and relationships with state governments. It is true that there are traces and strands of views in a number of books and papers going back over many decades but no‐one had ever thought to bring all that together. A reading of the speeches when this committee was set up, even those who opposed setting up the committee, shows this was not elucidated and was barely mentioned.

SPEECH.PARA: The great value of this report, putting aside the partisan arguments, is that, for the first time ever, a Senate committee has laid down what the relationship should be in terms of the powers of inquiry between federal parliament and state responsibility. We will not, I think, be able to accurately define when there is a severe overlap between the two. Nevertheless, Senator Childs and all the committee are to be congratulated on actually taking a principled position on this and laying down something that will be used by this chamber for many decades into the future.

BREAK.PARA: Senator Troeth invites us to produce evidence. I am happy to take you up on that, Senator Troeth. Next week I will come into this chamber with a whole range of documents and, naturally, you will talk to all your colleagues and you will seek their agreement to my tabling those documents in this chamber. I can tell you right now: you will not do so. You will do not do so.

The eventual recommendation of this committee is that, if we do not have sufficient powers to investigate this, we believe a independent judicial inquiry or royal commission should. It may well be argued that the only people excluded from giving evidence before this committee were current and ex‐state parliamentarians, public servants, statutory authority holders and employees, and police. At least half of the other witnesses could have been called. As I mentioned before, we could have turned it into a political circus and had Mr Walker and Mr Lloyd Williams along.

But this important principle must be established by this chamber, and I would say that, by the adoption of this report, it will: you cannot have two classes of citizens in this country. That is precisely what we would have done. We would have said all the police are exempt from giving evidence, all the employees of the casino authority are exempt, all politicians are exempt and all state public servants are exempt. If you do not happen to fall into that category, you could be subpoenaed and compulsorily forced to attend a committee hearing, and that, I do not believe, would be just. I think my colleagues took the view that that would not be just. Therefore, even if, as alleged by the government, there were political motivations here, in the end, principle well and truly prevailed.

For all the smirking of those opposite, I can at least say that I am quite happy at any stage to pull out my ticket of the Victorian branch of the Labor Party and look on it with pride. How Senator Troeth and Senator Kemp and the rest can look on their own Liberal Party ticket with any pride whatsoever when you see what has occurred in their own state branch, what has occurred in the state of Victoria in regard to this casino licence, what has occurred there in terms of lack of probity and what has occurred there in terms of political corruption, remains an absolute disgrace. It is an absolute disgrace that can only be dealt with by a royal commission or by an independent inquiry.

TALK.START.PARA: —You never produced any evidence. You had your chance and you never produced any evidence.

—Senator Kemp intervenes. Why, Senator Kemp, is the Victorian government currently amending the casino legislation to exempt a prohibited person? Prior to this, if there was any act of impropriety by any of the partners of the casino, then they lost the licence entirely. But now they are bringing in an amendment that, if one of the directors of the casino licence is found to be corrupt or an unfit person, the rest of them retain the licence. We know why. Because the Victoria government is now scared by some of the current police inquiries. If you want me to come in here next week I will be happy to come in on Gleem Pty Ltd and lay the whole thing out here in the Senate.
—Well, why didn't you produce it?

—Thank you. I will. I have the invitation. I will do that next week. I will go through the corrupt practices of Lloyd Williams and Ron Waker in regard to Gleem Pty Ltd on the invitation of Senator Troeth. Thank you very much. I will be here and I will do that on the adjournment next week. Thank you for the invitation to do that.

BREAK.PARA: Every time you look at your Liberal Party Victorian branch ticket, look on it with shame. Look on it with shame. Look back at the Auditor-General's report in regard to an extension of the casino and how the public were ripped off by hundreds of million dollars. I wonder how, in the second round bid of the casino tendering, they managed to up their bid by $90 million? I wonder how they did that? What about the conflict of interest between the architects and the others that were doing business with Hudson Conway at the time? I wonder how Lloyd Williams survived the Paisley Street, South Yarra scam and the royal commission into the builders labourers federation? What about the fact that he has twice had to be disciplined for breaching casino rules with Calcutta nights and minors on the premises?

There is a whole range of evidence. Those opposite ask: why was it not brought forward? The people I talked to all wanted to be compelled to come. They all wanted to be subpoenaed to come and give evidence there because of the climate of fear. Ask yourself about one of the biggest building companies that was called into the Victorian government and asked to shut up on this issue; otherwise their various road building contracts would be threatened in the state of Victoria.

This is stuff out of the deep south—deep out of the corporate state of Louisiana in the 1930s. Jeff Kennett is a modern day Huey Long—deduct box and all. It is all very well for Senator Troeth and the rest of the Victorian Liberal Party to smirk. Yes, smirk away. But principle has triumphed over political expedience in this case. So it always should. Nothing will take away the stench that exists over the Victorian casino licence that has existed in that state year after year ever since Jeff Kennett got involved in this particular issue.

This is one question I really would have liked to have asked in the committee. At the very time that Jeff Kennett was extending the casino licence, he was negotiating with Consolidated Press, who owned about a third of the casino at that stage, over a defamation settlement. Where is the conflict of interest rules there? How much money did Jeff Kennett get in that defamation settlement? It was rumoured to be a $400,000 settlement, at that very time he was making the person he settled with tens of millions of dollars by expanding the casino.

Jeff Kennett says, `The settlement's private, it can't be released.' It is in the public interest to release that sort of material so at least we know there is no connection between making tens of millions of dollars for one of the casino partners and a six‐figure defamation settlement. If the figure is $400,000, it is the highest private settlement that anyone has ever heard of in the state of Victoria.

Certainly, when those matters go to the courts in Victoria, you are very lucky to get even a six‐figure sum, let alone $400,000. It may be normal in New South Wales; it is not in Victoria. Yet none of that has to be declared, none of that has to be brought out into the open because of the privacy aspects supposedly surrounding a defamation settlement.

The second area that I would have liked to have looked at is all those companies working on the casino site that just happen to be the same companies doing the various renovations to Jeff Kennett's home worth $300,000. How many of them did contra deals? All the rumours are there. So when the opposition come in here and smirk away, let them smirk. I can at least have pride in the political probity that we on this side of the chamber abide with. Those on that side generally abide with it at a federal level, but they are willing to tolerate it at a state level.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Woodley, Sen John

TALK.START.PARA: —Let me firstly address some remarks made by Senator Troeth. I was interested that she included the Democrats in the majority report. Obviously she has not read, or taken note, that the Democrats certainly made a dissenting report. I note, Senator Troeth, that you were prepared to quote a press report from last October. I must say to you, I am behind in my reading, but I am not that far behind. I certainly read the report, plus my dissenting report, and I have had a quick look at yours because, obviously, it is only available now.

SPEECH.PARA: Regarding the evidence that you required, you asked, `Why wasn't that presented?' Let me tell you what happened. There were a number of journalists in Queensland who followed this whole issue with great interest, who were ready to put on the record information and evidence which did not attack the Liberal Party—which, in fact, probably put the Labor Party in less than a favourable light—but they said to me, `We're not going to stick our necks out and risk our careers if the Liberal Party is going to shut down this inquiry.' Let us be quite honest about it, the Liberal Party made sure that this inquiry did not proceed, with the help of the Labor Party which, I think, went to water a little bit on this. At least that is what I would claim.

I believe that, faced with the whole issue of investigating all of the casinos in this country, the Labor Party was aware that perhaps it had some casino skeletons in its cupboard as well, and so it was prepared to support a most scurrilous attack by the Premier of Victoria on this inquiry, in which he was forced to withdraw the aspersions he cast on my colleague, Senator Spindler. I believe that it was the weakness of the Labor Party and the determination of the Liberal Party which ensured that this inquiry did not go ahead.

I was particularly interested in the fact that there are many unanswered questions about the Treasury Casino in Queensland. One of our terms of reference was to ask whether or not the overseas reputation of Australia had been damaged. Let me read from the US company Harrah's report into the Treasury Casino. They claimed in 1992:

It is our view that, based upon what we know of the matter, the tendering process was not applied by the (Queensland) Government evenly among the various tenders for the (Treasury Casino) license, or consistently with the brief to applicants, including addenda, which the Government published and on which submissions were sought.
That company goes on to say, and this is on the public record:

. . . our unsatisfactory experience in connection with the Brisbane bid has resulted in a decision not to proceed with tenders for other available casino licenses in Australia, or, for that matter, any other business opportunities in Australia . . .
Was our overseas reputation damaged? It certainly was. That is not the Victorian casino; that is the Brisbane casino.

The Democrats want to say that this inquiry should have been opened up and it should have continued because there were many, many issues not just in Victoria but in other states which are part of the whole problem we have in this country with a growing casino culture, with a growing dependence of governments upon gambling revenue, which in the end is not only socially damaging but economically unsustainable as well. So that is why the Democrats have written a dissenting report and are very disappointed that the major parties saw fit to have this inquiry wound up. Let us make no mistake about it, the major criticism lies with the Liberal Party, who in this parliament decided they ought to protect their own party in the state of Victoria.

TALK.START.PARA: —You had a voice at the committee meetings.

—The majority report of the casino committee, Senator Troeth, found that the probe was hamstrung by the Victorian government's refusal to appear. They recommended that a full judicial inquiry or royal commission be held into the awarding of the Crown Casino licence. The Democrats agree with that. We certainly agree with parts of the majority report, and I make that clear right now.

SPEECH.PARA: However, we did not agree that there was sufficient reason not to continue with the inquiry, and I thought I made that clear all the way along. Certainly, you have criticised me, Senator Troeth, for saying that in the press. I accept that criticism, but I must say I was provoked at different times by what the Victorian Premier had said not only about my colleague, Senator Spindler, but also about the Democrats.

I believe that the shut down of this inquiry sets a dangerous precedent. I hear what Senator Ray has said, and I am sympathetic to some of what he said, but I believe it is a dangerous precedent for the Senate, which obviously now will cease even trying to subpoena public servants to give evidence before inquiries.

Where does that leave ordinary Australians? It means that powerful people within the political system in this country will be quarantined from the probing of this Senate. It means that they will have nowhere to go. We discovered that in the whistleblower inquiry. It was only Senate inquiry which enabled those people to be heard and which enabled them to continue their struggle for justice. If we remove this avenue from ordinary people, then they will continue to struggle against injustice whenever state jurisdictions want to make sure that inquiries by this Senate will not proceed.

BREAK.PARA: I believe that today we have seen the powerful walk away from scrutiny without a thought about how ordinary Australians can get justice.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine, Sen Brian

TALK.START.PARA: —I enter this second reading debate in its dying moments—as I understand it, only three people are listed to speak. There have been considerable and well worthwhile contributions to the second reading debate. Feelings about this matter run very high; it is an important matter. I have had an enormous number of calls and correspondence about this matter, mostly against the one‐third sale. However, there has also been a number of thoughtful contributions from the public about why a third of Telstra or, indeed, the whole of Telstra should be sold.

SPEECH.PARA: Even this morning, I received a telephone call on my message answering system from somebody in the outback of New South Wales who was concerned about the failure of Telstra to live up to its reputation and to serve the bush. That no doubt was an isolated matter. Nevertheless, it was of interest. For all of those who have contacted my office, I express my appreciation and hope they understand that it is impossible for me, with the very small number of staff that I have, to respond to them individually.

Yes, feelings are running high about this matter. There is quite a lot of emotional support for Telstra. This, of course, is because of its history in Australia: it has been an organisation which has assisted in nation building. Many people have worked for Telstra or its predecessor. In the 1950s I for one, for example, worked for a couple of years for Telstra which was then called the PMG's Department engineering division. I remember very well a number of those who were working at that time, including the father of one of the honourable senators here in this chamber. He was a remarkable man who had a high degree of commonsense and wisdom.

Telstra is an organisation which the people have taken to heart. The threatened one‐third sale of Telstra has raised the spectre of unemployment. Jobs are being slashed from Telstra at the present moment, irrespective of whether there is going to be a one‐third sale. That is a result of preparation by Telstra for the deregulatory environment post‐July of next year. That is a matter that had been planned as a result of decisions taken by the previous government and by this government as well.

The question of efficiency of Telstra is one that I have also had a good look at. The World Bank did do a study on the communications industry as to whether efficiency was affected by ownership. The answer generally was that, yes, it is affected by ownership if we are talking about underdeveloped countries. But with regard to developed countries, particularly those countries with a vigorous parliamentary democracy and a system of checks and balances, the World Bank report says that it is not necessarily ownership but structure and management that are the key factors. The government has a different view of that matter.

The Minister for Communications and the Arts (Senator Alston) will remember that I wrote to him on 2 September. I did get a shock as a matter of fact when I felt that the government was then saying that, although they were going to sell only one‐third of Telstra, that was likely to be a springboard for the sale of the whole of Telstra. I got a bit jittery about that. I know that other instrumentalities, other Australian icons like the Commonwealth Bank, have been sold—against my wishes, I point out. Senator Alston's comments drew the response of 2 September from me. I raised with him my concern that a one‐third sale of Telstra would be used as a springboard for the ultimate sale of Telstra; that even a one‐third sale might mean there was so much of an economic focus by Telstra that certain obligations that the old Telstra had towards regional and rural Australia would not be in the forefront of their mind.

Among the matters of greatest concern to me was that Tasmania would be left in a communications backwater, that it would not be able to travel the communications highway—to mix metaphors. The question of jobs was, and is, also a matter of great concern. All right: the government had indicated—and I believed that this was the core undertaking; they tell us about mandates—that what they intended to do and what they said to the people that they would do is attempt to get $8 billion from a one‐third sale of Telstra to help to redeem debt with $7 billion and to establish the Natural Heritage Trust with $1 billion or a little more.

With regard to that matter, I believe that all of Australia should recognise—and the government on behalf of all of Australia should recognise—the pre‐eminent position of Tasmania's natural heritage. I know that the government has been giving very serious consideration indeed to that matter. I actually favour the establishment of a fund—whether or not it comes from the proceeds of Telstra.

The fund proposed by the government involves five key areas, including the natural vegetation initiative and the coast and clean seas initiative. As a matter of fact, disbursements from the fund for Tasmania according to its population do not work because, with regard, for example, to the coast and clean seas initiative, many honourable senators may not know that the coastline of Tasmania is longer than the coastlines of New South Wales and Victoria put together. There are numerous examples of that in the natural heritage area.

The three other key areas are: land and water audit; national reserve system; and the Murray‐Darling 2001 project. The capital programs would be complemented by programs providing for land care, river care, world heritage management, farm forestry, a national weed strategy, feral animal control and a national wetlands strategy and so on. The `and so on' includes endangered species. In my letter to Senator Alston I indicated my concern that the government should, in disbursements from the Natural Heritage Trust, should it be established, recognise the pre‐eminence of Tasmania.

My discussions with the government on that matter, and indeed on the other matters, have been courteous, amicable and fruitful, depending upon a confirmation of those matters. Confirmation of the areas has been given to me, but in general I believe it would be useful for the chamber to hear of those matters, which include the need to ensure that Tasmania does not become a communications backwater. The large cities will have the cable roll-out. That is not proposed for Tasmania at present, but there are other ways of achieving a suitable end result.

BREAK.PARA: The remaining question that concerns me considerably is obtaining the $8 billion from a one‐third sale of Telstra by the issue of ordinary shares. I have proposed to the government in my letter that it should consider the issue of redeemable preference shares in a variety of ways. The government has been giving that proposal considerable thought. I believe that the one‐third sale of Telstra by ordinary shares would realise far more than the $8 billion that is suggested. An $8 billion one‐third sale presumes that the organisation is valued at $24 billion, whereas amongst the people whom I have had advice from I have heard no-one agree that it is worth only $24 billion. Madam Acting Deputy President, I seek leave to have incorporated in Hansard a brief back-of-the-envelope assessment that was done by my office which indicates that a one‐third sale could well yield $15 billion.

TALK.START.PARA: —The day before yesterday the Treasurer (Mr Costello) sent me a letter which rejected the third proposal for redeemable preference shares. In his letter he made a number of statements which I find extraordinary. The statements were based on certain assumptions which are not necessarily to be made. BREAK.PARA: At the outset, I note the importance of market signals in applying pressure for continuous improvement in the management of public sector trading enterprises such as Telstra. The partial sale of Telstra will significantly assist in achieving that goal.

The government has given me nowhere to go in regard to the two other matters that I have been discussing with it. I hope that the government will confirm those matters in broad terms at the end of the second reading debate. However, I am still very concerned about this question of the one‐third sale. I know it is not the complete sale of Telstra. That cannot be done without the approval of the people at a future poll.

TALK.START.PARA: —It can be done tomorrow.
—It can. That is true. I know that promises can be broken.
—That's presuming that's the only issue that determines the vote.

—But it has to go through parliament. Nevertheless, I do not think the government has thoroughly examined all the aspects of this matter. I believe that, as a minimum measure, the government should, for the benefit of everyone, agree to the reference of that matter to a Senate committee. As a minimum, if the second reading is passed and the committee stage is concluded, it should agree to have the proclamation date delayed until after the report of the Senate select committee. Under those circumstances, if all these matters are satisfactorily concluded, I believe that I would be doing my duty in voting for the second reading.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Colston, Sen Malcolm

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating today the Telstra (Dilution of Public Ownership) Bill 1996. The explanatory memorandum accompanying this bill states, amongst other things, that the principal purpose of the bill is to facilitate the sale of up to one-third of the Commonwealth's equity in Telstra Corporation Ltd.

SPEECH.PARA: The appearance of this bill did not take either house of the federal parliament by surprise. The possibility of its introduction was widely canvassed during the election campaign earlier this year. Indeed, the issue was a major plank in the policy of the then Howard opposition which was placed before the Australian people.

The government's proposal to privatise one-third of Telstra should be considered against a background of previous sales of public assets in Australia. During the last decade and a half, the partial and complete privatisation of public assets has gained currency as a way in which governments can fulfil their spending priorities without raising taxes. These sales have usually been dressed up as a strategy to achieve philosophical objectives, such as the need for greater competition or the desirability of governments to leave business activity to the private sector and, where necessary, use their powers to regulate that activity. However, the true objectives in most cases have been to help balance budgets or to repatriate debt.

The Commonwealth has not been the only government in Australia to sell public assets. It is worth while reminding ourselves of some of the more significant sales undertaken by the states in the last decade or so. These are some examples of such sales: in New South Wales, the State Bank and the Government Cleaning Service; in Victoria, the Grain Elevators Board and the Port of Portland; in Queensland, Gladstone Power Station; and, in Western Australia, the State Government Insurance Office and State Print. In South Australia, there were sales of the Bank of South Australia and the State Clothing Corporation, and in Tasmania, Tasmanian Travel Centres and the Tasmanian Government Insurance Office.

At the Commonwealth level, governments prior to the Hawke and Keating era of 1983-96 did not hesitate to sell public assets. Some examples of such sales prior to 1983 include the Commonwealth Oil Refinery, half of which was formerly owned by the Commonwealth; the Commonwealth Engineering Company; Amalgamated Wireless (Australasia); the Australian Whaling Commission; the Australian Aluminium Production Commission; and, in the ACT, Belconnen Shopping Mall, Mugga Quarry and the Commonwealth Brickworks.

As the electorate is well aware, the previous Labor government had a reputation for pursuing a policy of privatisation. The fact that the sales in the period 1983 to 1996 comprise a lengthy list give some indication of the ardour with which that government engaged in the sale of assets to achieve its fiscal objectives. Some, but not all, of the previous Hawke and Keating Labor government asset sales include the Tokyo Embassy sale‐redevelopment project; Aussat Pty Ltd; the lease on Chifley Square in Sydney; the Williamstown dockyard; the Commonwealth phosphate stockpile; the Commonwealth Government Centre in Melbourne; the head of mission residence in Paris; the Defence Service Homes Corporation, the National Materials Handling Bureau; the Lindfield property in New South Wales; Film Australia; Australia House in Sydney; the Australian Defence Force home loans assistance scheme; housing loans assistance schemes in the Australian Capital Territory; and the sale of Australian Airlines to Qantas.

BREAK.PARA: The year 1993 was a privatisation benchmark in Australia's economic history. The Commonwealth Bank's second share offer in 1993 was for only 19 per cent of the bank's share capital compared with the original offer of 30 per cent in 1991. Yet the second offer in 1993 was the largest ever government asset sale in Australia in terms of market value. It was the first open price tender offer and the first offer with dollar retail value applications. The sale of the 19 per cent share of the Commonwealth Bank raised $1.7 billion. But there was more that year. British Airways acquired 25 per cent of Qantas for $665 million, and AGL acquired 51 per cent of the Moomba-Sydney pipeline for $280 million.

The privatisation policy that began in the early 1980s and grew throughout the Hawke administration years developed into an art form during the era of the Keating government. The policy of privatisation was maintained in the years following 1993 with the sale of further assets, such as the Snowy Mountains Engineering Corporation Ltd, Aerospace Technologies of Australia and Commonwealth Serum Laboratories Ltd as well as the major assets of Qantas and the remainder of the Moomba-Sydney pipeline.
