In addition, legislation was prepared to sell what was left of the Commonwealth Bank.

Notwithstanding the frequency with which assets were sold, the Labor government's program of privatisation did not prevent its re‐election in 1984, 1987, 1990 and 1993. It may be misleading to imply that these election results signified that the electorate accepted the then government's policy of privatisation, but it is certainly plain that the electorate did not consider privatisation to be so untenable as to vote the Labor government out of office. At worst, the electorate endured it. At best, it silently judged it to be a necessary and appropriate method of gaining government revenue.

Because privatisation had become a fact of life during Labor's 13‐year term of office, it was ironic that privatisation should become an election issue to distinguish the two major parties during the last election campaign. Although the matter was originally raised by the then coalition opposition, it became a central issue in the campaign due to the actions of the then Prime Minister, Mr Keating.
On 14 February 1996 Mr Keating, in launching the Labor Party's campaign in Melbourne, threw down the gauntlet to the electorate. He said:
Let's be clear about this. One party will sell Telstra if they win this election, the other party not. The coalition will sell it. The Labor Party will not.

Disregarding the error of syntax and the omission that the coalition planned to sell only one-third of Telstra's equity, it was a clear attempt to use the issue of a possible sale of Telstra to set the two major parties apart in terms of policy. In view of the Labor government's pursuit of a policy of privatisation, observers could be forgiven for thinking that the then Prime Minister displayed less of a desire to retain public ownership of Telstra than the desire to have a real issue upon which to fight the election. Perhaps that is being unkind, but it was a clear reversal of policy for Labor.

Whatever the then Prime Minister's reason, the coalition canvassed its proposal for the partial sale of Telstra publicly and openly. On 18 February this year, the then Leader of the Opposition, Mr Howard, formally launched the Liberal Party's campaign and formalised the coalition's commitment to the sale of one-third of Telstra. At the same time, he emphasised that two-thirds of Telstra would remain in government ownership, and that his government would legislate to prohibit timed local calls and maintain the existing price caps. He also made promises in respect of maintaining the community service obligations, to ensure that rural and regional Australia would receive fair and equitable services. The one-third sale was strategically linked to a $1 billion fund to be set aside for environmental projects.

The results of the election were quite clear. The electorate did not support the Keating government in its bid to retain office. Whether Telstra was uppermost in the electors' minds as they cast their votes is difficult to determine. Whatever is the case, with the coalition being returned with a clear majority of 40 over the combined total of Labor and the independents in the House of Representatives, it is hard to argue that the coalition did not obtain a mandate to sell one-third of Telstra.

There are at least four principal justifications which are used by governments to rationalise their policies of privatisation. While I cannot give unqualified support for these reasons, it is pertinent to examine them. The first and most stated justification is that privatisation can provide fiscal relief for governments. It is not unfair to suggest that the privatisation program of the former Labor administration was one which was motivated largely by the government's desire to reduce its budget deficits. It was a policy which the Labor government chose to follow, regardless of the protests that it was `selling the family silver to pay the bills'. Nonetheless, there appears to be no hard evidence that the net impact from the sale of major assets by the previous Labor government has been detrimental to Australia's economic wellbeing.

A second justification which is often proposed is that privatisation results in the improved efficiency of an enterprise, a notion which has its origins in the concept of competition. This argument suggests that the organisation strives for internal efficiency, driven by the competition of market forces.

Third, those who support the sale of public assets suggest that this is justified on the basis that it enables national companies to engage in international economic integration. If this is so, it is worthy of consideration, as Australia strives to establish itself as a world class competitor in the field of telecommunications. Fourth, it is claimed that privatisation lends itself to another inclination of governments across the Western world; namely, the creation of what might be called the `shareholder' culture. As far as a partial sale of Telstra is concerned, there must be serious doubts that a majority of Telstra workers or their neighbours would be likely to be able to participate as shareholders in the floated part of Telstra. We should not deceive ourselves on this matter, because for many in the Australian community individual investment is a luxury.

Other factors, of course, are important in this debate—factors such as the status of non-commercial benefits which are generally attributed to government owned business enterprises. There are justifiable concerns that non-commercial benefits or `social benefits' will be accorded a lower priority in an enterprise that pursues commercial gain with the single‐mindedness traditionally reserved for private enterprise. In this regard, the universal service obligations of Telstra constitute the most significant commitment by the organisation to the provision of `social' benefits.

The cross-subsidies which fund the universal service obligations facilitate the provision of a standard telephone service throughout Australia. It is a service targeted to the needs of people living across this vast continent and it provides the necessary telecommunications services essential for the conduct of everyday business. By guaranteeing access to untimed local calls, continuous access to the telephone network, emergency number facilities and operator assistance, Telstra is part and parcel of the standard of living enjoyed by ordinary Australians.

It is essential that the current commitment to remote areas is not diminished if a partial privatisation of Telstra goes ahead. My major concern is that the process of partial privatisation should not, as far as practically possible, result in job losses in regional areas. The economies of rural communities and regional cities are quite fragile in that there are fewer wage-earners sustaining them than there are in metropolitan areas. While a small change in employment numbers may be able to be accommodated in metropolitan areas, the same cannot occur in Australia's rural and regional areas. Our rural communities are too important for the wellbeing of the nation's economy to ignore what job losses will do to those communities.

While I accept that there will be changes to the employment structures of large enterprises due to technological advancements, I do not consider it to be a foregone conclusion that some jobs have to be lost in the near future or that they have to be lost in large numbers in regional areas. It is part of the national character of telecommunications services in this country that telephone operators have been located in regional centres, rather than in metropolitan areas. It is of no concern to telephone callers in Brisbane that their queries for subscribers' telephone numbers are attended to by operators hundreds of kilometres away. Because of past policies of decentralising these operator services away from major metropolitan areas, in some towns Telstra is a major employer. I cannot accept that the viability of these towns should be threatened because of a partial privatisation of Telstra. To be acceptable, the privatisation process has to reap benefits. There can be no benefits if a major source of employment is effectively moved from regional and rural areas.

I am mindful of the employment needs of other areas of Australia, but my principal responsibility is to the people of Queensland. In this respect, I believe at this stage I am close to negotiating a satisfactory resolution in relation to the employment opportunities for telephone operators in regional areas of Queensland. In addition, I have engaged in discussions on ways in which services to rural Queensland may be enhanced. I expect those negotiations could have a satisfactory outcome before the end of the committee stages.

I will, therefore, support the second reading of the bill, with the fall-back position that there is a further opportunity to vote against the measure at the third reading if the negotiations and discussions to which I have referred have not been satisfactorily concluded.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard

TALKER.NAME: Senator ALSTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Communications and the Arts)

TALK.START.PARA: —It is now my pleasure to sum up a debate which undoubtedly has provoked fairly strong views on a variety of subjects, but the government's core position remains that telecommunications is one of the fastest growing sectors of the world economy. It is characterised by increasing levels of competitive, financial and technological risk. The international evidence is very clear as to the benefits and, indeed, the path down which virtually all other governments are now proceeding. The reasons for those are essentially the same, and they have been spelt out in very clear detail in the minority report.
—It could still be wrong.

—Of course, the rest of the world can always be wrong and only we can be right, but none of the evidence suggests that. Both the majority and minority Senate committee reports concluded that there was scope for Telstra to improve its performance against a range of measures. There was extensive empirical and factual evidence that realisation of this improvement through increased efficiency would have substantial benefits for economic growth and consumer welfare.

SPEECH.PARA: I will not rehearse all the arguments that have been gone through on many occasions in support of privatisation. However, I do want to deal briefly with three of the major claims that were made by the opposition in the Senate committee report: firstly, that it would undermine the universal service obligation; secondly, that it would involve selling off Australian assets to foreigners; and, thirdly, that it would weaken the industry development arrangements.

In respect of the universal service obligation, the ownership of Telstra has no effect whatsoever on the universal service obligation. The government is committed to retaining the legislatively required USO; that is, the obligation to make the standard telephone service and payphones reasonably accessible to all Australians on an equitable basis. Austel has the necessary powers to enforce the USO, including the ability to direct Telstra to provide particular services under the USO.

Consistent with the government's commitment, the level and quality of services provided under the USO is currently being examined under the review of the standard telephone service. The diversity of interests represented on the review will ensure that an appropriate balance is reached between the benefits and costs of any upgrade to the existing requirement for a 2,400 bits per second service.

PARA.BREAK: While in opposition, the coalition played a major role in highlighting the poor service being provided to Australians outside the major metropolitan areas. To address this, the government has decided to legislate for a customer service guarantee. The system which was put in place by our predecessors has not worked well enough and needs to be re inforced through specific obligations in legislation which cannot easily be watered down.

SPEECH.PARA: The government has always intended that all carriers should be subject to a licence condition, to have an industry development plan and to report on progress with its implementation. It is nonsense to suggest that privatising Telstra will erode the value of such arrangements. Under the current industry arrangements, the privately owned carriers—Optus and Vodafone—are achieving higher Australian content than Telstra. In 1995-96, Optus had a local content of 73 per cent; Vodaphone, 67 per cent; compared with Telstra, 65 per cent.

The foreign ownership rules in the bill will mean that, even if foreign persons or foreign companies take up all the shares which are available to them, Telstra will remain over 88 per cent Australian owned. No individual foreign shareholder or associated group of shareholders will be able to hold more than 1.7 per cent of the company. The government will not allow Telstra to be owned or controlled by foreigners. The foreign ownership limits are supported by a range of enforcement provisions to ensure this commitment is met. With the requirements for incorporation, head office and base of operations to be in Australia, and for the chairman and the majority of directors to be Australian, decision making and control of strategic direction will remain firmly in Australian hands.

The government's approach to telecommunications policy has properly been directed at ensuring that the benefits of reform are made available to all residents of Australia, both regional and metropolitan. The government is confident that a competitive telecommunications policy framework is most likely to provide the widest practical access to advanced services at the least cost to the community's resources.

PARA.BREAK: The government recognises the particular problems confronting telecommunications users in regional and rural Australia and believes it has a special responsibility to assist such users to achieve equality of access to telecommunications services. For too long, particularly over the last 13 years, govern ments have been content to see non‐metropolitan Australia lagging well behind the capital cities in their access to high quality, state‐of‐the‐art communications services.

SPEECH.PARA: As Austel observed in November this year, in general the more remote parts of Australia have benefited last from the introduction of all types of new technology, and telecommunications has been no exception. Quality of service data collected by Austel consistently shows that service in non‐metropolitan areas is below that enjoyed by the cities. Again, according to Austel, rural communities in several parts of Australia have expressed concern that their services will not keep pace with improvements in the overall network and may even deteriorate. Rural communications users are also disadvantaged through higher call charges, less sophisticated network infrastructure and billing data, and longer waiting periods for telephone connections.

This situation cannot be allowed to continue. We have already taken some action to address these problems. For example, we have obtained from Telstra an agreement to accelerate effective completion of digitisation of its network by December 1998, and the extension of ISDN capability to 93.4 per cent of Australians within 90 days of request by 1 July 1997.

But significant problems remain, and I acknowledge today the particular difficulties faced by Tasmania. Not only does Tasmania suffer from all the isolation problems arising from being divided from the mainland by a large waterway, but also it has more than half its population located outside the capital city. It has suffered for too long from the problems of an inferior telecommunications infrastructure. These problems are highlighted by its lack of access to new technology such as the broadband cable system which is being installed in areas of mainland Australia. In an age when a modern telecommunications infrastructure is becoming a prerequisite for business development, Tasmania is particularly vulnerable.

In the lead‐up to the March election, our policy commitments recognised that Tasmania had been systematically disadvantaged over many years and that specific action needed to be taken to redress this problem. The government believes that the partial sale of Telstra and the proceeds that will flow from that sale provide a unique opportunity to improve communications for regional and rural communities in Tasmania, as well as other parts of Australia. For example, in the Northern Territory isolated Aboriginal communities require particular attention.

Senator Harradine quite rightly reminded me of his letter of 2 September in which he said that amongst the matters of greatest interest to him were whether state of the art technology could be guaranteed to regional Australia, including his state of Tasmania; whether Tasmania's natural heritage pre‐eminence would be properly recognised in the disbursement of funds from the Natural Heritage Fund, and some other matters which I do not need to address precisely at this point in time.

It is also fair to say that a substantial portion of Senator Harradine's letter was concerned with the issue of redeemable preference shares and whether that was a route down which the government could go and still achieve its fundamental objectives. As Senator Harradine said, the letter he received from the Treasurer (Mr Costello) several days back pointed out the government's position at this point as not being in favour of that proposition, but we are prepared to examine the issue further. I understand Senator Harradine's concerns in relation to the issue and the need to have all of the possibilities fully explored, and we do agree that it would be appropriate for the issue to be referred to a Senate committee and for a report back to the parliament prior to 31 March, which would be our suggestion, and that there should be a delay in proclamation to accommodate that committee stage report.

It is certainly an issue that will provide the opportunity for a number of experts and interested parties to flesh out some of the arguments that Senator Harradine has put before the Senate and the public over recent months, and certainly I understand what he says in relation to the ability to have fluctuating dividends. The problem, I suppose, with that is that at times you can still maintain a consistent level of dividend, or even a higher level of dividend, even if your underlying profitability is not going up, but certainly I think it is worthy of further examination, as I have indicated, and we are prepared to consider it further on that basis.

Madam Acting Deputy President, accordingly, the government is prepared to commit $250 million from the proceeds of the partial sale of Telstra to create a regional telecommunications infrastructure fund which will operate over five years, and the money will be used to improve the quality of telecommunications services and to enhance employment opportunities in regional areas throughout Australia. The fund will directly improve the quality of telecommunications infrastructure in rural and regional areas, including the expansion of mobile phone coverage; will create employment opportunities in areas of high rural unemployment by assisting the establishment of customer call centres; assist community managed profit and non‐profit communications projects in regional areas; and establish additional Internet points of presence in regional areas to reduce or eliminate the STD charge associated with Internet access.

In addition to directly assisting employment opportunities in regional Australia, the fund will enhance the competitiveness of regional businesses and enhance employment prospects by improving the access of regional Australia to state‐of‐the‐art telecommunications facilities. This initiative will be welcomed by all rural and regional communities, and is a further concrete expression of this government's determination to ensure that all Australians benefit from developments in communications technology.

I also note in particular Senator Colston's comments about the validity of ensuring that people in rural and remote areas are not bypassed that there are some services that do not necessarily have to be located adjacent to the calling areas, and that in particular operator‐assisted services do provide opportunities to ensure that the level of employment in regional areas is not eroded. We will certainly be addressing those matters.

BREAK.PARA: Can I say, in relation to the Natural Heritage Trust fund, that the government recognises more than ever the need to reinvest capital in Australia's natural heritage. The Natural Heritage Trust is an historic proposal, the most significant attempt to repair and conserve our natural environment ever by a Commonwealth government.

TALK.START.PARA: —It's a bribe.

—I know it hurts. We recognise that it needed an input of significant capital. We found the way to do it—a reinvestment from the part sale of an asset to another asset, our natural capital. One billion dollars is a large amount of money, but the extent of the damage too is very great. Premier Court recently spoke about the enormous damage as a result of salination. He is absolutely right in respect of his state, but it is also a significant problem occurring elsewhere on a major scale.

BREAK.PARA: Rising water tables, salination, erosion, degraded creeks and inland waterways, damage to our coastline—the list is very long. So much so, we have decided to increase the contribution to the fund by another $100 million. The capital contribution from the sale to the environment will be $1.1 billion.

Responding to Senator Harradine, we accept his argument. Tasmania is pre‐eminent in natural heritage. One third of Tasmania has been committed to national parks or conservation reserves, a much higher proportion than anywhere else in the country. To maintain this to the standard that all Australians expect is very expensive.

Tasmania has forgone economic potential in making the commitment to all Australians. Furthermore, Tasmania has significant unemployment problems, and tourism based on maintaining the quality of its natural heritage is vitally important. We can therefore assure Senator Harradine that these special issues which apply to Tasmania will be taken into account in the distribution of trust funds.

Senator Harradine went out and fought vigorously for Tasmanian interests, and we accept the validity of his case. We have been working closely with the Tasmanian government to achieve a fair distribution of funds and we believe that the assurances we have been able to give the Tasmanian government will reflect a recognition and acceptance of the merits of Senator Harradine's arguments.

In conclusion, Australia needs a world‐class telecommunications system. Our future growth and prosperity depends on it. World‐class telecommunications systems can be provided only by world‐class telecommunications carriers. The corporatisation of Telstra, the introduction of limited competition, and advances in mobile and digital infrastructure have all contributed to better and cheaper telecommunications services. But you do not become world class and you certainly do not stay there by standing still.

There is clearly something still missing. Telstra needs an infusion of private sector culture and capital. Telstra's management needs to know that every decision is being watched by investors who will dump them if they make the wrong decision. The whole company needs to know that there is no safety net.

The government cannot guarantee that in an environment increasingly subject to competitive and technological risks that Telstra will grow and prosper. In the absence of private equity in Telstra, the risk that management will fail to respond effectively will be the greater and will be borne entirely by the taxpayer. If we do not take this opportunity now we will start the next century playing catch‐up while our major trading partners reap the rewards of having introduced varying degrees of private ownership into their communications carriers.

I do not need to say yet again that not only is it our firm commitment not to go beyond one third without approval from the people at an election—unlike Mr Keating, who had no compunction about breaking those sorts of promises—but to do so would involve a change in this very legislation. This legislation ensures that, without the approval of the parliament, you could go no further and we have no intention of going any further.

No convincing argument has been put forward on public policy grounds for retaining Telstra in full public ownership. The arguments come down to a resistance to change. The real test of these arguments is that no Australian government of any persuasion would buy a telecommunications company today. In fact, you would be hard pressed to find a government anywhere in the world interested in buying a telecommunications company.

TALK.START.PARA: —I don't want to buy one; I just want to keep the one we own.

—Indeed, so why would you continue to want to own part of it? We need to consider how Australia would be best served by its telecommunications carrier in the future. This bill, with its balance of consumer safeguards and ownership controls, provides an opportunity for Telstra to grow and develop into a truly world‐class telecommunications carrier while at the same time guaranteeing benefits to consumers.

BREAK.PARA: The partial sale of Telstra will also provide a unique opportunity to improve the communications services for rural Australia through the creation of a regional telecommunications infrastructure fund. Let's be perfectly clear about this. This fund will ensure, for the first time, that people around Australia outside the capital cities will get very real and substantial benefits in terms of access to telecommunications facilities.

TALK.START.PARA: —How come Queensland and Tasmania are the only parts of Australia that get a run in your speech, Senator? I am astonished!

—You might think we are talking just about Tasmania, but I can assure you that Queensland has a very high proportion of people outside major cities. There is a very large number of persons in areas of the state of Queensland in particular who will benefit from this proposal. It is a proposal that will benefit all Australians. It recognises that there is an imbalance that requires an approach that makes sure that all Australians benefit. I can assure you that those who have the largest claim will benefit the most.

BREAK.PARA: We certainly accept the proposition that there are people, particularly in rural and remote parts of Queensland, for whom you would otherwise have concerns about loss of jobs. You will see increases in jobs on the basis that some of these services will be retained in those areas. I have to say that Senator Colston has made vigorous representations of behalf of Queensland, and it was open to any of those opposite to make similar representations on behalf of your constituents.

If your constituents were not interested, that is your problem. They will be very annoyed. But they will also be very pleased when they see what we have been able to do for them despite your efforts. I assure you that those who have drawn particular problems to our attention have succeeded in demonstrating the validity of arguments in favour of ensuring people outside capital cities are not second‐class citizens.

You have not been prepared to put their interests where they ought to be. You have been prepared to see lags in services. You have not really cared if they are second‐class citizens because, basically, you write off the bush when it comes to elections. You think that as long as you stitch up the western suburbs and pander to a few of the middle class in the eastern suburbs, that will get you over the line.

We do not take that line. This bill will inject new life into Telstra and, in the process, provide a mechanism to ensure that both regional and metropolitan Australia are ready for the challenges and opportunities of the 21st century.

PARA.TAB: Question put:
That the bill be read a second time.

PARA.EMPHASIS: * denotes teller

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

BREAK.PARA: Bill read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kernot, Sen Cheryl

TALKER.NAME: Senator KERNOT
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —Pursuant to contingent notice, I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That so much of the standing orders be suspended as would prevent Senator Kernot moving a motion relating to the conduct of business of the Senate, namely a motion to postpone consideration of the Telstra (Dilution of Public Ownership) Bill 1996 in committee of the whole until the day after the day on which a Senate committee reports on the sale of Telstra by the issue of redeemable preference shares.

I think we all know why this is necessary. We have Senator Harradine saying that he wants the proclamation of this bill delayed until the Senate committee looks at the issue of re deemable preference shares. There are no amendments ready from Senator Harradine on the issue of redeemable preference shares.

We have had no time to canvass other committee options. I do not believe it is appropriate for us to go through the next stages of the bill in the hope that we might be able to insert something or reject something at the end of another really important part of the Senate process. I think we have got the process wrong and we should not proceed until we have finished what Senator Harradine considers to be the next really important stage. Why should we commit ourselves to this process and possible further reading then just leave the proclamation in abeyance at the government's whim?

TALK.START.PARA: —Exactly, we haven't heard the arguments yet.

—We have not heard the arguments; we have not seen the terms of reference and I do not believe we should proceed until we can have that opportunity. Senator Harradine has said for months that it is an extremely important issue to him as to how he is going to vote on this bill. I think we should all have the benefit of that knowledge before we are asked to take this bill one step further.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Schacht, Sen Chris

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the motion moved by Senator Kernot on behalf of the Australian Democrats. We heard in the second reading debate today a suggestion from Senator Harradine that he would like his redeemable preference share option to be considered by a Senate committee. The Minister for Communications and the Arts (Senator Alston), in his summing up speech, outlined that that proposal had been accepted by the government and would be referred to a yet unnamed Senate committee which would report back in March next year and the bill, if carried by this parliament in the next week or so—or early next year—would not be proclaimed until the report of the Senate committee was tabled in the parliament.

SPEECH.PARA: That is an absolute joke. Does anyone believe, despite what the Senate committee may say, that this government will hold up the proclamation once they have got the bill through the parliament? Of course not. They say that to Senator Harradine who has laboured long and hard in trying to convince the opposition, the government and anybody else who will listen that his redeemable preference share option is the way to go to preserve Telstra in public ownership. The very least he should do is support the proposal by Senator Kernot that the bill not be proceeded with until the Senate report on all the aspects of redeemable preference shares comes back. That is the only way he is going to get any comfort at all on his own proposal.

If Senator Harradine does not have that, we know what this government will do. They will say, `Fine, here is the Senate report. It is a wonderful idea. Tut, tut; we will proclaim it tomorrow.' That will be the end of the redeemable preference share proposal. It is a complete con on the Australian people, on the Senate and on the parliament to say that there is any way this is going to be seriously considered. The letter the Treasurer (Mr Costello) sent to Senator Harradine two days ago was a classically presumptuous letter from Treasury dismissing the idea—in a way that the Treasurer is so arrogantly now used to—of a redeemable preference share and saying, `Bad luck.'

That letter had a number of errors, I remind Senator Harradine. Mr Costello, in his letter, said, `The redeemable preference share option was discussed in the Senate committee on Telstra earlier this year.' That is absolutely wrong. It was never discussed; it was not in the terms of reference and there was no discussion about it—and there were no recommendations made accordingly. But Mr Costello asserted that. We know that this is just a device to get the bill through the parliament and that the Senate hearing—whatever its recommendations—is going to have no bearing on the government's view. The proclamation will take place the day after the Senate committee reports. Do not let anyone on the other side—particularly the minister—say the minister is going to take any notice of the Senate committee. He will just say, `Tut, tut, bad luck, we have got the bill and it is going to be proclaimed,' and away we go with the process of selling one‐third of Telstra.

This is really an artificial device. What we see here today, as outlined by the minister, is coupled with the bribe of several hundred billion dollars to go into a fund. It is not said where it is going to come from other than that in one part of it $100 million apparently will come out of the Telstra sale. We have no indication of how they are going to fund the $300 million to Richard Court—as stated in a letter he wrote to the Prime Minister (Mr Howard). All the figures on how they are going to pay for this extra funding have not been determined or explained. It is absolutely extraordinary that we are asked to say that there is a meaningful process for a Senate committee to consider Senator Harradine's process—

TALK.START.PARA: —Why would you bother?

—Why would you bother being on the committee and going through it when you know that at the end of the day it is going to be dropped straight in the bin and, the day after, the bill will be proclaimed if it is passed through here in the next week. We say that for the sake of Senate integrity and the process of Senate committees we ought to accept Senator Kernot's motion and support the Senate committee system—which government senators when they were in opposition were so willing to defend absolutely. In my nine years in this place I have never heard of this tactic of referring something off, knowing full well it is going to have no influence over the government's final outcome.

—All along, members of the Senate have been saying there are options. If the government is very keen to fund programs for the environment there are options; if the government is keen to find options for revenue raising there are options. Here we are offered an option in relation to raising funds with Telstra, an option which will have a different impact from the impact of the ideological bent of the government which is suggesting there are no options. The very least the Senate needs to do is explore those options and the very least we need to do in support of the community's concerns is to say that we have fully explored those options before final decisions are made. I support the motion today and I believe the government should support it, too, in the spirit in which it has been put forward.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard

TALKER.NAME: Senator ALSTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Communications and the Arts)

TALK.START.PARA: —If one thing is crystal clear it is that the opposition—and by that term I include the Australian Democrats—cannot abide the result of 2 March. They simply cannot acknowledge it.
—You are admitting that the committee process is a sham.

—What I did find rather breathtaking was the statement by Senator Kernot that there has been no time to canvass other committee options. We are talking here about adjourning the entire committee stage process because Senator Kernot says she has not had time to canvass other committee options. I do not know the basis on which she said that Senator Harradine is not ready with an amendment, but that is again what she said. Effectively, what they are asking for is to simply stall this for as long as possible so that at some time in the future they can do their best to avoid the verdict.
—He has just admitted that the committee is a sham.

—It ought to be clear to Senator Schacht that it is quite possible to amend the bill in committee to ensure that the date of proclamation is fixed. It is not a matter of taking the government's word for it. In that period, there is an opportunity for the Senate committee to properly consider all the issues in a way that some might say—
—You just admitted that the committee is a sham.
—has not currently been available to date. Those arguments can be properly tested in the marketplace.
—You are going to bring the bill back from Yarralumla, are you?
—Until that report is received, it would not be possible to proceed to proclaim the bill.

SPEECH.PARA: That is a perfectly reasonable outcome. What you are wanting to do by a subterfuge—by a desperate attempt to avoid the verdict of the people—is to simply stall this for ever and a day. You are not interested in waiting another three months for the committee stage process. Do not pretend that for a moment.

If you could think of some way in which you could suspend the committee stage for another six months, you would do it. I am not surprised that Senator Schacht says he supports Senator Kernot, because they were sitting there earlier this morning working out this little scheme. It is simply a device—it is a subterfuge—to try to avoid the verdict of the people.
It ought to be clear that what the opposition parties are about is simply a transparent exercise in avoiding the day of judgment.

TALK.START.PARA: —What do you call a committee reference?

—There is no difficulty about proceeding to the committee stage. You have had every opportunity to canvass all of those committee stage options. I asked Senator Schacht the other day whether he had any committee amendments, and he said that he was still thinking about it.

SPEECH.PARA: I presume he has thought about it by now. I presume you have got them ready to go. I presume that Senator Kernot has got some ready to go, despite the fact that you have no intention of supporting the bill, irrespective of any amendments. I presume you will still want to move some. That is a stage we ought to move on to now. There is no need for any further delay, and we can deal with the matter in the way that the people expected it to be dealt with.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Senator Collins, you have been persistently interjecting during this debate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —What a sham this is. If Senator Harradine and Senator Colston fall for it, then they are much lesser politicians than I thought they were. The reality is that, as Senator Kernot, Senator Schacht and Senator Margetts have pointed out, the issue is whether we set up a committee to look into proposals put forward by Senator Harradine. The committee will, essentially, be a sham because the government, at the end of the time, will proclaim the bill anyway. It is a waste of time for the Senate, a waste of time for that committee and a complete charade.

SPEECH.PARA: The charade we have seen is difficult enough. Senator Harradine has not been able to state quite clearly, after all the period of deliberation, where he stands on this issue. We have before the Senate the proposal that he wants to fight for Tasmania's environment. That is why he has been holding out, besides the other considerations.

That is turning a complete blind eye to the fact that he has been a prime agent in the destruction of Tasmania's world heritage and rainforest through woodchipping. He has been a prime agent in favour of the destruction of the Franklin River when he could have stood up for that. He was a prime agent in the loss of Lake Pedder to the Hydro‐Electric Commission. It has been going on for a quarter of a century. Now he comes in here ostensibly as a defender of the environment. What a sham that is.
Government senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Let me say this to those people bleating opposite: the fact is that the cost to the environment of Senator Harradine's ethos is far greater than anything he will get out of this for Tasmania. He supported millions of dollars in subsidy that has gone into logging in Tasmania. That has been ripping off the Tasmanian people—taking it out of the pockets of the Tasmanian people—and it is far greater than a handout he will get from the government through this committee system.

SPEECH.PARA: He might sit there quietly and blanch, but the reality is that he has been a loser in economic employment in environmental terms for Tasmania. Now the government says, `Well, we'll put it to a committee'.

TALK.START.PARA: —You weren't even here when they did what they did to Lake Pedder.

—Yes, but he was active on it in his pre‐Senate days, I can tell you, Senator Collins. `We'll put it to a committee; trust us,' says the government to Senator Colston and Senator Harradine. They say, `Trust us.' My advice to the senators is that, if you fall for that, you will fall for anything.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bourne, Sen Vicki

TALK.START.PARA: —I will not take much of the Senate's time, but I do want to make the point that I believe that, if this motion does not go through and we do go to a Senate committee which then will have absolutely no bearing whatsoever, and cannot have any bearing whatsoever, on what happens with the possible sale of Telstra, then we are bringing the Senate committee system into disrepute. That is something that I think we should all consider extremely seriously.

SPEECH.PARA: When the government were in opposition they did consider it extremely seriously. I believe they should think now about the way they thought then about the Senate committee system. The Senate committee system is something that we should all value very highly. What will happen if we send Senator Harradine's idea of redeemable preference shares to a committee, and then there is no opportunity in the committee stage of this bill for the recommendations of that committee to even be considered—the recommendations were not considered, despite what Senator Alston says; they were not considered when the last committee went round and looked at this bill; this is a new idea which should be considered now—and we allow this bill to go through to the third reading to be proclaimed as soon as the Senate committee reports, no matter what it reports, we will be bringing the committee system into disrepute. Why would we even bother? We do get good recommendations out of committees. The committee system is something I value enormously, and I hope other senators do too.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine, Sen Brian

TALK.START.PARA: —I reluctantly voted for the Telstra (Dilution of Public Ownership) Bill at its second reading, and there will be a committee stage. Some comments have been made here which have been unworthy of those who have been making them. I make the point to Senator Brown that one day he should really give some consideration to what he says at times.
—You should think about what you have done.

—I am happy, at any time, to defend what I have done in this particular area. In some other areas I have made dreadful mistakes, but in this particular area you are suggesting my support for the destruction of the Franklin River. Quite the contrary; you did not know what was occurring at that time when I was in the Labor Party. You did not know—you were not about.

SPEECH.PARA: When Senator Brown talks about my slashing and burning the environment, my wife and I have a little chuckle. The fact of the matter is that we are lovers of the bush. We regularly go camping. In fact, last weekend I heard absolutely no news for the whole of the weekend, from Friday evening till Sunday night.

TALK.START.PARA: —You didn't miss a thing, Senator.
—No, I know I did not miss anything. We happened to be camping. We went out and pitched the tent. That is what we did. We love the bush.

SPEECH.PARA: This particular program that the government has in mind is not only in the area of world heritage. The questions were raised by me, in discussions about the world heritage, the paths and so on, because we love the world heritage area. We go down to the south‐west coast. How many people go there? But I will not get into that at all.
Honourable senator interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —I think the Minister for Communications and the Arts (Senator Alston) has said that the government has recognised that we have had to forgo a number of productive employment opportunities in Tasmania because a substantial amount of Tasmania is devoted to world heritage and various other things. This is what the government has been able to accept and recognise.

BREAK.PARA: Somebody suggested that this was a bribe. That, I believe, is unworthy. If you are faced with this situation, what do you do? My letter to the minister was open and public. There were no behind the door deals and so forth. It was perfectly open and public. It was on the table. He has given the assurances with regard to the technological advancements in communications in my state, including the islands in my state which have not been attended to as yet. So that has been given.
I justifiably raise that. It is a matter of principle. If a third of Telstra is going to be flogged off, certainly regional Australia and Tasmania should be looked after with regard to that.

TALK.START.PARA: —And the rest of Australia.

—Yes, the rest of Australia as well, but the rest of Australia will be looked after because it will be commercially attractive to look after it. I am sorry that my time is running out. I did not realise I had only a short time.

BREAK.PARA: The Labor Party has not been showing interest in the question of preference shares. The shadow Treasurer, the honourable member for Holt (Mr Gareth Evans), has not even been in touch with me about it. I suggest the committee would be very important and very influential, particularly if the redeemable preference share option is attractive and the business side of town sees it as attractive and gets behind it. Then the government would have the opportunity of changing its mind.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Harradine, you know it's not going to happen.
—I think it would be very important and instructive for the future to see whether a redeemable preference share track is appropriate for any other sale. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Faulkner, Sen John

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I must say that, interesting though I found Senator Harradine's case against the suspension of standing orders, particularly in relation to his bushwalking activity—and I must say I share that interest with him—I think on this occasion it did not go to mounting the strongest case I have ever heard in the Senate against a suspension of standing orders. The substantive issue that is being debated here by virtue of the motion that has been moved by Senator Kernot is simply this: can the Senate, can Australians, trust the word of this coalition government on this or any other matter?

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Harradine is taking the most extraordinary risk, given the position that he argued in his speech in the second reading debate just a few minutes ago. Senator Harradine, you have proposed that it is appropriate for the issue of redeemable preference shares to be examined by a Senate committee. The terms of reference of that committee, the nature of that committee, the composition of that committee and the time frame in which that committee will meet and report is still unknown to me and, I suspect, to the vast majority of senators in this chamber. If we had a situation where assent were not given to this bill after the bill had been read a third time, you would be taking on trust a government that has an unparalleled record of breaching its commitments, of breaking its promises.

It is an extraordinary leap of faith for you to suggest that we can have a Senate committee inquiring into an important issue that you yourself, Senator Harradine, have identified as the most crucial one in this debate—that of redeemable preference shares in relation to Telstra—and have that committee report to the Senate on this matter after the bill has passed through the final stages in this chamber.

I have to say—through you, Madam President—that you are, Senator Harradine, obviously as sophisticated about parliamentary processes as, if not more sophisticated than, anyone in this parliament, anyone in this chamber. What you are suggesting, what you are taking on trust, what you are taking on faith—the commitments that you accept from a government that has shown an unparalleled capacity to change its mind—is just extraordinary. It is an amazing leap of faith on your part, because once this bill has been read a third time then that is it. No choice, no options, no opportunity to come back in this chamber and look at the issues again.

BREAK.PARA: The only issue that remains of course is when it might be granted royal assent. I doubt, to be honest with you, that the Governor‐General, after the bill has been read a third time in the Senate, will be doing other than taking the advice of his ministers—in this case, Senator Alston—in relation to assent to this bill.

So, Senator Harradine, no options are left. You are arguing against yourself in the sort of process‐examination that you believe consistently this Senate should adopt on this matter. I say, Madam President, to Senator Harradine and other senators: do not be conned by this government whose record on keeping its promises and keeping its word has always been to break them. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALKER.NAME: Senator HILL
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Environment)

TALK.START.PARA: —This is indeed an odd occasion because the Australian Labor Party, the Australian Democrats and Senator Brown are seeking to redefine a proposition of Senator Harradine for their own purpose in their own terms. Their own purpose of course is to avoid facing up to the committee stage of this bill and, ultimately, to avoid facing up to a third reading vote. That is all they are interested in.
—And you have been stalling.

—This is a trick. As Senator Sherry just said, this is a stalling mechanism. You have been calling for this debate. You have been demanding this debate. Every day you have been saying,`Bring it on.' We have brought it on and now you say you want to put it off for another three months! Why? Because you are determined to defeat this bill in any way possible come what may.

SPEECH.PARA: I know I cannot say that you are lot of hypocrites. But I will remind you: what happened with the Commonwealth Bank? What happened with Qantas? The difference was that those opposite did not even have the guts to tell the Australian people what they were going to do. They had no ideological opposition to privatisation at all. They came in here and urged it. The only reason of course it got through was that we were prepared to agree. So there is no question of principle at the basis of their objection at all.

BREAK.PARA: They simply want to defeat this because they believe they can get some political opportunity out of it. And even that is extraordinary because if ever there was a vote in a federal election that should have convinced them that the people were almost united in wanting a change of direction in this country it was the vote on 2 March. We put this detail to the people. We set out what we would do with funds received from a sale of one third of Telstra. We said that we would be able to repay public debt, keep interest rates down and help small business to grow and employ.

We said that we would set up, for the first time in the history of this country, a Natural Heritage Trust to reinvest some capital in another form of capital and that is natural capital. You understand that in this country we have degraded a lot of our natural capital. We did not do it deliberately; we largely did it out of ignorance. But everyone now accepts that it will cost an enormous amount to put it right.

In fact the major concern I get expressed when I go out and talk to environmental groups is that the money is not enough. You see, they are crying out for a reinvestment of this money. They are crying out for us to address the environmental degradation that has occurred that governments in the past have not been able to adequately address because they have not had a capital base for it. And we found a way of doing it. That is what so irritates the Labor Party—that we found a way of putting in place that capital fund that would give a really substantial money base to reinvest in natural capital to start to do something about the rising water tables, the increasing salinisation and, as Mr Court said—and I heard you deriding him—the huge trouble in Western Australia. What are the Western Australian senators saying about it? Do they have any idea what it would cost to overcome the problem of rising water tables and salt in Western Australia? This is where the money can be usefully put. Let's get the vote and get the money flowing! (Time expired)

PARA.TAB: Question put:
That the motion (Senator Kernot's ) be agreed to.

PARA.EMPHASIS: * denotes teller

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

PROCTEXT.PARA: The bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Schacht, Sen Chris

TALK.START.PARA: —We now go into the committee stage. In view of the remarks made by both Senator Harradine and the minister in the second reading debate that now some agreement and some arrangements have been reached and also Senator Colston's remarks that in the committee stage he would like to see negotiations going on about an outcome to protect jobs, particularly in regional Queensland, my first question to the minister is: will those commitments require amendments to this bill or are they just airy fairy statements and, if they are amendments to this bill, when is the Senate going to see them?

SPEECH.PARA: Senator ALSTON (Victoria—Minister for Communications and the Arts) (12.09 p.m.) We are not going to move any amendments.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Schacht, Sen Chris

TALK.START.PARA: —If the government is not proposing to move any amendments, that is an astonishing suggestion. I have to say to Senator Harradine and to Senator Colston that there is no obvious chance here for the chamber to judge the agreement reached by the minister and the government.
—The trouble is, Senator Schacht, that is not what the committee stage is about.
—Oh, I see!
—The committee stage is about the bill. Don't you know that?

—Well, this is an astonishing suggestion now being made. The government has made the arrangements with Senator Harradine and Senator Colston. But Senator Colston said in his remarks that negotiations are continuing with the government about his concerns regarding rural employment. Then he made only an inference that his judgment could be affected if he wishes to vote; he still has an opportunity to vote in the third reading. But what we are saying here is that there is now a deal which the Senate chamber itself is not going to be apprised of.
—Senator Hill says this has nothing to do with the committee.

—It supposedly has nothing do with the Senate, and nothing do with the Parliament of Australia, but we now have a suggestion that there will be something written down. I would have to say to Senator Colston and Senator Harradine: I trust you are not trusting enough to accept all of this on the word of the minister or the government without somewhere testing it in a document and in an amendment added to this bill, or even an amendment to the committee stage, that outlines your concerns and writes down the commitment the government made. Otherwise it is absolutely worthless.

SPEECH.PARA: The real issue now is that, with the one‐third sale of Australia's biggest public asset, the Senate, the House of Representatives, the Australian Parliament, will not have any details written in about what is being done behind the scenes of the sale of Australia's biggest public asset. This is an astonishing new procedure. One would have thought that in the transparency of government and in the process this would actually be laid out. If it is not laid out as an amendment we might have got a suggestion that the minister would make a detailed statement that could be debated that lays out the detail of all these arrangements.

I took notes when Senator Harradine and Senator Colston were speaking and when the minister was replying, trying to work out exactly what the arrangements were that convinced the two Independent senators to vote for this second reading. In process this is a very slapdash way to treat the Senate. There might have been a press statement, a detailed statement put out to the public or tabled here so that we could examine it while this debate was before us in the committee stage. But that, apparently, is not on. The arrogance of the minister to say, `We have no amendments' but in his second reading speech to say, `We are going first of all to refer Senator Harradine's redeemable preference share proposal to a Senate committee'! He did not even tell us which Senate committee. He did not tell us whether it is a references committee or a legislation committee or one that covers communications, the economics committee or a select committee.

TALK.START.PARA: —He does not care.

—He does not. There is no detail from the minister. Senator Harradine may have some suggestions but with the terms of reference and the actual detail one would have thought that if a deal had been done or an arrangement had been made with Senator Harradine on this issue he would have tabled it in the parliament now so that we could see the detail of the committee. That is on the issue of reference to a committee. We had that debate in the motion from Senator Kernot to suspend standing orders until a contingent motion. The next area of detail, going on the minister's remarks, is very sketchy indeed. I cannot go on the remarks of Senator Harradine—
—If you sit down I will tell you.
—Senator Harradine, I want to put some of this on record.
—Okay, but can I answer for you the question about the committee? I would be happy to.

—Apart from the committee, Senator Harradine, there are other matters I want to ask the minister about. Minister, in your remarks, you said: `There is a $250 million infrastructure program to guarantee that regional and rural Australia will have access to the most up-to-date communications systems.' We want to know: is that going to be a special appropriation? Is it going to be paid for out of the $8 billion sale or the one-third of privatisation? Is it going to be a levy on the carriers? Is it going to be funded as part of the universal service obligation?

SPEECH.PARA: How is the money going to be spent? Is it going to be spent at the direction of Telstra or at your direction through the Department of Communications and the Arts? Will there be any way for communities to apply to get access to this money? Will it be left purely to a bureaucrat either in Telstra or your own department to decide, or is it going to be left for you to decide? Have we got any detail yet on whether it is going to be dealing with cable roll‐out, the upgrading of telephone exchanges or the provision of satellite services? There is no detail on that.

Again, we would have thought that that is not an unreasonable amount of detail to be put before us rather than have you saying, `Trust us. There are no amendments about it.' We would have thought that it is not unreasonable for the Australian people to know how the $250 million is going to be funded and put through. Is it a supplementary appropriation?

All of these things are unanswered. I am astonished that there is no indication, in any way, of how this is going to be done. I accept that maybe this has only been agreed with the Independent senators in the last few hours and that you have not got the detail prepared. However, that means even more that we should get more detail from you before we complete the committee stage.

There is then the matter of the Natural Heritage Trust. Its funding is now going to be increased by an extra $100 million from $1 billion. Again, is the extra $100 million coming from the one‐third sale of Telstra? Is the $100 million coming off what was going to go towards paying off debt, so that it is reduced by $100 million? Is that going to be in a separate bill? Is that going to be an amendment to the Natural Heritage Trust legislation?

We have the implied suggestion that you accept that Senator Harradine from Tasmania has a particular case. I think you refer to Mr Richard Court's case for the salinity problems in Western Australia. How are you going to fund it? Are we going to get separate supplementary legislation coming through here? How will it be allocated? Are you going to allocate it? Will the committee that is going to run the trust fund allocate it? How will you guarantee that Senator Harradine gets a proportionate increase of the extra $100 million? Is all the $100 million going to Tasmania? Will it be available for discussion and debate in any form?

Again, if you do not want to amend the bill, you should at least give us a chance to receive a detailed statement in response to all these questions so that they can be properly debated before the committee stage of this bill is completed.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why is that? Might it change your vote?

—It certainly will not change my vote about the principle of selling Telstra. However, in terms of good government and Senate process—you may not now be committed to this, but when you were in opposition you kept screaming about these things—I would have thought it was to your advantage to give us the detail. If we then find that some of these so‐called commitments are a bit `hairy fairy', we might well say to Senator Harradine or even Senator Colston, `Listen. We think you ought to put an amendment in this bill so that this money will turn up and be allocated in the way that you want to meet the commitment.'

SPEECH.PARA: What the opposition wants to do—you may well get away with it if Senator Colston and Senator Harradine are willing to go along with it—is to have some arrangement off the side with them but not here on the floor of the Senate. It is not unreasonable to expect the detail of this extra arrangement to be described here today in the minister's summing up. He should outline to the Senate how it will be handled. If the Senate has a majority view that this ought to be written into legislation to protect the arrangement that Senator Harradine was very keen to get, that is fine. However, let us at least have a debate about it.

It seems to me that the minister wants to get through the committee stage on a blink so that there is no chance for any senators, including the Independent senators, to move amendments to guarantee the arrangements they want. At the moment, a $250 million fund for telecommunications infrastructure in rural and regional Australia is no guarantee that Tasmania or anywhere else in Australia will get equal access to it. You have not given us any detail. I do not think it is unreasonable to say that you should write that into this bill, at least as a general amendment to describe the process. In that way, your concern about regional and rural Australia would actually be met.

There are details in the committee stage that ought to be discussed. The opposition will in principle absolutely vote against this bill, as we have in the second reading. We will vote against it in the third reading. We will call a division on it in the third reading. Our principal position is that we are against it.

Finally, the minister made remarks about a conversation I had with him a couple of days ago when he approached me in the chamber about whether I had any amendments. If private conversations are going to suddenly be dropped on to the floor of the Senate whereby what I said is reported, there will be no more private conversations. I do not mind the minister's getting up and giving his view about this or that. I put to him my proposition that the other bill on telecommunications deregulation should go to a Senate committee. However, I did not say what his response was; that was up to him to give.

I do not think it is very good process to suddenly say, `The shadow minister did not have any amendments. He said that he did not know.' At that stage, and up until the vote was taken, we were absolutely committed to doing only one thing, which was defeating this on the second reading. If we had indicated that we had a great list of amendments, you would have then jumped up and down and leaked it to the press that we were already conceding our loss on the second reading. If the minister wants to have a trusting and honest discussion across the chamber, which I am more than happy to have in order to facilitate the sensible working of the Senate, I will be in it. However, I will not be in it when, in order to make a political point, he gets up and gives his version of what I said. That means there is no trust, and he will never be able to have a private discussion with me again.

I have gone out of my way, on behalf of the opposition, to facilitate the post 1 July 1997 legislation being considered by this Senate in a timely way. If you want to have a mayhem process, you know as well as I do that when that bill comes in, in the committee stage we will hang you out to dry for weeks and weeks and weeks. I have not ever threatened that, but if you start breaking informal conversations where people are honestly trying to work out a better process, you're in for a terrible time. I just want to put that on the record.

TALK.START.PARA: —He will have an opportunity of recovering on the beach at Waikiki.

—I suppose one reason why this committee, the proposal of Senator Harradine, is not being treated sensibly is that the minister will be lying on the beach in Hawaii for a week in January. I think these are reasonable questions that we want answered before the committee stage is completed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine, Sen Brian

TALK.START.PARA: —May I go to the question that has been properly raised by Senator Schacht in respect of the committee. I do have to say that things have come together, to a certain extent, only within the last 24 to 48 hours. There was really no opportunity for me to prepare a proposal until I had the situation confirmed, and I believe it was important for the situation to be confirmed by the minister in the chamber. The situation is that the government is prepared to support an amendment of mine, which is yet to be drafted, to the date of commencement of the legislation and the date of proclamation. I will be preparing such an amendment. And I will be preparing an amendment in respect of the committee. You say you do not know what committee. I am open to suggestions, but in my view—
—But is that your amendment, not the government's?

—Yes, it is my amendment. In my view the appropriate committee would be the Economics Legislation Committee. That is normally the committee to which these things go. That is the sort of thing that I will be doing. People have been saying, `Well, it is going to be too late. The committee is not going to be worth while.'
—It will not affect the outcome of the bill if it is already passed.
—You do realise that the bill provides for the third sale by way of preference shares?
—Yes, but—

—So you do understand that. I do not believe many people, both in this chamber and in the press, realise that the legislation if adopted enables the govern ment to go down the preference share track. That is the fact of the matter. Of course then, the committee is very, very important with regard to that, particularly if we have a reporting date by the committee which is maybe some time before the proclamation date. For example, I have in mind—
—The government does not take any notice of the report then, Brian.

—But I am saying that I have in mind that the committee would report to the Senate by 30 March, and that the proclamation date be 1 May. This would enable public debate about the proposal that I have been putting forward. I am very serious about the proposal, as you have said. I do believe that everything needs to be out in the open. During the later part of the committee stage when I move the motion for the reference of the question of the desirability of redeeming preference shares to a committee, I will be tabling, or incorporating if I may, the letter of the Treasurer, my advised comments on the letter from the Treasurer, and a number of other matters, so that chamber is well aware of them and the committee when established can work off that.

SPEECH.PARA: With respect, Senator Kernot, I admit to what Senator Faulkner said in response: I did not really address the point of your urgency, but the whole point about it is that the bill does enable the part sale—

TALK.START.PARA: —No, they have no intention of paying any attention to you, because the Treasurer—

—No. Senator Kernot, the Treasurer has said something. Look, if I write to the government saying that the Treasurer is talking through the back of his neck, I do not think the government would take that from me, nor should they. To be fair to the Treasurer, he examined the matter. But he was working off a different set of assumptions than those that I am working off. You need some independent organisation—that is probably not necessarily an apt description for a Senate committee. But you do need an organisation such as a Senate committee to have a look at both views and the views, more particularly, from the business side of town. I think there are attractions for the business side of town in respect of the redeemable preference share proposal. I thought I would answer you on that. Of course, the minister will answer the other matters.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carr, Sen Kim

TALK.START.PARA: —The opposition is obviously very concerned about the developments that have taken place here today. We are particularly concerned that there should be a proposition put to us that we engage in debate on issues for which we do not see the detail. We cannot see the detail, because no detail has been produced. We have some woolly statements based on some very woolly commitments about issues of employment. There are also some issues concerning the environment.

SPEECH.PARA: We are told that some undertakings have been given to protect regional employment. Let me deal with that issue first. Was it not the government's case throughout this whole process to argue that the basis for privatisation was one of efficiency? Blow the social costs and blow the economic implications at a regional level, because what it was all about was efficiency.

Do you remember all those fantastic graphs about the number of lines per employee and that under privatisation we would be able to reach world's best practice? We could measure it against this mythical company in the United States and, according to this model, we could demonstrate that, if we privatised Telstra, we would see an improvement in efficiency but the consequences that would flow would be a loss of jobs and a loss of social infrastructure at a regional level. We were told that does not matter because there is an overriding criterion—that of efficiency.

But now we are told there are some arrangements to be put in place to look after this little patch of employees or that little patch of employees in such a manner as to ensure that the political interests of some Australians are to be protected, that the social interests of some Australians are to be protected and that the economic interests of some Australians are to be protected at the expense of other Australians. The fundamental discrimination that is involved in this measure should not be misunderstood for one moment.

BREAK.PARA: It is a fundamental hypocrisy for this government to argue, on the one hand, we should do this on the basis of efficiency and then, on the other hand, to secure a couple of votes say we will make sure some Australians are given privileges that other Australians do not enjoy.

We have seen a business plan put forward by Telstra which sees one-third of the company out the door on the basis of efficiency. Remember that argument? We said all along that it was in preparation for the privatisation process. We said all along that, on the basis of the Project Mercury documents—the documentary evidence we had—and the minutes of those meetings, there was no doubt whatsoever that what was going on inside Telstra was that the adherence to government policy by the management of Telstra was already having a distorting effect on the company.

We made it perfectly clear what our position was. This government said, `No, it has nothing to do with any of those political considerations. We're going to have a higher form of economic morality. We're going to base our decisions on efficiency. We're not going to be concerned about the social or the economic consequences of our decision. We're going to be concerned with one thing: the saving of $600 million off the bottom line by the throwing of one-third of the workers in Telstra out the door.'

PARA.BREAK: We hear today that there are going to be some special arrangements put in place so that the people of Roma, presumably, can keep their operator exchange services. I am very concerned about the people of Roma but I am also very concerned about the 60 other operator exchange services across this nation. I am very concerned not just for the people of Tasmania, not just for the people of Queensland—some people in Queensland and some people in Tasmania—but for the people of Victoria, of South Australia, of Western Australia, of New South Wales and, of course, the people in the territories. We have to consider their interests as well, I would have thought, if we were a national parliament—not a parliament put together on the basis of a holding together alliance; an alli ance of convenience to ensure some Australians are given protection at the expense of other Australians.

BREAK.PARA: In Victoria at the moment there are some 22,000 Telstra employees. Under the projects that are being initiated by Telstra management, the management initiated redundancy programs, Victorians are going to be hit the hardest. Why should they suffer at a greater rate than the workers in Tasmania or in Queensland? What is the moral justification for that attitude? Of course, there is no economic justification for it. What is the moral justification for it? There is none there either.

What is so fundamental about this government is that it is completely amoral. It is amoral in its approach to politics because it does not matter what it says; it does not matter what it says because it does not really mean what it says. It is the end objective that matters—the end justifies the means. As far as this minister is concerned, it does not matter what you do to get there.

The fundamental immorality of this government is being exposed here today. We think it is reasonable that, if these measures are to be adequately considered by the parliament, we at least see what they say in writing, because this government's word cannot be believed and should not be believed. There is no basis for anyone to believe what this government says. It is not worth a blob of glue. This government has no commitment to honesty and decency in public life because it is about getting the end result, which is, of course—we all understand on this side, in any event—the full privatisation of Telstra. There ought to be no illusions about what this is about.

We were told that, somehow or other, the 1,500 workers in Tasmania should be given additional protection. I agree they ought to be, but so should the 22,000 workers in Victoria, so should the 12,000 workers in Queensland, so should the 5,000 workers in South Australia and so should the 6,000 workers in Western Australia. What is to happen to them under this proposal?

PARA.BREAK: If we are talking about the removal of one-third of workers out of Telstra to justify the reshaped corporate entity to meet the require ments of CS First Boston Group in terms of any prospectus, what does this measure really mean for the workers in Western Australia? Does it mean that they have to carry a disproportionate burden? I think there is only one conclusion you could reach. This government is not talking about putting more people on the payroll; they are talking about removal of people from the payroll. Therefore, one must conclude that the workers in the Australian Capital Territory will have to pay more dearly as a result of this deal, that the workers in the Northern Territory will have to pay more dearly as a result of this deal and, of course, that the workers in Victoria will suffer very dearly indeed. This is what this is all about—fundamental discrimination and immorality.

BREAK.PARA: We get to the issue of the provisions for an environment fund. I would have thought it obscene to distribute money on the basis of political advantage measured by the numbers of votes that you can gather in this chamber. I would have thought it was fundamentally constitutionally improper to give special advantage to some citizens over others. Therefore, we suggest that if it is wrong to privatise the corporation, then it is doubly wrong to privatise the corporation on the basis of a political bribe to some parts of the country.

It seems to me that it is totally inappropriate for an immoral adventure like this not to be challenged at every possible opportunity, and that is what we intend to do. I think there ought to be a rational assessment of the way in which moneys are distributed in this parliament. There ought to be a clear and transparent method for the distribution of public funds. There ought to be political accountability. These are some of the fundamentals, I would have thought, of public administration. But we are seeing that thrown out the window by these measures. What this means is that you slip in the back door and arrange a special deal on the side. That is the principle we are enshrining here today. It seems to me that this is not the proper way for us to proceed.

I think there is a legitimate case for moneys to go to Tasmanian national parks, but there are legitimate reasons as well for moneys to go to national parks in Victoria, legitimate reasons for wilderness areas in Queensland to be protected and legitimate reasons for conservation measures to be undertaken in the Northern Territory. If salinity is important in Western Australia, why isn't it important in the Murray Valley in Victoria? Why are the homes, the towns and the regions of Victoria not just as important as the regions of Western Australia?
