For that matter, why is it that they should be treated as second‐class citizens by this government because of these arrangements they are entering into—arrangements we cannot see, where there is no transparency, no accountability and no way of judging what arrangements have been made other than with broad and woolly‐minded commitments that we have heard here today?

It strikes me as extraordinary that Senator Harradine, with all his experience, should not be able to put to us a position that says, `This bill, on the arrangements I have made, won't be put into law until we have some commitments about certain matters.' I would have thought it was fundamental to any political deal making. But what have we here? We have a proposition that says that if this bill is read a third time it will not pass into law unless the government agrees with the report from a committee—but it is unspecified. Do you expect us to accept that as a reasonable course of action?

It seems to me that we would have to be extraordinarily gullible to believe for a moment that this government is other than committed to the full privatisation of Telstra—or, for that matter, when it gets to the third reading on this particular stage of that privatisation process, should it achieve a third reading by this parliament, that it will not proceed with the sale in terms of the bill. To suggest otherwise I find quite extraordinary.

So I think we come back to this. We find that the fundamental principles remain the same. There is no justification for the privatisation of Telstra. There never has been justification for the privatisation of Telstra, other than at the rhetorical level. The empirical evidence simply does not support it. What have we got on top of that now? We have the justification based on special arrangements entered into for special regions in Australia. We have a basis of discrimination introduced as a means by which we legislate in this country.

Telstra is one of the greatest assets this country has ever produced. It is an asset that has taken 100 years to develop. It is an asset that is far too valuable to sell and it is being sold off on the basis of this tawdry arrangement. I find it an extraordinary proposition that the parliament could possibly agree to such a thing, that in this day and age a new morality is being entered into, a brave new world of Australian politics where you find the truth is not as it at first seems. This is our giant X Files here, isn't it? I think we can expect much more to come from this government, and we should not be under any illusion as to what the true nature of these arrangements is.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kernot, Sen Cheryl

TALKER.NAME: Senator KERNOT
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —It is one thing to lose a debate on the superiority or inferiority of ideas in a contest of ideas. One can always accept that. But it is another thing to lose a debate on parochial deals and trade‐offs which, in the view of many of us, disadvantage many other Australians. That is not the basis of good negotiation.

SPEECH.PARA: I guess one could argue that the Senate is the states' house. Perhaps Senator Harradine and Senator Colston could find some argument there. But the problem with that argument in the case of this Telstra bill is that the impact of this bill affects every Australian, no matter where they live. That is why it is absolutely wrong to single out Tasmanians or Queenslanders in Roma or anybody else.

In my view, what we are seeing—and we have not seen the detail—is equivalent to the worst form of American pork‐barrelling, vote buying, that Australians usually show a great deal of disdain for. We do not want this American style of parochial vote buying—trade‐off a little bit, forget about the common good. We do not want that in Australia.

On the matter of what is being traded, I know we were criticised for our industrial relations negotiations. But I can tell you this: you had on the table a very comprehensive document which had, word for word, what we agreed to. We started with a couple of things in common. We did not say, `Oh, and we want $100 million here', or `We want this done for workers there.' We did not say that. We did not trade off crass regional objectives; we tried to put the benefits of all Australian workers foremost in our minds. We tried to find a fair balance for all Australians. Not just because I live in Queensland did I say, `I am going to put the interests of Queensland workers first in all circumstances', because that bill—as does this bill—affects all Australians.

Yes, we are entitled to look at regional differences as they are important, but we do not look at them at the expense of the total impact. I think it is of great concern that we do not know what has been agreed to. Senator Harradine has only referred to a letter from the Treasurer (Mr Costello).

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 12.45, I shall report progress.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 7 November, on motion by Senator Campbell:
That this bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Faulkner, Sen John

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —There seems to be a recurring theme in this place, because here we are again debating another piece of anti‐family legislation from this government. The Child Care Legislation Amendment Bill (1996), with the child care regulations passed last week and the appropriation bills, signal the end of child care as we know it in this country.

SPEECH.PARA: These measures attack the very core of the child‐care system that was built up by Labor over the last 15 years. Taken together, the coalition's cuts to child care mean that Australian parents will have to find an extra $½ billion over the next four years to pay for child care. That is $½ billion from family budgets which are already tight and which will become much tighter after the Howard government's budget cuts really start to bite.

Australia's child‐care system was one of the best in the world. I do not stand up here and say that it was perfect, but our record speaks for itself in child care. Our child‐care system was built on the Labor Party's commitment and belief that child care should be treated with the same seriousness as education and aged care. With that level of commitment, we built a $1 billion child‐care program.

Fifteen years ago, when the crew opposite were last in office, there were just 47,000 child‐care places nationally. Opportunities for women to take up work or study were limited because there was not enough child care available, or because the little child care that was there was so expensive. But Labor delivered on its commitments over its 13 years in office. Thanks to Labor, more than 440,000 families now use Commonwealth funded child‐care services in any one week, both work related and occasional care. The coalition does not share that level of commitment, and this legislation stands as testimony to that lack of commitment.

On this side of the chamber, we believe that quality, affordable child care is the greatest support we can give families to help them balance their work and family responsibilities and support the parents at home who want occasional or pre‐school care for their children. One of the ways we delivered that was through operational subsidies for community based long day care, investing in public infrastructure to invest in our children—not through weasel words, such as those used by the coalition. This legislation abolishes the operational subsidy for community based long day care.

Let me quote from the Department of Health and Family Services portfolio budget statement to give the government's primary justification for the abolition of operational subsidies for community based long day care. It says that this abolition will `encourage services to become more efficient and cost competitive with the private sector'. But as our dissenting committee report on the Child Care Legislation Amendment Bill states, that is the level playing field argument of the economic rationalists, the argument put by the National Commission of Audit for the abolition of all operational subsidies for community based services, and the principle underpinning the work of the Economic Planning Advisory Commission's child‐care task force.

As I said in this chamber the other day, the bottom line is that children are not commodities to be traded for profit. The dismantling of our social infrastructure which will arise from this proposal is far too high a cost to pay for efficiency and cost competitiveness.

The submissions that the committee received on this legislation paint a very unhappy picture of community based long day care after the abolition of the operational subsidies. There is no doubt in our minds that fees for child care in these centres will be higher—in the order of $25 a week per child—as a result of this measure. And there is no doubt in our minds that the quality of care provided by these centres will be reduced as a result of this measure.

The submissions received by the committee reveal some of the cost cutting options that have been canvassed by centres as a result of the axing of the operational subsidy. They reveal a very concerning list of issues. They include: employing fewer staff or taking on more children so that staff‐child ratios are lower; employing younger, less experienced and less highly qualified staff; restricting staff training and development opportunities; and requiring staff and/or parents to take on responsibility for cleaning.

They also include: deferring the replacement or buying of equipment, such as toys, books and the like; no longer providing educational program enhancements, like music classes or excursions; no longer providing hot meals, instead asking parents to provide meals from home; no longer providing a nappy service, instead asking parents to provide disposable nappies; providing fewer places for babies; providing fewer places for children with special needs; amalgamating with other centres; and, of course, closing. I find it very hard to see how these sorts of results line up with the coalition's commitments to deliver to all families and provide choice for families.

BREAK.PARA: This legislation does not stop at axing operational subsidies. For those families that do not qualify for the family tax initiative—the coalition's smokescreen for all their other cuts to families—their child‐care cash rebate has been slashed by one‐third. The introduction of the child‐care cash rebate by Labor recognised child‐care costs as a work related expense. Child‐care costs can be a significant disincentive for women thinking about taking up employment. Like other tax concessions for work related expenses, the rebate was not means tested.

Now, despite a specific promise not to do so from this deceitful government, this legislation applies a means test to the child‐care cash rebate. Families stand to lose up to $9.60 per week if they have one child in care or up to $21.10 if they have two or more children in child care.

I would like to remind the Senate that this legislation affects only two of those measures that I have previously identified in the Senate that really rip the heart out of our child‐care system. Now 5,500 community based long day care places and employer sponsored centre based places will not be built because we have this family‐friendly government axing the funding for them. John Howard promised to support the creation of additional places to meet the current unmet demand for child care. Instead, we are a further 5,500 places behind Labor's goal of meeting demand by the year 2001. We have no evidence that the private sector will build these places.

Do not forget that the changes to child‐care assistance—which many know as fee relief—which went through this place just last week mean that all parents will have higher out‐of‐pocket expenses for child care. The government has already passed guidelines which freeze the maximum amount of child‐care assistance that a family can get at today's maximum amount until 1999. With inflation, child‐care fees will increase over the next three years. Fees are likely to rise over and above inflation, but the amount of help a family can get will be frozen.

The maximum amount of child‐care assistance has been frozen, but the minimum fee that parents have to pay for their child care is not frozen. The minimum fee will increase annually. Some $85 million over the next four years has been slashed from child‐care assistance by this government, increasing the cost of child care for some 330,000 Australian families.

The $30 child income disregard allowed under the child‐ care assistance income test has been abolished. All families with two or more children, at least one of whom is in child care, lose under this measure. It is a savings measure which is specifically targeted at families with two or more children. The savings come from paying less child‐care assistance to families with two or more children where at least one of those children is in child care. It is a measure that will take $77 million out of the pockets of families over the next four years.

The child‐care assistance income cut‐offs for families who have more than one child in child care have also been reduced. On the face of it, this is perhaps a measure that one could understand the government reluctantly adopting in a climate of fiscal restraint. But I want to make the point that it is not only higher income families that are going to be affected by this measure. The manner in which the cut‐offs are being reduced means that all families with incomes above the point at which child‐care assistance starts to be withdrawn will be affected by the measure. Any family with two or more children in child care and with an income over about $27,000 a year will get less child‐care assistance as a result of this budget measure. As I said last week, there is definitely a recurring theme in this government's approach. This is a measure which penalises families who have more than one child in child care and takes another $13 million out of their pockets.

As I keep saying, and will continue to say, John Howard's so‐called family budget, with its family tax initiative as its centrepiece, is slowly but surely unravelling. It is slowly but surely being exposed. John Howard wooed families in the election with his family tax initiative, but as you add up the numbers you can see that the small benefits of the family tax initiative will be given to families with the one hand but taken away with the other. There is no more marked example of this than on the issue of child care and in the case of families, particularly families that depend on child care. Any bonus in the family tax initiative for them is gone.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is gone.

—That is right. Families with kids in child care lose it as a result of the cruel cuts of this government to child‐care funding. Those cuts take out a very large part of the increases in the tax initiative for families. Really, what we have is a transfer from families who are using child care to families where one person is at home caring for children. We argue—and always have, in the Labor Party—that all types of families need support. Families should be supported by government in the choices they make about how they balance their work and their family commitments.

BREAK.PARA: Some families choose for one parent to care for kids at home, and we have always argued that they should be supported in that choice. But some families choose for both parents to work, and we also stand by those families and believe that they ought to be supported if they make that particular choice. We acted on those beliefs in building a child‐care system when we were in government—before the coalition, after the March election, started to take the broadsword to—

TALK.START.PARA: —Social engineering!

—Yes, social engineering, Senator Mackay. But what they have really done is to take the broadsword to Australia's child‐care system—which is, as I have said, if not the best in the world, then certainly one of the best in the world. What this mob is about is seeing it unravelled and destroyed. Of course, the opposition believes that families using child care should not have to pay the price for a coalition government which has an absolutely ideological obsession with balancing the budget.

BREAK.PARA: We hear a lot from Senator Newman on the odd occasion that she deigns to answer a question in question time. She has established a new record now for any minister in any government in question time. She refuses absolutely to answer any question when she represents a portfolio minister in this place, because she is incompetent. But now she also refuses even to answer any questions in her own portfolio area, because she is incompetent. Amongst a team of no‐hopers, she is the worst.

TALK.START.PARA: —At least she is here, though, today.

—She is here for this particular debate. That is indeed unusual. In a team of no‐hopers, she is the worst. It is a very close run thing for last place, but I think Senator Newman has managed to win. She does come in here on occasions to try to build up her confidence by getting her colleague to ask her a dorothy dix question about the number of women sitting on the government benches, but where are those Liberal women when it comes to defending the child‐care system in Australia? Where are they? They have never stood up to be counted on this issue.
—There's one there.

—I am pleased, Senator Panizza, that you point out that one senator, Senator Coonan, has come into the chamber. It is nice to see you here, Senator Coonan. I hope that you do the right thing and support the Labor Party's amendments in this bill, and that you, unlike all the other weak and vacillating coalition women senators, do support the Labor Party's attempt to keep a decent and strong child‐care system in this country. Stand up for women in the work force. Stand up for protecting Australian families, whatever choices they make about the way they look after their kids. If you do that, Senator Coonan, you will be very unlike all your other colleagues and, certainly, very unlike the minister at the table, Senator Newman. I commend the opposition's approach to this legislation and I ask senators to support us in defending the great child‐care system in Australia that Labor has worked to build up over 13 years in government. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lundy, Sen Kate

TALK.START.PARA: —I also rise to support Labor's approach to child care in Australia. I want to remind honourable senators of how we got to this point of actually debating such massive cuts to such a fundamental service to Australian families. We got to this point because the government has done its utmost to dress up unjustified cuts in its expenditure and has applied them, in seeking to find some savings, to the most inappropriate areas. One of the most inappropriate areas is the subsidisation of community based child care.

SPEECH.PARA: For so many families in Australia, child care is a prerequisite to their considerations in entering the work force. It is not just that there should be an option and a number of ways that they can obtain child care. For people to actually head out into the work force after having had children or contemplated having children in their lives, quality, affordable, accessible care is a prerequisite. If people cannot be confident that the government is at least contributing towards providing those choices and that care, what on earth are women and men going to base their life decisions on with regard to how they are going to structure their families and work that in with when they get their mortgage? And how are both going to afford to be able to work and have a family at the same time?

I can speak from experience on this, because I distinctly remember the day that I made the choice, when I was 22, that I wanted to do both. I wanted to have children and I wanted to have a career; and, because of Labor's policies, I was able to make a choice and know that, if I chose to keep working, I would be able to find for my child quality care close to home that was affordable, accessible and good, and that I could have confidence in that care. What this government is proposing to do is to take away that choice from women like me who make those choices in their early 20s or late teens or whenever. It is basically an anti‐family policy.

I am sick to death of hearing the government use the word `family', when every day I sit in this chamber and see piece of legislation after piece of legislation that Labor put in place going down. The government is making that legislation go down, and is amending and changing it under the guise of savings on expenditure, but what they are doing is breaking down the social support structures that Labor has systematically put in place over the past 13 years. It has been a system that, I have to say, before I came to this place I had started to take for granted. I had started to think that Australia did have a solid base from which families could work and within which families could operate and make their life choices.

I supposed that, given the coalition's rhetoric leading up to the last election, that system was the base from which we were working as a society. So it was with great devastation that I, along with most of the population, realised that a lot of what we had heard from this government in fact had no bearing on working from the base that Labor had established. What we heard had no meaning and no substance, and there was certainly no inclination on the part of this government actually to continue working from that base. We have seen a systematic erosion of the base that Labor put in place for families.

Child care remains a significant cost for most families. If you have more than one child in care, the cost usually outstrips your mortgage repayment. When we talk about child care, operational subsidies, child‐care assistance or the child‐care rebate, we are talking about major impacts on the family budget. It is not just a sideline couple of dollars per week, although the couple of dollars per week are important too. It is a major weekly expense for families. Certainly, with the first set of amendments that this government pushed through last week with respect to the changes to child‐care assistance, we have had a sniff of what is to come.

What we are talking about today, with this government attempting to abolish operational subsidies to community based day care, is the next step—and there are still a number of steps to go. As Senator Faulkner said, the result is half a billion dollars worth of money being ripped out of families' pockets—families for whom a significant cost in their weekly budget is, more than likely, child care. The operational subsidies themselves represent a proportion of that money that has been taken out of family pockets.

I turn now to the more specific applications of those operational subsidies. The operational subsidies apply to 1,112 centres around Australia, probably just under half of how many private centres are around. While there is a perception out there that these centres are somehow poorly run, inefficient and bloated through this government subsidy, that is an absolute farce. In fact, what it means is that the parents who have their children in those centres may have a slightly less fee‐paying arrangement but, in my pursuit of looking for adequate care for my children, the difference was $20 to $25 a week per child in the cost of care. The operational subsidies in the community based centres also operate on the basis of a parent and staff management committee. So what this government is subsidising is the role and the right of parents and staff to actually control the environment in which their children are cared for.

When we had the hearings the other day of the Community Affairs Legislation Committee in addressing this specific bill, the question was asked: had the department ever factored in the costs or the value of the contribution that the parents were making to the management and the running of these operational centres? Had they factored in the costs or the value of the contribution the staff were making to the management of their centres? No, of course not.

But I ask all honourable senators what value they put on the role of parents in having a say and putting in their own time to run and manage a community based child‐care centre. What is that worth—not only in a monetary sense about the time and effort—in terms of the quality and the peace of mind that that gives parents? The choices of having this option available to parents cannot be emphasised enough.

Whilst a proportion of community based child‐care centres attract this operational subsidy now—and there is a greater proportion of private centres—it means that parents who are seeking a balance in wanting to have a greater role in their child's care are perhaps not prepared to go into the more comprehensive, private centre care—comprehensive in the sense that the parents are more distant, although they do have consultative structures.

In taking away the operational subsidy, we are forcing these parent and staff run centres to compete against private centres. That is quite clearly stated as part of this government's intention in their aims and objectives in pursuing this particular bill. My colleague Senator Faulkner mentioned before what the government's justification is, and it is to encourage the services to become more efficient. Therefore, this government puts absolutely no value on the parents and staff playing a great role in the running of these centres. They are saying it does not matter. Once again, it is the economic bottom line that comes to the fore. As if it were not enough to say to parents, `We don't think you have got an appropriate role here,' in the next step as part of this package the government said that it would find $8.3 million to put together a financial assistance package for these community based centres that were reliant on operational subsidy.

I think that is a bit of an insult to all those parents and staff who have been managing these centres very effectively for quite a long period of time. Not only was money offered for them to get through the transition period, but it was offered in such a way that they could not utilise that money themselves to smooth the transition, if this bill goes through. They had to purchase financial advice from a tender process that the government is initiating.

I want to turn to some of the guidelines that were issued as part of that advisers' brief for the provision of financial and/or management advice to community based long day care centres. Basically, this brief provides for a service up to the value of about $3,000 and instructs the community based child‐care centres receiving operational subsidy to address the following matters. Advisers will not get approval through this tender process unless they do, because it says in the brief, `specific areas to be addressed by all advisers'. It is a very telling list, because it says a lot about what this government wants to do to these child‐care centres that are parent and staff run and are structured to suit the children of those parents.

First of all, there is child to staff ratio management. From experience, trying to find a day care place for a baby is a lot harder than trying to find a day care place for a toddler, and that is because there is a greater ratio. So when I see that the child‐staff ratio management needs to be addressed specifically as part of this financial advice, I become very concerned. I know that you could achieve greater efficiencies if you reduce your number of places for babies. I know that you can probably make your books look a bit better and have a lot more kids in your child‐care centre if they are all a bit older and the ratios are a bit less. But what does that say about the availability of places for babies where there is a demand? What does that say about a community based child‐care centre that has established itself and tries to maintain a fair and reasonable ratio amongst children of all ages, and balances out and cross‐subsidises the fact that they have so many toddlers, so many older children and so many babies? It is a very fine financial line for these centres to walk. This financial advisers' brief is going to send someone in there to try to sort that out for them.

Staffing and salary is also listed. There is a very genuine and a very important campaign being conducted by the union at the moment in pursuit of fair and reasonable wages for carers. Fair and reasonable wages for carers, to me, is something that is so important in ensuring that the people who are looking after our children are qualified. It has got everything to do with me as a parent, and all the parents out there, being confident about the nature of the care their child will be receiving.It is not good enough to list staffing and salary as a means of trying to find efficiencies. Budgeting, fee setting and monitoring are listed. That is basically telling these people who have been managing these centres for years how to do their business. Debt management, utilisation, records management and waiting list management are listed. Here is a good one: No. 8 on the list is fundraising opportunities. I would like to spend a couple of minutes telling you about a local community based day care centre that does receive operational funding and what their fundraising opportunities are.

There are 28 children in this particular centre, which is Wattle Child Care Centre here in Canberra. They fundraise like mad to get the facilities they need. This year alone, they have managed to raise enough money to get a terrific airconditioning system put in their centre. They have been going for about four years now. They have got 28 families and most of those parents are involved in the management and running of that centre. It is a centre where everybody knows each other and everyone has a say, as parents, about what goes on there. They all contribute; they all do little things. They raised about $2,200 for this centre over the last 12 months, because they had nowhere to turn for any grants or support for this type of funding. Yet we see here, at No. 8 in the advisers' brief for the provision of financial and management advice to these centres, `fundraising opportunities'.

Does this government think that these centres do not take every fundraising opportunity that arises? Does this government think that they do not currently need to? The operational subsidy does not mean that what we are looking at is a bunch of centres that are sitting on great government subsidies. Things are still tight, even with the subsidy. The advisers brief says that fundraising opportunities need to be explored, and it talks about income generation planning, children's books and fetes. It even suggests that maybe they could run a fete.

Let me tell the government something. Most of these community based child‐care centres already do all of this. For the government to list them in this way is so condescending and such an insult to every parent who has made a contribution, whether it be through their time or their money. It is just not fair, and it is a slap in the face for those parents.

Let us have a look at No. 9, special services. It talks about a nappy service, food provision, the use of levies or fees for special services, the use of contact staff for specialised activities such as dance. Thank you very much! Special services are what contribute to making a child‐care service a quality service. They are part of the choice that parents make when they send their child to a specific centre. To say that special services need to be sold out or traded off as a way to cut costs is compromising directly the quality of care that parents choose, and that is unacceptable.

There are other issues that this report mentions, but I will not go on. I think honourable senators get the general view that this document is condescending and insulting in the extreme. It implies that community centres that receive the operational subsidy are totally inefficient and that there is no thought given as to how they are going to raise money themselves or improve the quality of services. This goes back to the perception of these centres as subsidised institutions. That is a false perception, but it is a perception that this government, through its statements, has sought to perpetuate. I have to say that they are only being consistent with every other publicly funded community service around.

There is a line of thought in the words that come out of this government consistently, which is that anything that receives public subsidy or public funding is in some way tainted or not as efficient as the pure private sector. That is where you come back to ideology. That is where you can see that we are not talking about community based day‐care centres being efficient. That justification has been exposed as false. What we are dealing with is a government that does not like paying any government money towards a community based service. My final point is this: what will it take for this government to realise that it cannot continue to con the public and con families that its policies suit them? The family tax initiative that the government has talked up so consistently will be wiped out singularly for so many families with the changes to child care. To say that this government is a government that cares about families just displays the massive chasm between what this government says and what this government does.

As I said earlier, day after day we sit in this chamber, as the Labor opposition, and see the structures that Labor fought hard to put in place that help families and that service specific needs being demolished one by one. They are not being replaced by anything. They are just being torn down. As a result, Australia will lose by it.

BREAK.PARA: From a woman's perspective and a parent's perspective, this government is saying all the wrong things. It is sending all the wrong messages. There are families out there now who are probably reconsidering their role in the work force. The fact is that those centres' fees will probably go up as a direct result of this decision. If they try to hang onto their current level of services they will put their fees up. If you have got more than one child, maybe all you are working for is $40 or $50 a week because you have your children in care. And I know plenty of women who do it. On their incomes they may be pulling $30, $40, $50, $60 a week after they pay their child‐care costs. Maybe, for so many of those women and men, this is the last straw. (Time expired).

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coonan, Sen Helen

TALK.START.PARA: —There can be no doubt that the availability of quality child care at an affordable price is one of the cornerstones that allows parents to participate in the work force and to undertake a range of other activities in the community interest. It is of fundamental importance, I think we all agree, that Australian families have access to child care. But that access must be equitable and fair, not only for those families needing child care but for the community that bears the cost.

SPEECH.PARA: That being said, there appear to be some fundamental misunderstandings about the changes proposed in the Child Care Legislation Amendment Bill and the claimed effect of those changes, especially the removal of the operational subsidy to community based long day care centres from 1 July 1997, which is the aspect that I want to deal with in the few minutes available to me.

Let's get a bit of reality into this and look at a few facts established by evidence before the Senate Community Affairs Legislation Committee's inquiry into this bill. When I say a bit of reality and a few facts, I am referring to facts as opposed to rhetoric and anecdote. There is nothing fair and equitable about 30 per cent of parents, or 70,000 families, using community based centres, getting a subsidy of nearly $40 million each year while the rest, 70 per cent or 220,000 families, currently using private, employer or non‐profit child‐ care centres, are getting no benefit from this subsidy.

If you look a little more closely at the statistics, the way the subsidy currently operates is starkly unfair. The private sector provides services to a greater proportion of low income families than the community sector, with 96,000 families in the private sector on maximum child‐care assistance, compared with only 27,000 families in the community sector. The private sector provides double the number of places for children of sole parents compared with the community sector. The private sector provides 31,000 places for children with special needs compared with 16,300 in the community sector. The private sector provides 20,500 places in rural and remote areas as opposed to 9,100 in the community sector. The private sector also cares for a disproportionately larger number of children under two and babies than does the community sector—14,000 in community centres as opposed to 26,000 in the private sector. Figures indicate that some 18,000 higher income families, not otherwise qualifying for child‐care assistance, are using subsidised community centres.

The argument that fees in community centres will rise beyond the reach of parents cannot be sustained. Firstly, the private centres manage to provide by far the magnitude of child‐care services and places for relatively the same weekly amount as paid by parents using the subsidised centres. The government has designated $8.3 million over the next two years to help centres seek professional assistance in planning for removal of their subsidies—a grant of up to $3,000 for each centre. If the private centres can do it, and do it for a much larger number of children than do the community centres, then the community centres, certainly with assistance, should be able to do it. The decision will, of course, be up to the management, with the parents and management of each of the centres seeing how they are going to adapt and what efficiencies they can make.

The government recognises the need for access to diverse forms of care and in fact it has retained the operational subsidies for family day care schemes, occasional and out of school hours care. The subsidy also remains in place for multifunctional children's services and multifunctional Aboriginal children's services. Children with special needs are specifically assisted in the continuation of the supplementary services program and the introduction of a special needs subsidy scheme. The government will provide supplementary funding to ensure that families in such areas do not lose their access to existing child‐care services. In providing these funds the government will give priority to areas where private long day care centres are not available.

Australia has a unique quality improvement and accreditation system for its child‐care centres. The National Childcare Accreditation Council, through its mandatory peer review system for all centres, both private and community, ensures that good standards are reached and maintained in the child‐care industry. No longer is it only the community day care centres that meet the requirements for quality. The argument that community centres provide better quality care than the private centres now rings somewhat hollow.

The existing system of child care in Australia has accomplished a great deal. I think we all need to acknowledge that. By the same token, we need to realise that we have to move on. We have to realise that there are divergent views on the best ways of providing services. What is beyond argument, however, is the need to set policy which meets an acknowledged need in a fair and equitable way. Putting community centres on an equal footing with private centres is a justifiable step. It is in the interests of efficiency, it is in the interests of equity and it is in the interests of at least simplifying the maze of options for child care that are currently available. I commend the bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —Like several of my colleagues I rise to speak in opposition to the Child Care Legislation Amendment Bill 1996. I would like to note at this stage that we are dealing with this bill during a period in which we would normally deal with non‐controversial legislation, and highlight the controversy that is actually an element of this bill.

BREAK.PARA: As Senator Faulkner has pointed out, this bill will legislate the budget decision to abandon the operational subsidy to community based long day care centres from 1 July 1997 and will also apply a means test to the child‐care cash rebate from 1 April 1997. To reflect on those two points shows that this bill enacts yet another two broken election promises.

We have already dealt in the last couple of weeks with the broken promises with respect to the cuts to child‐care assistance but I ask those opposite when they as individuals changed their minds with regard to the policy statements of the coalition, such as:
. . . the Coalition has long supported the recognition of the costs of child care associated with employment.
Another such statement was:
A Coalition government will maintain the non means tested Child Care Cash rebate.
Have members opposite changed their minds, or did they deliberately mislead the Australian people before the election?
I wonder whether any member opposite can name the former shadow minister for employment, training and family services who wrote thus to the Early Childhood Association:
The policy—
that is, the coalition policy—

also states our continuing support for the community‐based long day care sector, and we regard the operational subsidy as one of the key supports of that sector. The Coalition has no plans whatever to change the operational subsidy.

I will give you a clue. The previous shadow minister, from the other place, has a brother in this place. That is Mr Kemp. But the real question in relation to that reference is: when did he write this nonsense? We can say that it is outright nonsense at this stage, and it was three days before the election—three days before this coalition government faced the public that they now need to face in the light of their obvious plans to do otherwise.

It is the removal of the operational subsidy for community based long day care centres on which I wish to focus my attention today. A brief look at the report on this legislation, prepared by the Senate Community Affairs Legislation Committee, shows clearly the shameful lack of regard the coalition has for Australian workers and their families.

Senator Coonan has just said that you cannot say that private centres do not provide the same quality as community based centres. I actually agree with her, if you are looking at centres on a one‐to‐one basis. But a system which includes operational subsidies to community based child‐care centres, and a system that allows the skew to ensure that quality occurs in some sectors, ensures that that quality is maintained across the child‐care sector.

Let me go back to the report. According to the figures presented in appendix 3 of the report headed `Operational subsidy—some key statistics', 27.1 per cent of the total number of all child‐care places are in community based child-care centres and receive the benefit of the operational subsidy. The government argues that the removal of the operational subsidy will place community based long day care centres and private long day care centres on an equal footing. But this view ignores the differences between community and private sectors and simplistically follows the market view that considers parents and children as buyers and child care as a commodity to be purchased, and that has not been the view to date.

Community based long day care centres are run on a not-for‐profit basis. Unlike privately operated centres, they are run by local government, community organisations or churches. They usually have a management committee made up of parents. Indeed, this is one of the most valued aspects of community based care, as parents welcome the opportunity to participate in decisions made regarding the care of their children. It is one of the reasons why parents choose community based care for their children. Community based long day care provides for proportionally more of the expensive services—that is, care of children under two and care of disabled children.

Referring again to appendix 3 of the Senate Community Affairs Legislation Committee report, it can be seen that in the community based sector over 30 per cent of places are filled by nought to two‐year olds. In the private sector only 21 per cent of places are provided for babies under two years of age. Almost 36 per cent of community based places are filled by children with additional needs. This falls to as little as 25 per cent in the private sector.

The community based sector provides a higher proportion of its places in rural and remote areas than does the private sector, and this is one of the major areas that will be affected. The main body of the legislation committee's report states:

The private sector also provides double the number of places for children of sole parents compared with the community sector. DHFS noted that for children of sole parents who are working, the private sector provides 20 500 places (10 900 in the community sector);

Proportionally, this equates to 16.7 per cent of places in the private sector going to sole parent families, while in the community sector the proportion jumps to nearly 24 per cent. The report uses the raw figures to conclude that:

It is apparent from these figures that there is an artificial inequity in the quality and cost of services between private and community child care services. Accordingly, the Committee is therefore of the opinion that the current subsidy arrangements have an extremely limited, if any, discernible impact on the reasons for families choosing child care facilities.

The reality in the figures presented in the report, if not in the conclusions that government members drew from them, is that, proportionally, community based long day care centres cater for more babies, more children with additional needs, more children living in rural and remote areas and more children of sole parent working families.

This is a testament to the valued place that community based long day care centres have in the Australian community today. They are giving nearly 30 per cent of working families a real choice about the care arrangements for their children. It is this sector that should be supported, not abandoned by the government with the removal of the operational subsidies.

My own child is in a long day care private centre. I already pay an additional fee, because I choose only to use that centre on a part‐time basis. It probably meets some of the additional administrative costs associated with just using the centre one, two or three days a week rather than five. But I wonder whether, because of the age of my baby and because the competition which currently exists in relation to community based centres who receive operational subsidies, that competition's removal may now mean that I will be expected to pay more, because my baby is under two years of age. Will that perhaps occur in private long day care centres?

I will not dispute that the quality between the centre that my son attends and the community based centre in the local area may well not be very different, but with a change to the overall system—a change which will remove the skew ensuring quality—may well change that, because it will change the competition.

In closing I would like to make a comment on the issue of quality care. We hear much of the term `world best practice'. It is often applied to productivity and work practices and much importance is placed upon achieving a leading edge in world best practice. Perhaps the most dire consequence of this legislation is that the leading sector for quality care—for world best practice in child‐care services—is to have taken from it the resources necessary to develop that very leadership in quality services for the care of young children. Those resources will be removed.

The issue of quality has been glossed over by the coalition with reassurances of accreditation under the quality improvement and accreditation system—a system I might add that has received very little support from members opposite in the past, in fact active opposition in many cases. I will forgive Senator Coonan for her comments on this issue, because she was not a member of the opposition in the last term, but it is very difficult to forgive the minister, the minister representing the minister and others present when this coalition was in opposition and attacked the accreditation system.

In raising the issue of quality care, as I said I am not slighting the private child‐care sector. I am aware that the vast majority of private centres provide quality care. Indeed, because of Labor initiatives 85 per cent of private child‐care centres are accredited. The issue I raise is really one of leadership in the ongoing development of care benchmarks and this will be jeopardised by the removal of the operational subsidy to community based long day care centres, because the leadership will be the marketplace. The leadership will not be quality; it will be the marketplace. This bill should be rejected. It breaks further election commitments. It removes a genuine choice from working parents and it jeopardises the ongoing development of improvements in quality child care.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mackay, Sen Sue

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise on the same matter as senators before me. Through the changes to child care this government is challenging a fundamental right, and that is the basic right to participate fully in the life of this country. As Senator Jacinta Collins has indicated, the Labor government put considerable time and effort into the establishment and development of quality affordable child care around Australia. Seventy per cent of child‐care facilities in Australia are run by the private sector. It has been mentioned before.

SPEECH.PARA: The Labor government recognised that there were some areas which for a variety of reasons were not attractive to the private sector and therefore were clearly without access to child care. To address this inequity, which denied thousands of Australian families access to quality child care for their children, the Labor party supported the development of community based child‐care centres. These centres grew up in areas of need, for example in rural, remote and disadvantaged areas. The centres grew out of the efforts of community groups, the very people who actually used these centres.

They were never intended to make a profit; in fact, they were directed to run on a break‐even basis. This is to ensure that any monies made were put back into the centre to maintain and further improve the quality of the service that they provide. In recognition of the financial difficulties faced by centres in rural, remote and disadvantaged areas—areas the private sector is not interested in because there is no profit to be made and again I am not slighting the service provided by the private sector because it is excellent—the Labor government gave each of the community based centres an operational grant subsidy. This subsidy is vital to each and every community based centre, but nowhere more so than in my home state of Tasmania where not the national rate of 30 per cent but a whopping 70 per cent of child‐care facilities are community based.

What is this bill going to do? This bill will discontinue the operational subsidy to the community based long day care centres from 1 July 1997. Effectively, this government is wiping its hands of child care, and it is saying, `Let the market forces rule; let the market forces provide child care. Let the private sector run child care and, if a few areas go without child‐care facilities and services, so what.'

For some reason, this government just cannot see that it has a fundamental responsibility to ensure access to quality child care in the same way that it has a responsibility to provide quality schools and quality health care to all Australians, no matter where they live—something which recent initiatives would indicate the government has virtually no commitment to.

I think this government has quickly forgotten the pledge it made to govern for all Australians. It has certainly broken its pledge to look after particular concerns of regional Australia. It was regional Australia, incidentally, where the government got sufficient votes to become the government. Nowhere is that more clearly demonstrated than in this government's treatment of Tasmania.

TALK.START.PARA: —You've got to be joking!

—Obviously, you think it is funny but Tasmanians don't. Every decision that this government has made to cause pain in regional Australia impacts the hardest on Tasmania. Minister Judi Moylan continually states that 70 per cent of child care in Australia is provided by the private sector. That may be the case within the country as a whole but the complete reverse is true in Tasmania. In Tasmania, only 30 per cent of child care is provided by the private sector; 70 per cent is provided by community based child‐care services, every one of which is reliant on the operational grants subsidy to survive.
—They're very strong on family day care—or had you not noticed?
—Very strong on family day care—do you care about the child‐care centres in Tasmania?
—Of course I do.

—I am very pleased to hear that. We will see what your bill does to them. I repeat that figure: 70 per cent. Why is this the case? Simply put, as Tasmanian senators opposite know, we are rural and we are remote. Look at our unemployment levels, our median wage level, our productivity levels, and there can be no doubt that we are disadvantaged.

SPEECH.PARA: There is not the profit to be made to attract private enterprise in sufficient numbers to provide the number of child‐care places we need and in the locations where we need them. Currently, there are 60 long day care centres in the state caring for 1,789 children. Forty‐one of these are community based long day care centres, all of which receive the operational grants subsidy to allow them to survive. They offer high quality and affordable care.

The centres are sponsored mainly by parent groups, and some are sponsored by local councils, of course. The parents themselves are involved in planning, evaluation and the actual running of the centres. Nineteen services are listed as private but, of these, two are actually community based and do not receive funds. They are the Exeter and Grammar School centres. Two other centres are workplace based. They are St Johns and Hobart TAFE. These four centres account for 180 places. So 1,789 plus 180 equals 1,969 places compared to 508 private places.

Can the private sector pick up the places lost if community based centres close? Should they pick them up? The answer is no, they can't and they won't. And why should they go into areas where profit is not available to them? The following quote is from a letter sent to me from the Exeter Child Care Centre. As I said before, this centre does not receive the operational grants subsidy so, to all intents and purposes, it operates as a private centre. The letter highlights the problems faced by centres not receiving financial assistance, a situation which will become the rule, not the exception, obviously. The letter reads:
Our centre has struggled to survive. In order to make ends meet it is necessary to employ a majority of part‐time and casual staff to give maximum flexibility.
We monitor and change our staff roster on a daily, even hourly, basis.
During periods of low attendance, due to illness or fluctuations in work rosters, staff cannot be guaranteed work and may not be given any work for periods of time.
This is very unsatisfactory for staff and children and makes it difficult to maintain continuity of care.
Multi‐skilled staff are a requirement of the centre. Staff are required to be extremely flexible to work practices and hours.
Staff job descriptions include tasks such as cleaning, meal preparation, gardening and minor maintenance.
We have relied heavily on donations from the community as far as equipment and toys are concerned. Voluntary work by parents and staff is also relied upon, particularly for maintenance.
The centre is operated on a week to week basis, with continuous monitoring of our bank balance, fees outstanding and running costs.

Staff are very restricted as far as purchasing new equipment and supplies. We rely heavily on recycled materials and borrowing resources from various venues. Staff collect materials in their own time and at their own expense.

The building we currently use is rented to us at a very minimal rental. However we have reached the stage where it no longer adequately meets our needs and is also in need of much maintenance and improvement.
The centre has not the finances to consider the funds required.

The reason I read that out is that this letter demonstrates the difficulties facing centres in areas where there is no privately run centre and they do not receive an operating grant subsidy. This bill will take the subsidy from centres, and they simply cannot function without it. Centres need a minimum of 50 children to be viable. We have several centres with fewer than 30 children in Tasmania. They are: Huonville, Brighton, Clarendon Vale, Ravenswood and Georgetown.

Brighton Children's Services are sponsored by the Brighton Council. They have been told to casualise their staff or close by Christmas. Clarendon Vale has made the hard decision to close this week. All of these centres have already been through a complete restructuring to enable them to be as efficient as possible. They have already been through the restructure. All of these centres face closure immediately on loss of subsidy. Half of the existing community based centres will close over the next two years.

What does the government imagine are their options if operational subsidies are removed? Is this government suggesting that they drop their standard of care? Are some Australians—poor Australians—entitled only to cheap and badly run child care or, more likely, no child care? Is that what this government is suggesting? Is the government suggesting that centres absorb the loss of the operational grants subsidy by substantially increasing their fees, therefore cutting out families who cannot afford the increase—the battlers that this government has gone on about? The battlers will not thank the government for this one. Is the government deliberately ensuring that they just give up and close? Is that the idea?

A centre on the north‐west coast of Tasmania has this to say about the impact of the loss of operational subsidy. Honourable senators do not have to believe me, these are the letters that I have been getting from Tasmanian child‐care centres. They say:
Circular Head Child Care Centre Inc. is a community based service situated in the far north‐west coast of Tasmania with fees currently at one hundred and fifty dollars a week.
Our community is classified as rural, isolated and disadvantaged.

There is no private service for child care within the proximity of three hundred and thirty‐six kilometres. Our closest neighbouring centre, which is also community based is at Wynyard, one hundred and sixty kilometres away.
The loss of operational subsidy to our centre means an increase in fees to one hundred and eighty dollars a week.
That is what the child‐care centre at Circular Head is saying, not me. They continue:

Parents of special needs children will not have respite due to staffing cut backs. There is no other service within two hundred kilometres available to them. Qualified staff will no longer be affordable.
They are saying this, not me. They then say:
Women will be forced to return from the workplace to their homes, due to the high cost of child care.

That is what the centre is saying. What is the government saying in response to statements like this? They are saying, `Restructure.' That is the great panacea—restructure. Where is the government getting its advice from except, of course, the National Commission of Audit in relation to this? As far as I am concerned, members of this government must walk around with their eyes shut and their fingers in their ears because there is a not a community based centre in Tasmania that has not already gone through a comprehensive restructuring, and there are no reasonable changes left to make.
I turn to another local child‐care centre, Ulverstone Child Care Centre. In a letter to me they say:

We have always been extremely budget conscious bearing in mind that our operational costs determine the fee that our parents will have to pay. In recent years in particular we have restructured our staffing—eighty per cent of our budget—in a flexible, workable manner.
These are actual, real child‐care centres and that is what they are saying. I have another quote, from Wynyard Child Care Centre:

As with all long day centres, we have always had to submit a break‐even budget to the Commonwealth. We were unable to carry over money in reserve. Now with a time frame of less than eight months, we are supposed to completely restructure our financial management practices to cope with huge cuts to funding.
That is an impossible ask. They go on:
If our centre closes there is no alternative for the ninety‐seven families who use our service. Private centres are not likely to open up in our small town.
Correct. That is right. Even if centres are able to remain open, many aspects of the operation of the centres will be adversely affected by loss of operational subsidy.

Places for babies will go, for example. Of the 14 private child‐care centres in the south of the state, only four centres offer care for babies under 12 months of age. That is obviously due to the very high cost of caring for babies in Tasmania. We have excellent child‐staff ratios for children under 12 months of age, one staff member to three babies—that is excellent. The community based sector fills this gap and provides quality child care for children from birth. Places for children with health, behavioural and developmental problems will no longer be available. Staff morale will be affected. Staff continuity and stability will be clearly compromised. Consistency within programs will disappear and families will lose valuable support. Tasmania has the highest unemployment rate in the country, we have the lowest population growth, we have the lowest productivity growth and we have an ineffectual state government—not exactly the circumstances to inspire investor confidence, not just in relation to child care but in terms of all areas. Private centres cannot and will not be able to take over from community based centres.
In the time remaining to me, I turn to Devonport Child Care Centres Inc. In their correspondence they say:

The reason this state has not attracted privately owned centres is found in our high unemployment, our high staff child ratio which is a state licensing requirement, our lack of economic growth, a poor or nil return for the existing private operators and low population growth in this state.
Our unemployment is ten point seven percent compared to eight point eight per cent nationally.
Staff child ratios are twice as high as Victoria. This is required because of the large number of part‐time children in care. For example our centre is licensed for 42 children at one time . . .
They say also:
. . . we have one hundred and fifty enrolled for the week.
Our state has delivered the worst four year result for economic growth relative to the rest of Australia for decades.

TALK.START.PARA: —Oh!
—That is true. I tell you, it is worse than South Australia.
—Dr Gloom!
—Dr Gloom? I will tell Senator Abetz that it is no accident that we have had a state Liberal government and now we have got a federal Liberal government and this is happening.
—It's no accident; the people want it.
—Senator Abetz should look at the federal election results from Tasmania before he makes those kinds of statements.
—You got only two senators.
—Next time we will have three, let me tell Senator Abetz, the way you lot are going. Devonport Child Care Centres Inc. conclude:

SPEECH.PARA: Tasmania has a population growth of one percent as compared to four nationally.

This is not the environment in which to hand over an important social service to the private sector, and particularly not in rural, remote and disadvantaged areas. You lot are not about choice. There is no choice for families if their access to child care is reduced to zero through the impact of this bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Defence Industry, Science and Personnel. Is it a fact that the drafting of amendments to raise the Medicare levy for people without private health insurance has been delayed because of the intervention of the Minister for Defence Industry, Science and Personnel? If an exemption from the surcharge is applied to defence force members, what will be the cost to budget of such a move, given that the health minister, Dr Wooldridge, included defence force members in his plans for the surcharge on those without private health insurance?
—I will get an answer for the senator.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs. Can the minister outline to the Senate the significant enhancement to the tertiary sector brought about by the successful passage through the Senate of the Higher Education Legislation Amendment Bill?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Troeth for this question. She has had a longstanding interest in education matters and, no doubt, she would be pleased to have outlined the benefits to the higher education sector of the Higher Education Legislation Amendment Bill agreed to by the Senate yesterday.

ANSWER.PARA: The changes that will come about as a consequence of this legislation are quite substantial. They are beneficial to Australian universities and Australian students. The previous government thought it was appropriate to prohibit universities from offering qualified Australians the same opportunities the universities were able to offer overseas students. That is, the universities could sell a place to an international student, but they could not sell a place to an Australian student. We believed that prohibition was inappropriate and we sought to remove it. The universities will welcome that.

The previous government thought that, if universities over‐enrolled and the government got a HECS contribution from those students, it was appropriate to simply pocket that money—put the money in the back pocket and say, `Thanks very much.' We believe that is inappropriate. The HECS contribution from over‐enrolled students should be returned to the universities. That is another source of income for those universities which have the space in courses to take more students without adding costs.

We have also decided to require students in lower cost courses to pay less than students in higher cost courses. The previous government thought it was appropriate that a teacher, who has a low course cost with a lower income, should pay the same annual contribution as a doctor, who has a high course cost and would expect to have a much higher income. That was an inequity in the previous government's HECS system that we believed should be removed. It was grossly inequitable to ask a doctor to pay only the same amount as a teacher or a nurse. Finally, we have got rid of that inequity.

BREAK.PARA: Equally, the previous government was continuing to run down basic research funding. Madam President, you would have heard answers in this place before indicating this government's commitment to boosting the forward estimates in research funding for universities by something like $130 million. That is $130 million that the previous government would never have given to universities. These changes address those inequities.

Universities will have an increased flexibility therefore to channel their efforts into their chosen area of expertise. That means that our universities—excellent as they are—have now been put in a position where they can more easily compete on an international scale with world-class universities. We would expect them to compete and compete well.

Australian undergraduate students also have increased choice. For the first time in over 20 years, students who do not obtain a government funded place in the course of their choice will be able to invest in their future by purchasing this place on a fee paying basis if they choose to do so.

It is very important to remember that this government is providing 6,000 more government funded undergraduate places next year than were available this year. I repeat: 6,000 more undergraduate places will be available next year than were available this year. On top of that, other additional students who wish to buy a place will be able to. I welcome the amendment moved by Senator Harradine that also puts more equity into the HECS system, by acknowledging the costs of children. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —That is a disgrace, that answer. Full of lies. You know it is full of lies.
—On a point of order, Madam President: for a period of time to try to keep the peace, one puts up with interjections that are unsatisfactory.
—Oh, one does, does one.

—One does. But I have had it just about up to here and beyond with Senator Bolkus not having the guts to stand up and, in your hearing, Madam President, say, `That's a pack of lies.' If he wants to say that, if he wants to make those assertions, then he should not be such a damned coward and sit down and whisper it away. Senator Bolkus, say it out loud so the President can rule you out of order.

—On the point of order: I was making assertions during the minister's answer that there has been a cutback of $1.9 billion, that there would be 17,000 fewer places and that her answer was a pack of lies. If that offends you, Senator Vanstone, I withdraw.
—That is not a point of order, Senator Bolkus. It is a matter that ought to be dealt with in the taking note of answers at the end of question time.

—Madam President, I did not make myself clear. Since Senator Bolkus, I do not think, has the indecency to deny that he said, `That's a pack of lies'—he has asserted that I am a liar—I want you, Madam President, to ask him to withdraw it.
—I do not have the `indecency'. I did not whisper it. I shouted it and I withdraw it.

—I direct my question to the Minister for Social Security. I refer to the minister's recent press release in which she claimed credit for the performance of her department's data‐matching program which had resulted in total savings of $75.5 million in the first quarter of this financial year. Does the minister recall what the coalition's views on data‐matching were in opposition? Does she recall her colleague Senator Knowles stating, as recently as November last year, `We—
—Order! Senator Newman needs to hear this question so she can answer it.

—I am reminding the minister of what the coalition's views were on data‐matching when they were in opposition. Senator Knowles stated, `We'—meaning the coalition—`are very concerned about the insidious extension of data‐matching,' and `the data‐matching program presents major privacy concerns to the coalition.' Why and when did the coalition change its mind on data‐matching? (Time expired)
—The coalition has not changed its views about the need for privacy protection. No data‐matching program will be introduced by this government without the due protection of the citizen.

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. In that case, could the minister outline to the Senate precisely what the coalition's policies are in relation to that privacy protection? Could she table a necessary report on the subject before the close of this session?
—I will give consideration to that question and come back to you, Senator.

—I direct my question to the Assistant Treasurer. Minister, in response to repeated attempts by the opposition to be economic doomsayers by talking down the economy, can you advise the Senate of the implications of the national accounts released yesterday? Do the accounts show that the economy is growing solidly in a low inflation environment, consistent with the budget outlook? How will recent reforms, including industrial relations reform and the government's deficit reduction program, contribute to improving the Australian economy?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Chapman for that astute question. Senator Chapman, the national accounts confirm two things: the economy continues to grow solidly and the opposition continues to show its economic incompetence.
—Which way have the growth figures gone in the last two quarters?

—I was speaking about Mr Gareth Evans, not you, Senator Sherry, on that particular occasion. Do not get sensitive. I was not attacking you; I was attacking the shadow Treasurer. Mr Evans, in particular, has shown he is completely out of his depth as shadow Treasurer. For example, on 7 November, he said—and I am quoting your shadow Treasurer:

ANSWER.PARA: It is not an exaggeration to say, as I have been saying, that the Australian economy is dead flat—flat as the Nullarbor Plain and flat as a billiard table . . .
That is what your shadow Treasurer said. Wrong again.

The national accounts show that the economy continues to grow solidly, with GDP rising 0.8 per cent in the September quarter and 3.8 per cent in the year to the September quarter. The growth occurred despite the opposition's efforts to talk down the economy. Growth was underpinned by particularly strong investment growth and net export growth, with non‐farm stocks and private consumption also contributing.

Private business investment grew by around eight per cent, reflecting strong growth in both the equipment and construction sectors. Strong investment is, of course, needed for future strong growth. Export growth was strong as well, up 1.2 per cent, while imports fell.
The accounts show that the manufacturing, transport and communications sectors continue to grow strongly while retail trade growth has moderated, as expected at budget time.

TALK.START.PARA: —`Moderated'!
—The national accounts are consistent with the budget forecasts more generally.

ANSWER.PARA: All this is happening at a time of low inflation. The non‐farm GDP deflator rose by 1.9 per cent in the year to September. Solid growth, investment led growth, low inflation and the lowest home mortgages in years—all in all, good news for the Australian economy. I know you hate it, Senator Conroy, but it is good news for the Australian economy.

TALK.START.PARA: —Just keep kidding yourself.

—Moreover, Senator Conroy, the outlook for the medium term is enhanced by the overdue reforms the government is now implementing. We have had the passage of the workplace relations bill, the budget—a very responsible budget—ending Labor's deficit debt approach, taking the pressure off interest rates and easing the tax burden on small business, and the micro‐reform across a broader front, including, of course, the telecommunications sector.

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Chapman, in answer to your question, all in all it is a very good story for the Australian economy. We have a budget on track and the economy growing at a solid rate.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Lundy, Sen Kate

TALK.START.PARA: —My question without notice is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Health and Family Services. Minister, is it a fact that the department of health, in a submission to the inquiry into the health insurance industry, has slammed the arrangements for insurance premium increase approvals put in place after the budget by the Prime Minister? Did the department say that the short‐term time frame has made `it difficult to analyse the issue and reach a consensus on the merit of the premium increase before the premium is deemed to have effect'?

QUESTION.PARA: Minister, was the department unable to reach consensus on the premium increases granted to date, and did the increases lack merit? Minister, given the department's claims, how can the Australian public have any faith that premium increases will be granted only when the viability of the fund is in question?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn

TALK.START.PARA: —The Labor Party feeds on headlines in its question time—it is pretty noticeable—and very selective headline grazing as well.
—You should have an answer on this one, shouldn't you?
—Senator Collins, you have been interjecting persistently.

—I have a very strong memory of the performance of some of the ministers opposite when they were in government. I do not have a problem with competing with them. The advice that has come from the minister for health is that the report in the Australian today, which I gather is the report the senator is referring to, is a pretty selective and salacious piece of quoting from the department of health's submission to the Productivity Commission.
—Order! There are too many interjections and too much noise from the opposition benches.

—You wonder why they bother to ask questions; they never seem to be interested in the answers. The submission of the department of health was simply saying that the new arrangements are being bedded down. Nobody is denying that the approval arrangements needed to be improved—after all, they were arrangements which were being managed and run by the previous Labor government. Certainly, the arrangement that we inherited was not perfect. We believe that refinements are always possible and, in this case, very much so.

ANSWER.PARA: The Productivity Commission's terms of reference simply ask it to look at regulatory frameworks and to identify measures to improve efficiency and competition in the industry. We may have forgotten, but I do not think that over those 13 years there was any occasion when the Labor government refused a request from the private health funds for an increase in their premiums. That was at a time when other decisions were being made by the Labor government to effectively destroy private health care and the private health industry. Yet, even at the time that Medicare was being framed, the expectation was that a strong and vibrant private health sector was essential to the continuation and the survival of Medicare.

This government is cleaning up the mess that was left in so many portfolio areas by that arrogant government that did not listen to the people of Australia. If only, instead of asking silly questions based on stupid headlines, the Labor Party would stop whipping up hysteria and let us get on with the job of cleaning up their mess.

TALK.START.PARA: —I remind Senator Newman, first of all, about the point that I was seeking in the first question and in doing so ask a very specific supplementary question.
