Is the government giving consideration to amending the statutory seven‐day notification period for premium increases, in the light of the department's insistence on a three‐week notice period?

—The government asked for this inquiry to be undertaken by the Productivity Commission across this whole regulatory framework. The government is not proposing to make changes until it has had advice from the Productivity Commission, which it asked to inquire into the whole mess you left us with.

—My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs, Senator Hill. What is the minister's reaction to the newly‐instituted indefinite house arrest of Daw Aung San Suu Kyi? Does the minister recall that the granting to Burma of observer status at ASEAN was followed immediately by a crackdown on democratic activities and increases in human rights abuses by the military regime in that country? Does the government still maintain that allowing Burma into ASEAN will encourage the SLORC to adopt a more democratic position with respect to human rights and political freedom when the reverse is clearly now the case? Will the government now join the large number of countries, including the USA and the European Union, which have imposed or are considering imposing visa restrictions on the SLORC and economic sanctions against Burma under the current illegal and brutal regime in that country?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —Obviously, we are disturbed and disappointed at the apparent return of Daw Aung San Suu Kyi to house arrest. The facts appear to be a little unclear, but our information is that she has been at least temporarily confined to her compound and five NLD youth members have been taken into custody after leaving her compound.

ANSWER.PARA: I do not have anything to suggest that there is any link with the admission of Burma to observer status of ASEAN, as was suggested by Senator Bourne, as I interpreted the question. I think she was suggesting that perhaps this was seen as some form of green light by the SLORC to go ahead with such further oppressive measures. There is nothing in my brief that would suggest that we have evidence to that effect.

It has been suggested that these unfortunate developments may be related to the heightened student tensions. I understand NLD plans to hold a public national day ceremony on 5 December, and SLORC efforts to stop Suu Kyi from meeting foreign journalists visiting Rangoon might also be part of the motivation.

Obviously, we would wish to see her released immediately. Obviously, we would wish to see an improved human rights environment in Burma. The latest signals—they have been up and down during this year—can only be expressed as very disappointing. The dilemma for the international community remains what actions we can take beyond our wishes to see a better environment and respect for human rights within Burma.

Senator Bourne would be aware of the actions that we have taken, some of which we inherited from the previous government and have continued—the suspension of our aid program, the ban on defence exports, our position of not encouraging trade and investment. She may be aware that we lobbied hard to achieve the tough UNGA resolution on Burma adopted on 27 November calling on the SLORC to urgently implement human rights reforms. It was an effort to get the international community again to work together on this difficult subject.

I can also tell Senator Bourne that, during the last six months, we have intensified our regional diplomacy on Burma. Australia's leading role in raising the profile of Burma at the ASEAN regional forum in July is just one example.
Behind the scenes we have been involved in intensive diplomacy with our ASEAN colleagues, who tend to have greater influence on Burma's behaviour than we do. We will continue such measures.

We still do not see broader economic sanctions as a realistic alternative. We do not believe that they would be adopted by a sufficient number of countries to have any real effect at all. We do not see, as I said, that closing off visas or applying formal visa restrictions would help because we have so few officials from Burma seeking to visit Australia in any event.

It is regrettable therefore that by ourselves there is not a great deal more that we can do than what has already been done. If there was action that we could take in concert with others to help achieve a better human rights result then certainly we would take it. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the minister for that answer, some of which was quite encouraging. But I draw his attention again to parts 2 and 3 of my question. I think he has got a bit confused with what I was asking—perhaps I did not ask it clearly enough. Would the minister mind going back to the portfolio minister and asking him to go back to the department to see whether the government does believe that the granting of observer status to Burma led to a crackdown on democratic activities? And then followed the last one, the granting of membership at some future date. That has now led to a further crackdown on democrat activities and abuses of human rights. Would the minister check with the department and the minister whether we believe that is the case.

—I will specifically ask the minister that question. I said to Senator Bourne that on the material I have before me, we do not seem to have any evidence that is the case. Certainly, being granted such observer status and its progress towards membership are resulting in a worsening human rights situation. We would have hoped that, because of the influence of ASEAN members, it would result in a better performance. That is certainly not occurring in the short term. But I will take the specific question back to the minister to see whether I can get some further information.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Resources and Energy, representing the Minister for Science and Technology. Minister, has the Commonwealth acceded to requests from the Western Australian Premier, Richard Court, in his letter to the Prime Minister of 7 November to fund the remaining $10.7 million required to relocate the CSIRO Division of Petroleum and Gas to Western Australia? How can you justify such spending to other industries when you have just slashed funding for industry research and development by $235 million—that is, 27 per cent—in 1996‐97 alone? Or, in an election context, are such justifications unnecessary for the government of which you are a member?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Parer, Sen Warwick

TALK.START.PARA: —Let me respond to the second part of your question first, Senator. You will be aware of the fact that in the budget we had to make difficult decisions due to the $10 billion deficit. You might recall that Mr Beazley went to the last election saying, quite categorically, that there was no budget deficit. We ended up with a $10 billion budget deficit. We had to confront that and we did it in a fair and equitable way.

ANSWER.PARA: The decisions that we took were not easy decisions. They were decisions that had to be taken and they were decisions the previous government would not take. It fooled, it deceived, the Australian people. We addressed it in a fair and equitable way that was accepted by the public. They knew we had to take these decisions and they elected us to do so, and that is what we did.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tell us about the CSIRO.
—In respect of the CSIRO, I am unaware of the letter from the Prime Minister. I will refer it to the minister and come back to you.

—I indicated it was a letter from the Western Australian Premier, Mr Court, who wrote to the Prime Minister on 7 November with a wish list of pork‐barrelling in the Western Australian election. Apart from an election, Minister, what characteristics does Western Australia have that would merit such uncharacteristic generosity from your government? Will you now also consider the shipbuilders in WA and perhaps the book printers in Maryborough in the same spirit of generosity?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Parer, Sen Warwick

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I am not sure whether that was really a supplementary question, but I am only too happy to answer it in regard to shipbuilders and book bounties.

ANSWER.PARA: This government's decision—and, again, a difficult decision—to terminate the bounties ahead of time was, of course, caused by the need to reduce the budget deficit. But the opposition's stance on this is totally and utterly hypocritical. If you are so concerned about the removal of bounties, why did you phase them down from around 20 per cent in most cases? Why did the former minister say they were only a temporary form of assistance? That is because, Senator, you in opposition are so hypocritical and because they are.

The government has recognised that there are more valuable ways that we can enhance the performance of the industry. We have taken additional measures to ensure that Australian industries are well prepared for the challenges ahead.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs. I refer the minister to next week's plenary session of the United Nations General Assembly, which will again vote on resolution L.37, commonly known as the Malaysian resolution, which calls for negotiations leading to a nuclear weapons convention. How will Australia vote in the plenary session on resolution L.37, given that Australia abstained on the first vote on this resolution? Given that this resolution follows the recommendations of the International Court of Justice and of the comprehensive test ban treaty which call on parties to pursue negotiations in good faith leading towards disarmament and allows for the steps outlined by the Canberra commission and given Australia's stance on the nuclear non‐proliferation treaty, the CTBT, the International Court of Justice decision and the Canberra commission, how could the government justify not supporting or abstaining from a vote on this highly important resolution?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —I will give a little background to this because I am not sure that all senators would be familiar with this matter. The Malaysian sponsored General Assembly resolution urging negotiations on nuclear disarmament was a new resolution which built upon extracts from the advisory opinion on the legality of the threat or use of nuclear weapons issued by the International Court of Justice in July.

ANSWER.PARA: As you know, Madam President, the Australian government is fully committed to achieving nuclear disarmament. While we were therefore sympathetic to the general nuclear disarmament aims behind the resolution, we were concerned about its main thrust, which was early negotiation on a nuclear disarmament convention. It was the view of the Australian government that there are many steps to be taken on the road to the ultimate goal of nuclear disarmament before the question of a single nuclear weapons convention could be productively addressed.

Australia would therefore have preferred this resolution to focus attention on the immediate and intermediate concrete steps which would take forward the process of nuclear disarmament rather than seeking an artificial timetable or possible final mechanism for achieving the goal. Australia therefore abstained on the resolution, as did other regional countries such as Japan and South Korea.

Australia's abstention sought to balance considerations such as Australia's commitment to the twin goals of preventing proliferation of nuclear weapons and working through progressive balanced steps towards complete nuclear disarmament on the one hand and, on the other hand, our concern to ensure that international deliberation on the International Court of Justice's advisory opinion facilitates rather than complicates the attainment of real advances on the international disarmament agenda.
While abstaining in the vote on the resolution as a whole, Australia did vote in favour of the operative paragraph of the resolution which underlined the unanimous opinion of the court that:
There exists an obligation to pursue in good faith and bring to a conclusion negotiations leading to nuclear disarmament in all its aspects under strict and effective international control.

Which, again, underlines the government's firm commitment to nuclear disarmament. In relation to the vote in the plenary session, there is no reason to believe—presuming it will be the same resolution that is returned—that Australia would change its position.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question, Madam President. The minister missed out the point that I raised in my question, which was that this resolution allows for the stepped approach outlined by the Canberra commission. Does the government concede that the resolution enjoys overwhelming global support and is likely to be passed with a comfortable majority at the December plenary session of the United Nations General Assembly, where further abstention by Australia would make us look even more hypocritical and less genuine in our previous attempts to further the cause of nuclear disarmament? In view of these considerations, is there any chance that the government will change its stance to actively support the co-sponsorship of this UNGA resolution?

—No, I expect that Australia will stand by its previous votes for the reasons that I outlined. I am a little surprised that Senator Margetts is not applauding the role that the Australian government has adopted towards constructive negotiations on nuclear disarmament and, in particular, our view that rather than talking about a disarmament convention, which might be an ultimate step, we should be taking up the initiative of positive immediate and intermediate steps that can produce real progress along that path.

—My question is directed to Senator Parer representing the Minister for Small Business and Consumer Affairs. Is the minister aware that the fitting of air safety bags to motor vehicles, whilst a benefit to the majority of people, has contributed to the deaths of many children under the age of 10? Does the government plan to take any steps to see that these bags are modified or at least to study their effects? Will consideration be given to making compulsory the fitting of two airbags which release at a slower rate, or would the cost of this be too prohibitive?

—I thank the senator for his question. I happened to see those articles in the paper about the danger of airbags. In fact, I understand that there have not been many deaths but, of course, one death is more than enough if it happens to be your child. I agree with you entirely, Senator, about that. I am unaware of whether there are any investigations going on about it this matter, but Mr McGauran may have responsibility for this matter and I will refer your question to him. I think it is of concern to people that these bags are going off and, in the process, even in a minor accident, are causing deaths. It is something that should be considered.

—My question is to the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs, Senator Herron. Minister, you will be aware of newspaper reports that Queensland police arrested a large number of Aboriginal mourners on their way to a funeral at Woorabinda. Can you inform the Senate of the latest developments in this incident?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Herron, Sen John
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Coonan for the question. I am aware of the newspaper reports referred to by Senator Coonan. I have been in touch with the Queensland Minister for Aboriginal Affairs and I have received a detailed report from ATSIC. I find the actions of the police appalling. I find it beyond comprehension that anyone could decide that a gathering for a funeral was an appropriate opportunity to conduct a police raid, particularly when one considers the cultural insensitivity displayed.

ANSWER.PARA: For the information of the Senate, I have been advised that on 3 December a police contingent went to Woorabinda to serve 388 warrants on some 130 people. The warrants had been overdue for periods of between two days and two years. The amounts ranged from $20 to $700‐plus. As a result of the police raid, which occurred at the funeral of a highly respected elder, it is understood that at least 27 people were taken into police custody. The police operation involved 21 police officers from Rockhampton and seven community police from Woorabinda.

In light of the fact that many of the warrants are up to two years old, there may be a breach by the Queensland police of recommendation 120 of the Royal Commission into Aboriginal Deaths in Custody. The Queensland government gave qualified support to the recommendation, which is:
That governments consider introducing an ongoing amnesty on the execution of long‐outstanding warrants of commitment for unpaid fines.

The source of that is the response by the governments to the Royal Commission into Aboriginal Deaths in Custody, volume one. The Queensland Department of Aboriginal Affairs and ATSIC, in conjunction with the police minister's office, are investigating the incident. I understand that the Queensland police minister, Mr Russell Cooper, will be making a statement regarding the incident to the state parliament later today.

I note that in the Courier‐Mail newspaper today police minister Russell Cooper was reported as saying that he was `appalled at the decision to continue the operation while the funeral of a highly respected elder was taking place'. I agree with and welcome that comment.

This government believes that the state and territory governments must make a top priority of implementing fully the recommendations of the Royal Commission into Aboriginal Deaths in Custody. Issues like this will be considered at the forthcoming ministerial summit on high Aboriginal incarceration rates and deaths in custody. I can only repeat that I find the matter appalling and I look forward with interest to the statement by Mr Cooper later today in the Queensland parliament.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Industry, Science and Tourism. I draw the minister's attention to recent reports of the federal government's intention to privatise its Public Service computer network. Is the minister aware of growing concern within the Australian computer industry that it risks losing $100 million in Public Service contracts to multinational competitors such as Electronic Data Systems, IBM and the Computer Science Corporation as a consequence of the government's plans? What impact will this proposal have on domestic R&D in the IT industry? What calculations has the government made as to its long-term effects on our balance of payments?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Parer, Sen Warwick

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware of the fact that discussions have been going on for some time now about the privatisation or contracting out of the IT business in the public sector. I am unaware of how far that has progressed at this stage but a committee was formed some time ago to see if benefits could be achieved.

ANSWER.PARA: The assertion that this is going to end up in the hands of multinational companies is not necessarily correct. We have in Australia a well developed IT industry, as you would be aware. Certainly from a software point of view it is very much a leader in this part of the world. I am happy to refer the matter to Minister Moore and come back with a more detailed answer if he has one.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Minister, are you aware that a significant part of the South Australian government computer business is now in the hands of EDS? Are you also aware that that contract was announced by then Premier Brown on the day EDS finished in court against the Florida government for naughtinesses in their business?
—`Naughtinesses.'

—I can use a better word if you like. Minister, I would like you, in seeking any further information on this matter, to take account of the experience already in Australia that multinationals are succeeding in taking over some of our computer work and that Australia really does have a need to be concerned.
—I will refer your supplementary question to the minister.

—I draw the attention of honourable senators to the presence in the chamber of a parliamentary delegation from the National Assembly of the Socialist Republic of Vietnam, led by Associate Professor Dr Tam Dan. On behalf of honourable senators, I have pleasure in welcoming you here to the Senate and trust that your visit will be both enjoyable and beneficial.
—Hear, hear!

—My question is directed to the Minister for Resources. I want to follow up my question of yesterday about greenhouse gas reduction. Minister, yesterday you said that the Megabare model had been refereed domestically by the Centre for Policy Studies at Monash University. Minister, what do you say then to comments by the centre's professor, Peter Dixon, that he wishes ABARE would stop quoting him as a referee for this interpretation because he is not, that the government's interpretation of the data is `crazy' and that the misuse of the model is `extraordinary'? Minister, you also told the Senate that the model was internationally accepted. Is it not a fact that the model never participated in any rigorous international study before your government based its policy on it and that it still has not undergone such study and has never been published in a refereed journal? How long is the government going to base its greenhouse policy on misinterpretations the of results of an untested, non-credible economic model?

—I made it clear to Senator Kernot yesterday that I would seek advice from ABARE as to any comments that were made in the refereeing of the ABARE model. I draw Senator Kernot's attention to the fact that the ABARE model is one that is accepted.
—All the people you are quoting don't accept what you say.

—If Senator Kernot had allowed me to come back with the comments made by various referees it might have been helpful. This is still on notice. I have offered to do that. The Megabare model is used extensively. It is one that—
—Keep flicking through the pages.
—I will.

BREAK.PARA: Honourable senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order!
—I made the point yesterday, Senator, that it is an economic model.
—Where are the referees?
—I gave you the referees after question time yesterday. They were advised to me by ABARE. You are quoting a particular person I do not know.
—I am quoting one you quoted.

—I gave the name of Monash University. That is the information given to me by ABARE. I know that you want to dispute ABARE because ABARE is not giving you the answers you want. That is where the real problem lies. The people involved in ABARE are totally professional. You asked me a question yesterday as to whether they were being funded by the Coal Association of Australia as if to say, `Well, if they are, they have some sort of bias.'

BREAK.PARA: That, to me, is a total slur on this organisation. I would say that those people on the other side who have had any relationship with ABARE, including people such as Senator Bob Collins, would support the fact that ABARE is well recognised as being independent and having people of great integrity. With regard to the other model that ABARE is developing—I thought I would just mention it to you—they have not put in those other factors that you raised with me yesterday, but they are working on the model. The name of that model, if I am correct, is Gigabare, which has yet to be developed.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Minister, you started by saying that you were going to read all these comments, but you still have not read one comment about what the referees have said. Are you saying that ABARE has misled you about the comments of the referees? Will you undertake to take that back to ABARE, and bring these comments to the chamber? You say that I am not happy with the modelling. No, I am not. I am asking you to prove why, in scientific terms, it should be accepted as internationally credible when you cannot even prove that it has been internationally refereed according to due scientific process.

—Madam President, I did tell Senator Kernot that I would come back to her. I understand that there is also another referee involved, a fairly well‐known scientist from Sydney who is doing a review of the process. I will come back to you on that.
—Senator Parer, you should be addressing your remarks to the chair.

—Thank you, Madam President. Senator Kernot is trying desperately to denigrate an organisation that is held in absolutely high regard and high respect. I might say, Senator, that it is regarded so not just by me but by people such as Senator Collins, who dealt with them for many years. There is no doubt that they have always shown strong professional independence and objectivity over the past 50 years. That is what they have done. You can question them as much as you like. I am happy to come back with some detailed answers to questions you might be asking in this respect. (Time expired)

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Industry, Science and Tourism. Has your attention been drawn to comments by the managing director of ICI Australia, Mr Warren Hayes, that the government's R&D cuts will make Australia less competitive as a location for global R&D? Are you aware that Mr Hayes states that the R&D cuts would `leave less money for your organisation to develop your research and take it to market'? I further ask the minister whether his attention has been drawn to comments by the chairman of Robert Bosch, Mr Kurt Liedtke, who has warned that Australia will attract global R&D only if it is offered a better environment for it than other markets? How does the minister reconcile these views of industry players at the coalface of R&D expenditure with the government's view that the cuts will not reduce Australia's international competitiveness?
—Give us the Randy Wigle answer again, Warwick.
—I will. We could go on and on repeating over and over that we do not walk away from the fact that we cut R&D from 150 per cent to 125 per cent, which is still internationally competitive.
—No, it is not.
—It is still internationally competitive.
—You just lie about these things. You think repetition solves the problem. It is not true.
—There are far too many interruptions and interjections.
—Madam President, I raise a point of order. Senator Cook said that Senator Parer lied. I think he should withdraw it. He used the word `lie' and I think he should withdraw it.

—On the point of order: I did not say that. Senator Hill was interjecting across the chamber to me. I said, `You lot just lie about that.' I was not talking to Senator Parer. I was talking to the Leader of the Government in the Senate, who was interjecting.
—On the point of order: I would be very surprised if Senator Patterson could hear anything. She is so far away on the back bench.
—That is not a point of order.

—The latest exchange indicates that there are far too many interjections from both sides of the chamber at present. Questions cannot be heard, and answers cannot be heard either. Senators should abide by the standing orders.
—Thank you, Madam President. I will try again. Let us have Senator Ray back on the front bench.
—Senator Parer, you should be dealing with Senator Childs's question and directing your remarks to the chair.

—Thank you, Madam President. I was just trying to help the Senate, because I thought it might bring some class back into it. The benefits we are deriving from the general tax concessions provide a researcher with a maximum tax benefit of 54c for every dollar of R&D expended under 150 per cent deductibility. Under 125 per cent deductibility, the maximum benefit available under the concession is reduced to 45c. Even at that reduced rate, as I mentioned earlier, this is one of the most generous in the world.

BREAK.PARA: All the R&D programs in the world by the previous government did not stop them destroying many of our industries. If fact, you will recall one million Australians being out of work. What we are about—

TALK.START.PARA: —Industry is telling you you are wrong.

—No-one likes cuts. I think I have said this time and time again: we had no option but to take some hard decisions. But we have still left in place an R&D regime which is equivalent to that in most other parts of the world. The other matter that people opposite keep raising is the syndication. They knew the rorts were there. I have said this over and over again and I will repeat it: I know you tried to do something about it, Senator Cook, but it did not work. We had no option. The fact that you and people on your side are persisting would indicate to me that somehow you are supporting these people involved in abusing the system, involved in using a system legally but really as a tax lurk. These are the people supporting those very people who have ripped off the system. In the process, because we had no other option but to address it in this way, there are a number who are quite legitimate. I do not disagree with that, but there was no option other than to do it.
—What are you going to do about them?

—Senator Cook interjects, `What are you going to do about them?' He would be well aware that we have the Start program. Those particular people who have been knocked back under the syndication program have the opportunity to apply through Start.

—My question is directed to the Minister for the Environment. This week has been designated CoastCare Week. This is of particular interest to Tasmanians, whose coastline is greater than the Victorian and New South Wales coastlines put together. Could the minister explain what CoastCare Week aims to achieve and what actions the Commonwealth is taking to address the challenges facing our coastline?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to get this question, particularly from Senator Abetz, because he is one of the senators who have been pressing the very justified claims of Tasmania to a fair and reasonable share of the Natural Heritage Trust. I am pleased to get the question today because this is the historic day on which the Senate has voted in principle for the sale of one‐third of Telstra to fund this Natural Heritage Trust in order for us to put in place the largest capital fund for reinvestment in Australia's natural capital in the history of this country.

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Abetz, your state and your coastline, which you accurately remind us exceeds that of Victoria and New South Wales combined, will benefit from that fund. So it is a great day and I am pleased to give recognition to your contribution. I remind Senator Abetz that $100 million will be now devoted to our coasts and clean seas policy under the Natural Heritage Trust. That will benefit all Australia, all Australians. CoastCare itself, which you refer to in reference to CoastCare Week, brings the community into this process, because it is a week in which we acknowledge the thousands of ordinary Australians who are devoting their time and energy to caring for local coastlines through CoastCare groups. This is in fact the new environmental movement in Australia—something the Labor Party does not seem to appreciate—with tens of thousands of Australians out there making a contribution, recognising problems in their environment and doing something about them.

BREAK.PARA: I am advised that there are now some 700 such community groups nationwide. We estimate that about 140,000 Australians are involved in those groups. Between them they now have some 250 projects under way to rehabilitate beaches and dunes, control weeds, survey and protect flora and fauna, prepare management plans, undertake monitoring, and educate the community on coastal and marine matters. The government supports the CoastCare groups. It supports them through direct financial assistance for their work and also through supporting CoastCare facilitators who are employed to assist local CoastCare groups.

I was therefore pleased last weekend, on Ocean Care Day, to announce $722,000 worth of CoastCare projects for Victoria. I did so in conjunction with my Victorian colleague Marie Tehan. This is the first of this year's CoastCare funding which will be going to communities all around Australia. The Victorian allocation is of course part of the $3 million that we have provided to the program this year, which I remind you is a doubling of last year's program which was put in place by Labor.

I also take the opportunity to commend Australian business groups who are supporting the CoastCare program through sponsorship, in particular Uncle Toby's and Pioneer, and also some of our sporting champions who have lent their names to this program, Lisa Curry and Patrick Rafter.

After years of neglect, we are doing something; we are doing it together with the broader community. Together, we can make a difference. The Senate has today taken a step towards this goal by voting in principle to set up such a magnificent Natural Heritage Trust. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Veterans' Affairs. You would be aware that one of the most common disabilities suffered by Vietnam veterans is post traumatic stress disorder, the side effects of which can include substance abuse and erratic behaviour. Is it not true that a number of veterans commit crimes, the cause of which is contributed to by the war caused disabilities suffered by these veterans? Is it true that veterans who commit offences under state laws in such circumstances will now not be entitled to receive Commonwealth legal aid funding from 1 July next year? Does the Commonwealth deny that it has any responsibility for the legal consequences of the war related injuries suffered by these veterans?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Evans for the question. Being the wife of the Vietnam veteran, the wellbeing of Vietnam veterans is, of course, of great importance to me.
—And the mother of an army engineer.

—Yes, and I am proud of both of them. I hope you are proud of your family, Senator. One of the saddest things to come out of any war is those people who have suffered some form of post traumatic stress disorder. It is now believed that the veterans of the First World War who suffered shell shock were suffering from some form of post traumatic stress disorder. But still, after all these years, people do not really know how it is caused and how best to treat it.

ANSWER.PARA: For a proportion of Vietnam veterans who are continuing to suffer that disorder, it is a very distressing matter and often leads to family break-ups and occasionally, as you have said, to crime. I am not certain whether the Vietnam veterans entitlements under legal aid that you are referring to are affected by the changes which Mr Williams has announced. Certainly, the Commonwealth is requiring the states to provide legal aid in respect of state laws. Nevertheless, as I understand it, where people are in receipt of Commonwealth income by way of financial support, like social security benefits, the Commonwealth can help. But I will double check that because I would not want to mislead you.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Minister, I think you will find that the issues that I raised with you are correct. I think you will also find it is true that some members seeking compensation for injuries suffered while serving in the armed forces will not be entitled to Commonwealth legal aid funding from 1 July next year. For example, isn't it true that many of the victims of the Voyager disaster have had to rely upon legal aid funding to bring action for compensation under state law? Wouldn't these veterans have been unable to obtain justice, without the support offered through the Commonwealth provision of legal aid in a manner which did not discriminate against them, on the basis that their claims arose under state as opposed to Commonwealth law?

—Senator Evans raised several issues there relating to the legal action under the Voyager disaster and also relating to our veterans' compensation. I think it is best if I get a detailed answer for you from the minister responsible. If you really want the answer to that question, you must ask the minister responsible. I am happy to do that for you if you are serious about the answer.
—Madam President, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper .

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Parer, Sen Warwick

TALK.START.PARA: —In question time Senator Hogg raised a question with me about airbags. The question relates to using horror stories from the United States to suggest that Australian motorists are at risk from airbags. I am advised that in Australia there are no grounds for concern. The situation in the US is quite different. In the United States, seat belts are not compulsory. Airbags are used as the primary restraint mechanism for protecting motorists in collisions.

QUESTION.PARA: This means that airbags in US vehicles are triggered more aggressively and earlier to capture an unharnessed occupant. This can occur at very low impact speeds, raising the possibility of injury, particularly to young children. In Australia where seat belts are compulsory, airbags are triggered later at a higher impact speed and inflate at a slower rate. We also use a smaller bag. I understand that the Federal Office of Road Safety is monitoring the United States situation but is not aware of any problems in Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Faulkner, Sen John

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the answers given by the Minister for Social Security (Senator Newman), to questions without notice asked today.

TALK.START.PARA: —Were they answers?

—I baulk at the word `answers' because we have yet another series of non-answers from Senator Newman. Senator Newman, I think it has now been identified that you are the weakest minister in this Senate. In a team of no-hopers, you are the worst.

—Mr Deputy President, I raise a point of order: I ask for your consideration of the argument that this is an abuse of taking note of answers. This process was put in place to give the opposition an opportunity to respond to a specific answer, to put their point of view and to contribute—
—He is certainly doing that.

—Hang on, give me a chance —to the debate on a particular issue arising out of the question. That is why you take note of a particular answer. Senator Faulkner has not sought to do that at all. He said, `I want to take note of answers so we can have a debate about a particular minister.' That was not the purpose for which this reform was instituted.
—Pardon!

—That was not the purpose at all. The purpose was that we objected to the fact that during question time the minister got all the time to answer on a particular subject matter and the opposition got no chance to respond. So this reform was instituted to allow an opposition to respond to a particular issue. That is not what Senator Faulkner is doing. That is why this is an abuse. He should be brought back to the purpose of this part of the program, and that is to debate issues arising out of a particular question.

—Order! Before I rule on the point of order, I should mention—in case honourable senators are concerned—that the clocks had been stopped while this point of order is being discussed, so Senator Faulkner will not miss any of his time. Senator Faulkner moved to take note of certain answers. I think that he is entitled to make some comments before he gets into discussing those answers. That is what he is doing. I would ask Senator Faulkner to continue.

—I very seriously make the point that here we have a situation where a cabinet minister represents a range of other portfolio ministers in this chamber. We now have the situation where there is no point in a non-government senator asking questions about issues such as defence; health and family services; defence industry, science and personnel; and veterans' affairs—all represented in the chamber by Senator Newman—because consistently this minister wilfully refuses to answer these questions. She seems to think that the only role a minister in the Senate representing a minister in the House of Representatives should play is to be a post box for them, to take everything on notice.

SPEECH.PARA: I must say, Mr Deputy President, that has never been the practice in the past. During 13 years of Labor government you saw ministers in this chamber representing ministers in the House of Representatives make every attempt to seriously deal with issues of substance that were raised by senators around this chamber. But it is even worse than that: when Senator Reynolds asked Senator Newman today yet another question on her own portfolio of social security, again she was incapable of answering the question.

So the only questions now that this incompetent minister is willing to front up and answer are dorothy dix questions asked by government senators with written notice and written answers. They are the only questions that this incompetent minister is willing to answer. No questions on her own portfolio or the portfolio she represents is she willing to answer.

I read in the newspaper that workers who were renovating Senator Newman's office dubbed her the Hyacinth Bucket of Australia politics. That is what I read in the newspaper. I must say, in many ways, Senator Newman, you are a dead ringer for her, aren't you? It is your demeanour; you are so patronising, you are so nosy. Your superior air—

TALK.START.PARA: —Could I take a point of order, Mr Deputy President? There is a lot of bitterness coming across the table at the moment, but I suggest again that it is outside the scope of this debate.
—Why do you have to defend her? Can't she defend herself?

—I do not know why she has to sit here and listen to that tirade of abuse, actually. Maybe in certain circumstances we on this side have to do that, but I do not think we have to under this part of the program because that is not what this part is all about. Therefore I am suggesting, Mr Deputy President, that you might suggest that taking note of answers is all about issues arising out of the answer to a particular question, and that should be the subject of the debate.
—Order! I think some of the language has become a little indelicate. I ask the Leader of the Opposition to concentrate on the answers that he is taking note of.

—Thank you, Mr Deputy President. I certainly always try not to be indelicate. I was actually going to make the point that the real Hyacinth Bucket has a lot to say. This minister, masquerading as Hyacinth Bucket, has nothing to say. That is the key point about this.

SPEECH.PARA: I really believe that it is outrageous for this minister to hold out her hand for the pay cheque at the end of the month. It is outrageous because you are not willing to fulfil any of your responsibilities as a minister. You are weak, you are incompetent, you are unwilling to come in this place and answer questions that are directed to you. It means that an opposition or a non‐government senator can not only not ask you questions about those important areas that you represent in this chamber, but you now refuse, Minister, because you are so weak, because you have failed so miserably to get across your portfolio—

TALK.START.PARA: —Could I take a point of order? This is an abuse, Mr Deputy President, I put to you again for the third time, because it is not a matter arising from the answer to a question at all. To get it from Senator Faulkner, who so failed as a minister that Prime Minister Keating had to bring in Senator Bob Collins to rescue the situation, is appalling in itself.
—You were praising Coast Care today. He started it.
—I said we had to double the money.
—I think you have raised your point of order. Senator Faulkner, if you can, would you relate your remarks to the answers that you are taking note of?

—We have a situation where Senator Newman was asked questions representing the Minister for Defence Industry, Science and Personnel, and she was not able to answer; representing the Minister for Health and Family Services and she was not able to answer; representing the Minister for Veterans' Affairs and she was not able to answer; and representing her own portfolio, Social Security, she was not able to answer.

SPEECH.PARA: The fundamental point I make is this: any minister in this place who is worth their salt has a responsibility to get on top of their brief—not only their own department. Even if you are not capable of doing it in the portfolios you represent, what about making a rough attempt in social security where you have an obligation, a ministerial responsibility, to come in here and provide this parliament with responses to questions?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn

TALKER.NAME: Senator NEWMAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Social Security and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women)

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, I do believe this was a misuse of the taking note process, but I cannot let it pass. Once again this loud‐mouthed bully—and I regret having to describe a fellow senator as that, but that is what he has become—tried a vitriolic attack which has no substance at all.

SPEECH.PARA: This is the former minister who was described by the Sydney Morning Herald as the `minister for getting rolled'. I wonder if Senator Faulkner remembers that? This is the former minister who said that he was a man without a dream. This is the senator who, in very strange and extraordinary circumstances, had the opposition walk out on him during his maiden speech. That does not happen to people.

This is the senator of whom Premier Goss said, `I feel betrayed over Port Hinchinbrook.' Do you remember that? The Age said, `There was an image of a minister in training remaining.' The Age also said, `Faulkner's intervention futile.' Do you remember that? And what was the cost? The cost was 40 jobs and $1 million. What about the woodchip brawl that you had with your colleague Beddall? What did the Australian say about that? `Faulkner was a disappointment as an environment minister.' `He was politically incompetent', said the Sydney Morning Herald. The Australian said that Faulkner and Beddall were both discredited.

The carbon tax backdown—does Senator Faulkner remember that? The Australian said that the debate there was `ineptly handled by Faulkner'. Does he have an inferiority complex or something? He certainly has a class war complex.

What about the Berlin climate summit; does he remember that? The Australian said, `Faulkner takes a roasting at the summit' and, `His performance left Australia looking inept abroad.' That's what they said about him.

We saw a very hysterical incident in here the other day when he could not control himself when he tried to take on the Deputy President. Do you remember how hysterical he has been in the past? He won the award for the most hysterical outburst at an ALP conference. Does the senator remember that? Perhaps he goes away in such a fury that he does not know what he is doing.

TALK.START.PARA: —But I came in here and answered questions.

—And so have I—day after day. Senator Loosley told him that he should retire and grow onions at his comfortable Glebe terrace—he is a yuppie as well. Bob Brown said, `Faulkner had failed on uranium, the greenhouse, the Tarkine and the forests.' How much more of a failure could he be? He has covered just about everything else. The opposition has been engaging in a fake class war. Comments have been thrown across the chamber for weeks about my looks, my speech—obviously, my intelligence—
—Your looks! They're great.

—Thank you. My looks are okay? Nevertheless, the opposition, who have a fixation on class, seem to find that everything about me gets under their skin. I am sorry but I am here to stay. I am doing a job—I am doing a very big job—and I remember very well that, when the opposition were in government, the people who sat on the front benches had some very strange ways. I have highlighted some of Senator Faulkner's. I do not have time to go on and on but—
—Tell us about Senator Crowley's answers.

—I remember Senator Crowley's answers extraordinarily well. How could anybody forget, because you could not read them, let alone understand them. Certainly, if there were a lesson to be learnt about answering questions from the previous government, I sat here for 10 years and took it all in and studied the techniques thoroughly.

SPEECH.PARA: There are some sitting on the back bench now who were very good teachers. I thank Senator Ray for that. It is a pity that he is not down the front where they could use some professionalism. In closing, I find that nobody in Australia knows that Senator Faulkner is the shadow minister for social security. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —Let me continue Senator Newman's education. The one thing I never did when I sat over on that side of the chamber was fail properly to get across the portfolios I represented from the other chamber. I always attempted to give sensible and accurate answers—at a cost, because I had to work a lot harder to do so.

SPEECH.PARA: Today, the first question Senator Newman was asked was a very serious question about the one per cent Medicare levy, why the legislation had not proceeded, and why Mrs Bishop was running interference, preventing that legislation from emerging—something which Senator Newman, as a cabinet minister, should have been across. She did not answer the question at all; just took it on notice and sat down.

She was asked a second question on data matching. You only have to read the Hansard record to know how often she and her colleagues have spoken on data matching. Yet we got a contemptuous answer here today with total disdain and disrespect for the Senate. She just wiped it off, not answering the question. Those opposite were very vocal in opposition about data matching. Now the amnesia has hit; now they can say absolutely nothing.

Then Senator Newman got a third question on her own department. She could not answer it. Finally, because she could not answer the other three, we managed to get question No. 7 or 8 up on veterans' affairs, which she could not answer either. This is serious. It is not good enough to come into this chamber with a plaintive plea, like at the end of the Elephant Man film. `I am only representing a minister,' she says, as though she has no responsibility whatsoever for providing information to this chamber.

There is a higher responsibility in the Senate because, normally, there are only seven or eight ministers collectively representing about 21 or 22 ministers in the other place. They treat it with contempt over there—it is an institutionalised thing—but not over here, and it is not reflected necessarily by other ministers.

Senator Hill, who is sitting there, always tries at estimates committees and in this chamber to answer questions. I will not flatter him on the competence of his answers—I would not want to embarrass him—but at least he tries. But Senator Newman at estimates committees does not try at all. The secretary, Tony Blunn, is the spokesman; he answers everything. Senator Newman sits there silent. The silent senator sits there, saying nothing because she cannot get into trouble if she does not say anything.

She does not even bother to bring her Defence portfolio brief. Where is it? Can she wave it around? Did she bring it down today? No, she did not. Did she bring it down in the last few weeks? No, she did not. That is her contempt for this chamber: she does not even bring the defence department brief with her, does she? No, she does not.

Today we had a total failure to address these issues. It is the old saying: ignorance is bliss. Senator Newman would be a very happy person today. Not only does she say, `I am only representing,' but she also always puts in her answer `the opposition is not interested in this answer' when it is a non‐answer. Then there is a repeat of the question, which takes up 30 seconds. `Thank you for the question,' takes up another 10 seconds. With a couple of compliments to the person in the chair we are a minute into the answer. Then suddenly she says, `I will seek further information.' She says it in a very gracious and kindly way—that is terrific—but we want to see the answers now.

We also want to see whether Senator Newman can hack it in this chamber. Clearly, she cannot. She cannot handle the cut and thrust. She had to come in here today and read prepared articles out of the newspapers—golly gosh, wasn't that really funny—but she cannot defend herself, her own record, or her failure to answer questions.
In conclusion, there was the answer that Senator Newman gave Senator Lundy where she described the quote as `salacious'. What did you mean by that, Minister?

TALK.START.PARA: —Look it up in the dictionary.

—Senator Abetz wants me to look it up in the dictionary. I did. It means lustful. It means lecherous, tending to cause sexual desire. Did the earth move here in the Senate today? Did it, Senator Newman? No, not only can you not answer questions, but the one time you try to make a foray into it you use some word totally out of context. Go back, read your briefs before next week and be prepared to answer questions on portfolios you represent here.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Abetz, Sen Eric

TALK.START.PARA: —I feel somewhat superfluous after the mauling that Senator Newman gave to Senator Faulkner. Senator Newman quite properly outlined to Senator Faulkner his failed history as a Labor Party apparatchik and as a Labor Party minister in the former disgraced government.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Newman has taken on a very tough job and is doing a superb job. The Labor Party cannot stomach to see a successful woman in politics because their success stories are people like Dr Carmen Lawrence. That is their great success story. Or I can point to Senator Belinda Neal, another great success story of the Labor Party women. No wonder that Senator Robert Ray referred to the women on his side as only `biological women'. That was the term—biological women.

TALK.START.PARA: —What other kinds are there?

—Women that are capable of holding cabinet positions—and you do not have any of them on that side at all! That is why the right wing of the Australian Labor Party are calling your frontbench women only biological women, because they do not have the sorts of capacities that Senator Newman has. To make sure that they do not look so bad, you think that you can attack Senator Newman gratuitously and, by trying to chop her off at the knees, make the women on your side look a bit better.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me tell you that you are going to fail. You people know from your own reports that two demographic areas that were particularly adverse for the ALP in the 1996 failed election campaign were women and the aged—in this case, the women. We won the women's vote. Why? Because we had senior people like Senator Newman on our side who won the women's vote for us.

The electorate no longer wants the old hackneyed lines of the socialists, feminists— all those lines. The Dr Carmen Lawrence lines these days just do not work. The people of Australia respect the sort of people that Senator Newman represents—the sort that can actually tell the truth.
Senator Robert Ray, from time to time, took questions on notice as a minister. If you are not 100 per cent over the topic, the decent thing to do is to take the question on notice.

TALK.START.PARA: —Not all the time.

—Just because you talked for four minutes, Senator Bob Collins, does not mean that you answered the question. You used to think that if you talked for four minutes it meant that you answered the question. The reality is that you guys never answered questions whereas Senator Newman does. When she thinks she can provide more information, she decently and graciously—as Senator Robert Ray says—takes the matter on notice and provides further information in the future.

SPEECH.PARA: Another matter that really gets at the Labor Party is that Senator Newman, in her capacity as minister, has targeted those areas in welfare where people are getting funds which they should not be getting. She has been criticised by the Labor Party for that. But their own research from the last federal election tells us under the heading `Targeted welfare' that it seemed that everyone knew of a welfare cheat. This exploitation was blamed on Labor.

Senator Newman, in a very methodical and professional manner, is going about knocking out those sorts of rorts—and you people criticise her for it. Each time you criticise her, the more support we get in the electorate. So I welcome these debates when Senator Faulkner and Senator Robert Ray get up—and undoubtedly somebody else will get up—to try to criticise Senator Newman for the excellent job she does. Each time you do so, we will win more and more support within the electorate.
In case there is any doubt in the minds of those opposite, we on this side are terribly proud to have Senator Newman as one of the senior ministers of the Howard government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Neal, Sen Belinda

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise also to take note of the answers—or those things that are referred to as answers—given by Senator Newman. I have to say that Senator Newman is right: we are not entitled to criticise her for her physical appearance or the method that she uses to speak. But there are certain things that we are entitled to criticise her for as a minister. One of the duties of ministers is to answer properly questions given to them in this chamber at question time. Certainly, if someone cannot answer those questions, they are entitled to be criticised. That is why we have raised this matter here today.

SPEECH.PARA: The situation has occurred on many occasions that Senator Newman has quite rudely pointed out to me that she is not the minister for health; that she only represents the minister for health in this chamber. But the fact is that, even though she only represents the minister for health, she certainly has a responsibility, at least to a certain level, to get the briefings on the issue and provide at least some sort of rudimentary answer in the area of health. On many occasions—and even today—Senator Newman has failed to do that.

Today she took it one step further because not only did she fail to answer questions on the portfolio that she represents from the other house; she also failed to deal in an adequate way with issues raised within her own portfolio. That really is quite sad.

It was quite amusing to hear some of the matters Senator Newman raised about the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate (Senator Faulkner). It was almost, `This is your life, Senator Faulkner.' That was pretty amusing. We actually enjoyed it in some respects, but the fact is that Senator Faulkner does not have responsibilities as a minister that he is not carrying out.

What this shows about Senator Newman is that she is failing to carry out her responsibilities as a minister; she is failing to get across the issues she should be getting across. She has the capacity to do the research and the preparation, as demonstrated in the speech she read on Senator Faulkner, but she just has not bothered. She has the capacity. She has the ability. She has the time to prepare for those issues but, when making the choice on how to spend her time, she decided that she would prefer to prepare a speech in criticism of Senator Faulkner than actually prepare to answer questions on the issues in her portfolio. That is extraordinarily disappointing.

I notice that the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Hill) has not bothered to defend her. He has run off and is only sticking his head through the door. He could not be bothered getting on to his hind legs, so he sent Senator Panizza, the whip, running over to see Eric—third, fourth or fifth bat; I am not sure—to get up and defend Senator Newman, rather than taking on that responsibility himself.

There are some issues that are very important that Senator Newman should have been concentrating on. One such issue is the disaster that has come about because of how this government has dealt with the issue of private health insurance. The fact is that private health insurance in this country has gone from bad to worse during the stewardship of this government. We have a situation where, even after the government has expended the sum of $600 million of public moneys, people are still paying the same level of premiums as they were before.

In fact, the Minister for Health and Family Services, Michael Wooldridge, admitted shortly after the budget that he was aware at the time of the budget that HBA—or National Mutual, as they also are known—had already put in an application for premium increases that would undermine and make valueless the moneys that were being spent to subsidise private health insurance. So the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) stepped in. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Patterson, Sen Kay

TALK.START.PARA: —I am actually very sad, because I have not seen anything like this in the nine years I have been in this chamber. When we were in opposition, we saw incompetent ministers sitting on this side of the House. There was one minister in particular, and I will not name that minister. But if one were to go back and read some of the answers that that person gave, one would see that they were none other than verbal fruit salad. Mr Deputy President, as psychologists, you and I know what it actually indicates when people produce verbal fruit salad. But we did not get up and carry on like this and take up the whole of the debate on taking note of answers with this issue when that minister was totally incapable of answering a question. Not only that; the answers were incomprehensible.

SPEECH.PARA: As for Senator Ray coming in here and mocking someone for using a malapropism, I find that just unbelievable. Constantly, people in this chamber use words incorrectly—like `fulsome' and all sorts of other words—especially in the heat of debate. A word can come out that is not quite the right one. We all do it. Senator Ray obviously would have done it at some time, but he came in here, in a most degrading way, and used that as some sort of indication that Senator Newman was not capable of doing her job.

Senator Faulkner said that Senator Newman did not have the right to take her pay. Senator Newman is not in the chamber at this very moment. Do you know what she is doing? She is launching a booklet to circulate around women's groups, which is one of her portfolios. In that booklet are details of all members of parliament from both sides of this house and from both sides of the House of Representatives. That booklet is designed so that people in the community—in particular women and women's groups—can have access to parliament. That was never done by a minister of the Labor government—never.

Senator Newman is doing her job in bringing parliament to the people and making it accessible to the members of the public—in particular, making women of this parliament accessible. She is launching that booklet. She has had it prepared, and we have all made contributions. In a non‐partisan way, she has ensured that there are Democrats, Independents, Labor, Liberal and National Party women represented in that booklet, as well as representatives from all the committees to which she could go.

Let me say something else, as the chairman of the government social security committee. I have been with Senator Newman when she has been out visiting regional offices. I have met people who have said, `I've worked in Social Security for 19 years and I have never seen a minister.' I have seen Senator Newman walk up to a counter of a regional office and have someone at the counter say, `Senator, it is outrageous. We have had people coming in here making a claim on this benefit to which they are not really entitled, saying that they have a disabled child. Yet there are people who come in here who really do have children with disabilities who are missing out.' Senator Newman is hearing what people are saying.

She has e-mail directed to her own office so that officers in regional offices—people at the coalface delivering the services—can e-mail her with concerns. There was a very simple one the other day when I was out with her. A person expressed a problem associated with people in nursing homes. The problem was that, when people go into respite care, they have to get the information to Social Security that they are now not a couple but are singles for the two weeks. If they do not get it in on time, they lose their benefit. I raised that with Senator Newman because it was raised with me as we were both going around, and I know that will be addressed. That is the sort of thing she is doing—going and listening to the people who are delivering the services. And her officers are responding.

Sick leave is dropping. When the opposition were in government, sick leave in Social Security increased from 10.3 days a year. The previous government got a two per cent productivity increase, and they said they were going to decrease sick leave to 8.3 days a year as part of their saving of $6 million. Out of their $12 million productivity increase, $6 million of it was going to come from reducing sick leave. But what happened after two years? Sick leave went up to 12.3 days a year and cost $6 million more.

Since Senator Newman has been the minister, sick leave has been going down. The Social Security officers are responding to her and responding to her leadership. We are also seeing savings being made with the reduction in fraudulent claims—another response to Senator Newman's innovations in the Department of Social Security. (Time expired)
