TALKER.NAME: Senator CAMPBELL
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to table a statement on behalf of the Minister for Sport, Territories and Local Government on Commonwealth policy on local government, to incorporate the statement in Hansard and to move a motion in respect of the statement and two related documents, the first entitled Commonwealth, Councils and Community—Looking Ahead: Commonwealth Policy on Local Government , and the second entitled Local Government National Report—1995‐96 (Financial Assistance) Act 1995 .

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The statement read as follows—
I table for the information of Honourable Members the first Local Government National Report and accompanying policy paper outlining the Commonwealth policy on local government.
Under the Local Government (Financial Assistance) Act 1995 the Federal Minister responsible for local government is required to report annually to Parliament on the operations of the Act.

This report is an important document aimed at improving the accountability of councils, encouraging council efficiency and effectiveness. It also makes the process of distributing Commonwealth grants to councils transparent.

Together with this first National Report, I am tabling a policy paper on local government, Commonwealth, Councils & Community—Looking Ahead, which challenges local government to take advantage of Commonwealth support and work together to advance good governance, good economic management and greater fairness in our community.
We would all agree that local government plays a key role in the well‐being of every Australian.

From Huon Valley to Minjilang, from Busselton to Cardwell, across Australia some 770 local councils provide leadership and services to their local communities. In total, local government expenditure exceeds $11 billion or some 5% of total government spending, and in 1995‐96 local councils employed some 155,000 people.

The services of local government are vital to businesses as well as to individuals. Local public works, recreation, public health, community services, building, planning and development approval, and cultural activities are just a few examples of services for which we rely on local councils.

Despite the diversity in councils, the central challenge for each is to provide the highest quality and widest range of services consistent with the needs and aspirations of its community and the resources available. This must be achieved within the provisions of relevant State and Territory legislation and regulation.

If Australia is to develop and prosper, all three spheres of government—Commonwealth, State and Territory and local, must play their part in establishing a framework of governance which allows individuals, families, business and communities to realise their potential and flourish.
To meet this challenge, councils must:
seek continuous improvement in all council activities;
identify and introduce new technologies or processes which can achieve quantum improvement in councils' operations or service delivery;
provide leadership in balancing the demands of the vocal against the views of the wider community; and
seek to broaden and deepen the council financial base to provide greater financial capacity and stability.
Many councils are taking up this challenge and this needs to be an ongoing process, as it is for other governments and the private sector.

While local government governance is primarily an issue for State and Territory governments and local councils themselves, the Commonwealth wishes to ensure that financial assistance to local government contributes to optimal community outcomes.

Most local councils derive the largest share of their revenue from property rates. Other sources of income generated by councils include charges for garbage collection, public services, housing and community services, economic services, health and community services, recreational and cultural amenities and charges associated with development activities. Total income from these sources, however, is generally not sufficient to fully finance councils' operations and provide an appropriate level of services to residents. Councils with small populations and a limited revenue base are often among the most stretched.

The Commonwealth provides significant financial assistance and program funding to local government. As a matter of good management, however, local councils should seek as far as possible to achieve financial security in their own right. This requires them to consolidate their revenue bases, explore alternative financing mechanisms and ensure that their administration and services are as affordable and efficient as possible.

In 1996‐97 the Commonwealth is contributing over $1.2 billion to increase the financial capacity of local councils and provide greater certainty in their funding. This represents an increase of four per cent over Commonwealth funding to local government in 1995‐96, an excellent result for local government in the light of the very difficult economic circumstances faced by the Government when it came to office.

The funding provided by the Commonwealth through financial assistance grants (FAGs) is a significant element in the budgets of individual local councils, ranging up to around half of their income in some cases, especially in remote areas. The overall contribution by FAGs to local government income is over ten per cent.

In keeping with the Local Government (Financial Assistance) Act the Government will initiate a review of local government financial assistance, to be carried out not later than 30 June 2001. This will be done in consultation with the States and Territories and local government.

An important purpose of the report being tabled today is to improve the transparency with which States and the Northern Territory Grants Commissions determine the distribution of financial assistance to councils within their jurisdictions. The information provided through this annual report will be valuable background for this planned review of FAGs.

The documents being tabled today review the existing position of councils but, importantly, also look to the future. Commonwealth, Councils & Community—Looking Ahead sets out a range of new initiatives. These are summarised in the policy paper but the main elements include:
training for council officers to enhance their skills to meet emerging policy and management challenges;

continuing support for the National Awards for Innovation in Local Government (NAILG), to promote excellence and innovation in local government activities and services. For the 1997 awards there is a reduced number of categories to encourage even higher quality applications and proposals;

the Government's response to the recommendations of the Small Business Deregulation Task Force that relate to local government. In consultation with the States, Territories and local government, I intend to provide support for the implementation of local government related recommendations;
cooperation with councils affected by the Sydney 2000 Games to facilitate their making the best possible use of opportunities provided by this unique event; and
continued support for benchmarking and continuous improvement initiatives.
I will be making more detailed announcements on these and the other initiatives early in the new year after discussions, including with State and local governments.
The initiatives outlined in Commonwealth, Councils and Community provide a framework for addressing the challenges facing local government.
I commend it and the National Report to Honourable Senators.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the statement and documents.
I seek leave to continue my remarks.
Leave not granted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Faulkner, Sen John

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —In relation to the issue of local government, I think I should commence my contribution on this issue by reinforcing that the Australian Labor Party has long considered local government as an institution that is very much underutilised and poorly protected in our national political system.

SPEECH.PARA: In fact, an historic partnership has existed between Labor and local government at the national level which has seen more than 20 years of reform to the role of, the funding of and the status of local government. It is also true to say that the relationship between local government and the Commonwealth really was never stronger than it was in the last years of the former Labor government. I believe that the advances to that point need not necessarily be lost because there was a change of government in March. Maintaining the relationship that has been established and improving the relationship that has been established certainly do provide a real challenge for us all.

The Working Nation white paper on employment and growth in 1993 brought together the Commonwealth and local authorities for, perhaps, the greatest ever expansion of intergovernmental relations in the history of Australian public administration. Working Nation, as I am sure you would appreciate, put in place the government infrastructure that was needed for regional economic decision making to be moved out of Canberra to the regions themselves where teams of local leaders, with the support, of course, of the Commonwealth, best identified strengths and weaknesses and also best identified how these should be addressed. It was Working Nation that put into place organisations which reported directly to the federal government on local matters.

TALK.START.PARA: —A very good paper, Working Nation .

—Indeed, Senator Carr. I might say that the regional development organisations, better known to all senators as RDOs, and the area consultative committees actually comprise local government representatives, employer groups, unions, local business leaders and education and training providers in many regions around the country.

SPEECH.PARA: RDOs and ACCs were responsible for the local allocation of Commonwealth money and for advising Canberra of local needs and of priorities. It is important that we acknowledge that this has meant that there was an unprecedented devolution of power from the Commonwealth to regional bodies, and it was largely based around existing alliances between local government authorities. I sincerely believe that Working Nation was a major turning point for intergovernmental relations in Australia, really with local government becoming a major player in the national economy.

What it also did, of course, was allow Canberra to draw back from the role of driving priorities. I am pleased to see that Senator Campbell is such a student of Working Nation that he keeps a copy handy. You, too, Senator Campbell, can partake of the wisdom that is contained within it.

TALK.START.PARA: —It's a shame it didn't work.
—It is a pity that some in your government do not take the close interest in Working Nation that you do. Perhaps a little chat with Senator Vanstone would not go astray.

SPEECH.PARA: We did have a situation where Canberra could draw back from the role of driving priorities and it allowed, as I have indicated, local leadership to do this within the policy framework. So part of the Working Nation commitment, as Senator Campbell knows only too well, was an array of labour market programs. They were aimed at assisting long‐term unemployed to gain relevant training and recent work experience. These programs, I believe, were extraordinarily successful, such as the landcare and environment action program.

TALK.START.PARA: —They've been cut.

—They have been cut, Senator Sherry. There was the landcare and environment action program, which is one from the previous environment minister—and I acknowledge the kind things that have been said in the chamber today about my stewardship of the portfolio, particularly by Senator Newman—and the new work opportunities program, which trained and employed young people on local projects.

SPEECH.PARA: The point I want to make is that these local government authorities were absolutely instrumental as sponsors of LEAP and new work opportunities projects around the country. For the first time in decades we had a situation where local government authorities were taking an active role in training and helping to find jobs for their own unemployed constituents. It also ought be placed on record that this was something that was undertaken with a considerable degree of success. It would be remiss of me—I am sure my colleagues would agree—if I did not note that the Liberal government has backed away from these strategies.

TALK.START.PARA: —The non‐core promises.

—The area consultative committees were frozen. The government has recently realised their value, and I suppose there is a bit of an effort occurring at the moment to try to defrost them. On the other hand, RDOs have had their funding cancelled. The budget that has been brought down—this vicious and vindictive budget by this callous and dishonest government—has cut around $1.8 billion from Working Nation, closing both the LEAP and the new work opportunities programs. I believe the government stands condemned for that.

SPEECH.PARA: The Commonwealth has closed the Office of Regional Development saying that there is no clear constitutional rationale for Commonwealth involvement in regional development. These issues really highlight the difference in commitment between Labor and the coalition on local government. We have the spectre of some audit commission recommendations, which this government has under active consideration, and they are of great concern to local government. On the part of the opposition—the Australian Labor Party—we will maintain and build those strong links that I was referring to. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: NATURAL HERITAGE TRUST OF AUSTRALIA BILL 1996

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Report of Environment, Recreation, Communications and the Arts Legislation Committee

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell, Sen Ian

TALKER.NAME: Senator CAMPBELL
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I present the government's response to the report of the Environment, Recreation, Communications and the Arts Legislation Committee on the Natural Heritage Trust of Australia Bill 1996. I seek leave to incorporate the response in Hansard and to move a motion in relation to the document.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The document read as follows—

PARA.EMPHASIS: Recommendation 1: That the Bill proceed, however, the Committee foreshadows amendments in the Committee of the Whole.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government agrees that the Bill should proceed, and notes that the Committee foreshadows amendments in the Committee of the Whole.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Recommendation 2: That the words `Board' and `Trust' be changed or greater explanation be given in the Bill of the parliamentary accountability arrangements and the roles of the various Ministers.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government notes the Committee's concern that the use of the name `Board' to describe the partnership of administration between the Ministers for the Environment and Primary Industries and Energy may convey the impression of a body less subject to parliamentary scrutiny. The details provided below clearly show that this is not the case, as the decisions of the Board and the financial transactions of the Trust will be subject to normal Parliamentary scrutiny and accountability arrangements. However, to avoid confusion about the role of the Board and to make it clear that this is a Ministerial body, the Government will propose an amendment to the Bill to change the name to `Natural Heritage Ministerial Board'.
The Bill already includes clauses which ensure parliamentary accountability and provide opportunities for parliamentary scrutiny in the same way and to the same degree as other Government agencies:

Clause 33 provides that the Minister for the Environment must cause to be prepared an annual report which includes, but is not limited to, a report about the operations of the Trust during the relevant financial year, financial statements relating to those operations and the Auditor-General's report on the financial statement (cl. 33(1)).
The report on the operations of the Trust during the relevant financial year and the financial statements must comply with written guidelines issued by the Minister for Finance (cls 33(2) and 33(3)).

Clause 34 provides that the financial statements must be given to the Auditor-General for examination and report. The Auditor-General is required to state whether the financial statements had been prepared in accordance with the Finance Minister's guidelines and whether they give a true and fair view of the matters required by those guidelines (cl. 34(3)). Consistent with the requirement that Departmental Annual Reports are prepared prior to Senate Estimates Committee hearings, the Annual Report on the operation of the Trust will also be prepared in a timely manner.
The annual report must be laid before each House of the Parliament within 15 sitting days of that House after the completion of the preparation of the report (cl.33(4)).
The Minister for Primary Industries and Energy must give the Minister for the Environment such information as will allow the latter to comply with the reporting provisions of the Reserve (cl.33.(5)).

Parliamentary scrutiny of the Trust will also be possible in a number of other ways. The consolidated revenue funds which will flow into the Trust, for example, will be able to be scrutinised in the normal way by Parliament. Details will be reported in the Budget context via the Portfolio Budget Statements which are Budget Related Papers tabled in both Houses. Trust expenditure will also be subject to normal Senate Estimates scrutiny.

To facilitate this scrutiny Environment Australia and the Department of Primary Industries and Energy have offered to appear together at Senate Estimates hearings, so that the Senators can address any questions under the heading of the Natural Heritage Trust with relevant officers from both Departments present.

As a result of the above provisions already in the Bill and the opportunities for Parliamentary scrutiny, the Government does not believe it is necessary to include further detail on parliamentary accountability arrangements in the Bill itself, or change the name of the Trust. The Government will, however, provide further details in the explanatory memorandum to explain these arrangements and address the Committee's concerns.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Recommendation 3:
3.1 That the two Ministers responsible for the Environment and Primary Industries Portfolios comprise the two-person Board

SPEECH.PARA: The Government agrees with this recommendation.

PARA.EMPHASIS: 3.2 That the Minister responsible for the Environment Portfolio be chair of that Board

SPEECH.PARA: The Government does not believe there is anything to be gained from nominating a chair of a two person Board. As the Minister responsible for the Natural Heritage Trust legislation, the Minister for the Environment has ultimate responsibility to Parliament for the Natural Heritage Trust.

The Memorandum of Understanding between Environment Australia and the Department of Primary Industries and Energy establishes the Secretary of Environment Australia as the secretary to the Ministerial Board.

PARA.EMPHASIS: 3.3 that an Advisory Panel consisting of about 8 experts be established to advise the Board and assess proposals for funding

SPEECH.PARA: The Government is committed to ensuring a strong emphasis on community participation in priority setting and program implementation for the Trust initiatives, and will ensure that the Trust's advisory structures reflect this commitment.

The Ministerial Board will receive expert advice across the range of Trust initiatives from the full gamut of interested groups already represented on existing advisory bodies (including the statutory National Landcare Advisory Committee (NLAC) which reports to both Ministers on natural resource management issues, the Biological Diversity Advisory Committee (BDAC), the Murray-Darling Basin Community Advisory Council (MDBCAC), the Endangered Species Advisory Committee (ESAC)), and also from the new Council for Sustainable Vegetation Management (CSVM). Community project assessment procedures will be transparent and apply through regional and State panels.

The Government is also committed to the principle of encouraging devolution of funding and decision making to the lowest practicable level, consistent with maintaining sound environmental, natural resource management and sustainable agriculture outcomes subject to proper accountability and national priorities being addressed.

The Government believes that the establishment of an additional Advisory Panel, as proposed by the Committee, would be inconsistent with this principle and would duplicate the existing and proposed new advisory mechanisms outlined above, some of which have existing statutory responsibilities. The establishment of the Panel would also conflict with the Government's commitment to streamline project funding processes, by adding another level of project assessment.

PARA.EMPHASIS: 3.4 that as far as possible, and if appropriate, the existing specific purpose advisory councils should be retained and be a source of advice to the Panel if necessary

SPEECH.PARA: The Government will retain the existing, specific purpose advisory bodies as outlined above, but as a source of advice to the Ministerial Board, rather than the Panel.

PARA.EMPHASIS: 3.5 However, Departments should take this opportunity to examine these and other advisory structures, to streamline them and to ensure that duplication is avoided

SPEECH.PARA: The Government agrees that advisory arrangements for the Natural Heritage Trust should be as streamlined as possible and should avoid duplication. The Departments have been examining existing and proposed arrangements in this context, and also to ensure that advisory bodies have the relevant expertise to cover the full range of issues addressed by the Natural Heritage Trust.

PARA.EMPHASIS: 3.6 That the Departments should as a matter of urgency, streamline their administrative processes and co-ordinate with other funding organisations (such as State Departments) to simplify the funding/submission process and ensure that any system is flexible enough to address unforseen changes in priorities or methods

SPEECH.PARA: In the statement `Investing in Our Natural Heritage', Senator the Hon Robert Hill said "We will develop integrated approaches to minimise the number of separate programs and consequent paper warfare." The Government agrees that administrative processes should be streamlined and is currently undertaking a consultation process with States/Territories, community and non-government organisation representatives on proposed management arrangements for Trust programs. The aim is to ensure that delivery of programs is organised so as to ensure that natural resource management, sustainable agriculture and nature conservation programs are complementary; that the interface between these programs and the community is straightforward; and that public funding is directed to catalytic, strategic investments in natural capital with clearly identified and measurable outcomes.

The aim is to have the streamlined arrangements in place so that projects can be funded in the 1997-98 financial year, recognising that a lead time of some six months is needed for such grants programs between the time applications are sought and announcements of funding are made by Ministers.

One of the principles which will underpin the delivery of the Natural Heritage Trust package is that, as far as practicable, interaction between local communities and government bureaucracies in relation to Trust programs should be simple, readily understood and based on the "one-stop-shop" concept.

PARA.EMPHASIS: 3.7 The Bill should include a reference to the type of advisory structures which will be put in place by the Departments and their roles and responsibilities and that separate regulations should contain the role of the Advisory Panel, the tenure of members etc.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government does not believe it is necessary to include details of advisory structures in the Bill, as most of the advisory bodies are already established by other legislation (eg. NLAC, MDBCAC, & ESAC), while others (eg. CSVM) are intended to be non-statutory, expert bodies.
This issue of the proposed Advisory Panel is addressed under Recommendation 3.3.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Recommendation 4: That the Bill explicitly state the Minister responsible for the Environment Portfolio's primacy as Chair of the Board and the relative roles and responsibilities of each Department.

SPEECH.PARA: Given that the Environment Minister is responsible for the Bill and subsequent administration of the Act, and that the Trust is domiciled in Environment Australia (which is responsible for reporting on Trust operations), the Government does not believe it is necessary to explicitly state the Environment Minister's primacy by making the Minister Chair of the Ministerial Board.

The Government does not consider it is appropriate to specify the relative roles and responsibilities of each Department in legislation. This is an administrative matter which will be handled in the Memorandum of Understanding (MOU) between the two Departments. The MOU will establish the framework within which Environment Australia and DPIE will work cooperatively towards common and complementary environmental natural resource management and sustainable agriculture outcomes. It will clarify respective roles and responsibilities and ensure a coordinated approach to management of Trust initiatives through agreed operational principles and interdepartmental coordinating structures. The MOU will be available from Departments once it is signed.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Recommendation 5: That the Bill include broad goals and objectives in the environmental areas—Vegetation, Rivers, Biodiversity, Landcare, Coasts and Clean Seas, and Atmospheric Issues, to enable the Bill to respond to changes in priorities and that the Government give consideration to full description of the five capital projects in a portfolio statement. Such a statement could be made annually to inform the community on achievements and any changes in priorities.

SPEECH.PARA: The Bill already includes the primary objectives of the five capital programs to be funded from the Trust (clauses 10—14).

The Government believes that to expand this to include broad goals and objectives in the key environmental and natural resource management areas listed above may actually restrict the ability of the Trust to respond to changes in priorities, as any activities to be funded in the future would have to meet the goals and objectives identified now to be legally eligible for funding.

The Bill essentially establishes a repository for funds. The details of the activities to be funded are set out in the Government's policy statements relating to the Trust. These will form the basis of program guidelines.

The Government believes the Bill already provides the flexibility for the Trust to adapt to changes in environmental priorities. In particular, clause 15 defines the type of activities that can be funded under the environmental protection purpose of the Bill (clause 8(f)). The definition is broad enough to ensure that the wide range of activities necessary to achieve the objective of protecting and rehabilitating Australia's natural environment can be undertaken with funds from the Trust.

The five capital projects have already been described in the Statement by the Minister for the Environment on 20 August 1996, `Investing in our Natural Heritage'. The Committee's recommendation that a statement could be made annually to inform the community on achievements and any changes in priorities will be addressed in the context of the Trust's Annual Report as required under clause 33 of the Bill. In addition, the Government will prepare an annual whole-of-Government Budget Paper to identify the total Commonwealth expenditure on the environment across all Portfolios and agencies. This will be produced for the first time in the 1997-98 budget, and will include information on Natural Heritage Trust programs.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Recommendation 6: That the Bill include reference to atmospheric issues, exotic pests, feral animals and weeds, international treaties, education and training.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government does not believe that specific reference to these issues in the Bill is necessary as the environmental protection clause is broad enough to enable Trust funding to be provided in these areas. However, the Government will provide further information in the Explanatory Memorandum to explain the full range of programs intended to be funded through the Trust.

It should also be noted that the Trust is not the sole source of funds for the Government's environment, natural resource management and sustainable agriculture programs, and many activities will continue to be funded through normal budgetary processes.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Recommendation 7: That the Government address funding for Australia's Built Heritage as a matter of priority.

SPEECH.PARA: The prime purpose of the Trust is to ensure a strategic and integrated delivery of the Commonwealth biodiversity conservation and sustainable agriculture programs. However, the Government also recognises that the built heritage is an important component of Australia's heritage.

The Government has therefore made a commitment to develop a national policy on heritage places. This initiative is identified in the Australian Heritage Commission's Discussion Paper "A National Future for Australia's Heritage", as a matter for further consultation and development with the community, conservation groups, industry, and State and Territory Governments. Funding for Australia's built heritage will be addressed in the development of this policy.

The Government is also committed to refocussing the National Estate Grants Program to concentrate on projects of national importance. The revised program will assist projects that help identify, conserve and promote nationally important heritage places; seminal studies that develop methodologies or policies for heritage issues of national relevance; model studies, plans or projects which can serve as examples of best practice; and projects that encourage and facilitate community involvement in heritage activities.
It is anticipated that these funds will be directed primarily towards historic and indigenous heritage projects, given other funding initiatives proposed under the Natural Heritage Trust.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Recommendation 8: That the Government should consider whether gifts and bequest funds should be attracted by the fund and if so whether a more appropriate vehicle for handling such funds (perhaps a separate highly visible account and administration Board) should be established; and that if gifts and bequests are retained, the Bill should include reference to those of a certain amount being tax deductible; and that a watch be kept on the matter of gifts and bequests to ensure that funds are not attracted away from community-based groups.

SPEECH.PARA: For gifts (other than testamentary gifts/bequests) to the Natural Heritage Trust to be made tax deductible, it would appear necessary to amend section 78 of the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936 (ITAA) to specifically list the Trust as an eligible gift recipient. Deductibility for testamentary gifts/bequests raises separate issues, given that such gifts made to organisations listed in section 78 are not currently deductible.

The Government will give careful consideration to the question of tax deductibility, bearing in mind a number of factors, such as the importance of the Trust in the Government's environment policy, the Government's general policy of not amending section 78, and the potential cost to revenue.
The Government will monitor the impacts of the gifts and bequests clause on community based groups.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Recommendation 9:
9.1 That the Bill should include measures to account for improvements as a result of expenditure programs against base level data and objectives

SPEECH.PARA: The Government agrees that Natural Heritage Trust funding should result in improvements against base level data and objectives. The Government will seek to achieve this through the comprehensive Partnership Agreements to be developed between the Commonwealth and each State and Territory. These Agreements will specify respective rights and responsibilities, and encourage devolution of funding and decision making to the lowest practicable level consistent with maintaining sound environmental outcomes. The Agreements will include a description of the outcomes to be achieved over an agreed time frame, against which reporting will be required.

The National Land and Water Resources Audit, to be funded from the Trust, the State of the Environment Report, and other processes will establish many of the biophysical (and in some cases socio-economic) benchmarks and indicators against which progress can be measured. These will be developed in consultation with states and territories.

PARA.EMPHASIS: 9.2 That the Bill includes measures to ensure that no project receives funding where the existing regulations will work against achievement of the Trust's goals

SPEECH.PARA: The Government agrees that in order for Trust funds to be used effectively it is desirable that there are no Commonwealth, state/territory or local government policies or legislative programs in place which will mitigate against the achievement of the Trust's objectives. The Government intends working cooperatively with states/territories, through the Partnership Agreements and existing consultative mechanisms such as the Australia and New Zealand Environment and Conservation Council (ANZECC) and the Agriculture and Resource Management Council of Australia and New Zealand (ARMCANZ), to pursue this goal.
Recognising that this goal can only be achieved over time, and through cooperative arrangements, the Government does not believe it is appropriate to include such measures in legislation.

PARA.EMPHASIS: 9.3 That the Bill has as an objective, that the Commonwealth will work actively toward uniform or complementary legislation in the environment field

SPEECH.PARA: The Trust is designed to support common and complementary environmental natural resource management and sustainable agriculture outcomes, through cooperative arrangements between all levels of government. The Commonwealth Government will be encouraging the development of state/territory legislative programs which contribute to the achievement of these complementary outcomes, while at the same time moving to ensure that there are no legislative programs in place that will mitigate against the achievement of the Trust's objectives. Consistent with the Government's commitment to developing a cooperative approach to achieve the Trust goals, this will be pursued through the Partnership Agreements and through existing consultative mechanisms such as ANZECC and ARMCANZ.

PARA.EMPHASIS: 10: That the matter of needs-based funding be brought to the attention of the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government notes the argument put forward by the Tasmanian representatives that funding from the Trust should be based on priority need.

Allocations from the Trust to individual States will be determined as program objectives and priorities are further developed, and will vary between programs, depending on the purpose of the program and the nature of the problems to be addressed, consistent with policies set out in Saving Our Natural Heritage, Reviving the Heartland and Sustainable Agriculture.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carr, Sen Kim

TALK.START.PARA: —The Natural Heritage Trust of Australia Bill 1996 is a very clear example of the way in which a government develops a matrix of deceit and chicanery. It is of supreme disappointment to us that sequacious elements within this parliament—
—What elements?
—Salacious?

—Sequacious. I am sure you know what that is. I am sure you would be right on top of that. What disturbs me is that, as I indicated earlier this day, this government has embarked upon a fundamental fraud on the Australian people with this measure. We have expected a few basic principles in the way money is distributed in this country as a result of this parliament's deliberations. Under a Labor government, people got very high standards, but with this government we have an entirely different set of circumstances.

SPEECH.PARA: We would expect some transparency in the way in which money is distributed. We would expect some device of parliamentary accountability. We would expect the moneys to be distributed in accordance with the normal constitutional provisions, that is, on a non‐discriminatory, non‐preferential basis. Section 99 of the constitution is very clear on this point.

What have we found? The normal provision of no discrimination against states or against regions within states is not being followed by this government. With this measure and the very sleazy, shady arrangements in this Telstra bill, money is being distributed—

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, on a point of order: the motion before the Senate is to take note of the government's response to the report of the legislation committee on the natural heritage trust bill. If Senator Carr cared to read the report of that committee—a committee I served on and Senator Schacht served on—he would firstly notice that Senator Schacht actually signed the report. The report does not deal with Telstra, and nor does the government's response. I ask you to ask Senator Carr to be relevant to the motion before the chair.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: FAULKNER

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, on the point of order: Senator Carr was developing a matrix of arguments on this report. I identify Senator Campbell's point of order as a spurious one, probably deliberately intended to interrupt the flow of the argument that Senator Carr was developing. It is a long bow to suggest the matters that Senator Carr was addressing are not relevant to the report before the Senate, because every single senator, even Senator Campbell, is well aware of the implications of this important report on a matter of public policy that the government has given a great deal of priority to in deliberations before the Senate.

INTERJECT.PARA: So I would ask you, Mr Deputy President, to rule this point of order out of order. I would also believe it appropriate for you, Mr Deputy President, to suggest that the Manager of Government Business, who really should know better, not take spurious points of order. TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I take the point of order seriously but I do believe that Senator Carr is developing an argument and will speak to the matter before the chair.
—Mr Deputy President, on a further point of order: do the clocks stop for points of order in this particular session? I know they do in some sessions.
—The clocks did.

—They did, but should they have? I thought that was not the rule. The only reason I raise the point of order is I thought that Senator Faulkner was so embarrassed by what his colleague was saying that he was trying to take up his time so that he would have less time to embarrass himself and the opposition. I just want to try to help Senator Faulkner by making sure the clocks go on if that is the ruling of the Senate.
—It has been the practice to stop the clocks for points of order. The provisions do differentiate between certain debates. I will look at the matter for the future.

—Mr Deputy President, on a further point of order: I accept that Senator Ian Macdonald in part was trying to make a serious point, though I believe he was really basically making a polemical point. But I am surprised, Mr Deputy President, that you recognised Senator Macdonald, who rose to take a point of order while not in his seat in the chamber—or as a newly appointed secretary awarded the position for crawling, he may well have taken a point of order from a frontbench seat. I do not believe he should have been recognised by you in taking a point of order from where he is sitting in the chamber.

—I certainly was aware of that. But I was also aware of the fact that I did not know whether there were some special considerations which allowed Senator Macdonald to be where he was. So I erred on the side of accepting his point of order.
—Thank you, Mr Deputy President.
—On with the matrix.

—That is right. I was referring to the matrix of deceit, Senator Campbell. Given the sequacious way in which you have responded this afternoon, it is clear that this government is demonstrably engaged in a `policy of blatant, cynical fraud', as a recent article pointed out quoting a senior minister. The deceit was described as `sickening'.

BREAK.PARA: This government is embarking upon a policy of funding various projects on the basis of special treatment to attract support for the privatisation of Telstra. Special amounts of money have been used to fund projects in Tasmania and Queensland. Recently, we saw this example followed in pork‐barrelling in Western Australia in regard to salinity.

I simply ask: is this not the sort of action that is likely to provoke a constitutional challenge? There does appear to be a prima facie case that the administration of moneys under this proposed trust is being presented to us in a discriminatory manner in that preferential treatment is being given to particular states and particular regions within states. There is an opportunity here to actually spend money in a way that takes away parliamentary and budgetary accountability. It should be resisted by this parliament and it ought to be resisted by all senators within this parliament.

The proposed trust fund will involve restrictions on the level of parliamentary scrutiny. It will involve the delegation of parliamentary responsibilities to a trust fund. But the committee report clearly indicates that there are serious deficiencies in the composition of the trust board, the inherent rigidities in the trust fund allocations and in the range of recurrent initiatives which are in fact capital expenditure.

Quite clearly, a discriminatory policy is being followed by this government for blatant political reasons. This government presented itself to the Australian people prior to the election as the defenders of the environment. Now, after the election, the opposite policy is being pursued. Before the election, there was a commitment that they would spend more on the environment; after the election, there are cuts to environmental programs of some 13 per cent. Before the election, we saw commitments to the environment; after the election, we saw proposals to establish a fund for purposes which should be funded directly out of the budget, out of consolidated revenue.

There is no excuse for the establishment of this fund, other than the blatant ransom that is being demanded in terms of the blackmail associated with the privatisation of Telstra. There is an extricable link between those two propositions.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why did you fund social security by selling Qantas?
—There is no way that this mean‐spirited, callous and, I think, discriminatory government can be allowed to get away with this. It ought to be exposed at every possible turn.
—You sold Qantas to pay for welfare payments.

—Measures ought to be funded directly out of consolidated revenue without the privatisation of what is the most valuable of all public assets. It is an asset that is in fact too valuable to sell, an asset which ought to belong to—and remain in the ownership of—all Australians.
—You didn't say that on the Commonwealth Bank. Where were you on the Commonwealth Bank?

—I raise a point of order, Madam Deputy President. I bring to your attention the continual disruptions we are getting from Senator Campbell. He is filibustering by interjection and it is an outrageous approach, an outrageous contempt of the Senate chamber. I ask you to bring him to order.

—Madam Deputy President, I raise a further point of order. You saw me sitting here during a debate earlier this day and you very calmly sat there and, in your own way, tried to maintain some order while Senator Carr and his other mates continually interjected. Senator Carr, in particular, ceaselessly interjected and ignored your rulings. I will cease interjecting now, but I draw your attention to the gross hypocrisy of some of those people on the other side.
—There is disorder on both sides. I would appreciate it if order was maintained on both sides of the chamber. Senator Carr, you may continue directing your remarks to the chair.

—The natural heritage trust bill that this government is seeking to have passed by this parliament is nothing short of a 25‐page ransom note. It is the device for the delivery of the blackmail on the privatisation of Telstra. It is flawed from beginning to end. It is flawed on the grounds that it is proposing to spend moneys in a manner that is not publicly accountable. It is flawed in so far as it seeks to spend money without appropriate transparency. It is flawed because the proposed method by which money is spent will be discriminatory—on the basis of pork‐barrelling in particular regions of Australia. It will involve discrimination against other Australians as a result. There will be favourable treatment of some Australians at the expense of other Australians.

BREAK.PARA: Senator Campbell seeks to misrepresent the opposition on this matter. In the report, the opposition and Democrat senators stated:

. . . although they were in agreement with the general thrust of the report, in its consideration of the operation of the proposed Natural Heritage Trust Fund, their consideration of the Fund cannot be taken in any way as support for the Government's proposal to fund the Trust from the partial privatisation of Telstra.

Your government senators signed up to the proposition in this report that serious flaws had been identified by the committee in terms of the potential for the trust fund to restrict parliamentary scrutiny over an important area of Commonwealth expenditure, the manner of the composition of the trust board, the inherent rigidity of trust funds and the reference to a range of recurrent initiatives as capital expenditure. Senator, I ask you to read the report.

TALK.START.PARA: —Read the response.

—You will be very surprised indeed. I would suggest finally, Senator Campbell, that you read section 99 of the constitution while you are at it. While you are engaged with your sleazy little deals to stitch together alliances to put together the privatisation of Telstra, bear that in mind and also bear in mind what sort of legal action is likely to be provoked as a result of the arrangements this government has entered into in the last 24 hours.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —At the time of the election, this Natural Heritage Trust Fund was meant to get the Democrats and the Greens to vote with the government on the flogging off of Telstra to the private sector. But that did not work. It netted two Independents instead. While the Greens and Democrats could see it for what it was—a slush fund for environmental purposes in various states and not germane to the real responsibility of this government to legislate, to adequately fund from consolidated revenue for the protection of the environment—the Independents have apparently been drawn in.

SPEECH.PARA: A committee was set up to look at the proposed legislation for the establishment of a Natural Heritage Trust of Australia, which will have something like $1 billion to disburse over the next few years. That committee has made a series of recommendations. What we are discussing here is the government's response to those recommendations.

To sum it up, the government has simply brushed them all off. It is as if the committee has wasted its time. It might have saved the money. The report from that committee at first put its thumb on the real fault in this so-called Natural Heritage Trust Fund, and that is that it sets up a board to determine where $200 million, $300 million or $400 million a year is going to be spent repairing the Australian environment. It calls itself a board. Most people would think that when you have a board you have a series of people with expert skills who will be able to expertly decide both the priorities for the spending of that money and then how best to spend it.

But nothing of the kind. We have two ministers, self-appointed under this legislation, calling themselves a board. It is a sham. We have the minister for cutting down trees and digging up things from the House of Representatives, Mr Anderson, and in here the minister for stonewalling against any attempts to protect the environment but going under the name of the Minister for the Environment, Senator Hill. These two people are going to sit together and determine the fortunes of Australia's environment and in particular the money from the sale of Telstra, which is supposed to be put across to the protection of the environment.

What we have found already, what we have heard already today in the Senate, is that it is not going to be determined on environmental priorities; it is going to be determined on political pressuring. Already we are seeing the influence of the Independents, not least Senator Harradine, in being able to determine where that money goes.

I might call into question Senator Harradine's expertise in approaching this so-called board to determine where the environment might benefit from the spending of moneys. This is the same Senator Harradine who, as I said earlier today in this House, used his influence in the flooding of Lake Pedder, who stood aside, to put the best tilt on it, as the Franklin River was put up for destruction and who has actively worked over decades now for the destruction of Tasmania's world heritage, national estate and nationally significant forests and wildlife, including rainforests and the tall eucalypt forests, which are the tallest flowering plants on the face of the planet. This is the man who is having mega‐influence on this government's disbursement of what are public funds.

The board idea says that the committee should be looked at again. Would it not be better if, instead of having these two ministers—who, prior to their entry into this place, at best had no environmental expertise at all—you had a range of people who were the brains trust of Australia, if you like, in how best to spend what meagre funds there are available in trying to repair the enormous damage done to Australia's environment by past malpractice? `No', says the government. `We are not going to take that recommendation. We want to keep our fingers on the purse strings to this slush fund.'

It is nothing more or less than that. So they turn down the first and most important recommendation, which is to try to get this money, which is being set up under patent political favouritism and influence buying, out of the arena of political favouritism and influence buying. And the government says straight up, `No, we will not have a bar of that.' Of course it is not going to have a bar of it.

PARA.BREAK: Then there is a series of recommendations from the Senate committee about how the expertise of Australia's environmental experts might be used, put in various ways to the government. What is the government's re sponse? It says, and I quote—and I think this has to be done tongue in cheek:

SPEECH.PARA: The government is committed to the principle of encouraging devolution of funding and decision making to the lowest practicable level.

Well, they have got it. They have got Senator Hill and they have got Minister Anderson. They have devolved it to the lowest practicable level at the outset. That is where they want to keep it. They do not want to elevate it to expert import—not on your life. They want to keep it in their own hands. Shame on this government that this committee ever sat and challenged it, because all it has ended up doing is wasting public money.

I could go into the other recommendations made by the committee. Without exception, the government has turned them down. It has said: `We are not going to be influenced by a Senate committee. This is political decision making. It is not about the environment. It is not about delivering to the Australian people good value for their money. It is about us politically determining how to get Telstra into the marketplace, out of the hands of the Australian people and into the hands of the select and wealthy few who can line their pockets with the profits coming from it in the years ahead. At the same time it is a sweetener which was necessary back at election time. We will set up this Natural Heritage Trust Fund because it is going to make us look a little green and it might make the Democrats and the Greens squirm a little in the meantime.'

That ploy did not work. No-one over here is squirming. There is a lot of outrage and the ability to see this slush fund for what it is. But as I said earlier, it did unfortunately net a couple of Independents, including the new green guru from Tasmania, Senator Harradine. I do not think the environment is going to get much value out of his advice. I do not think the government is going to do any better in the future because clearly it is not interested in getting proper environmental advice; it is interested in getting political favours and kudos out of this in other ways.

At the end of this, there is this government response to the recommendation from the committee that the matter of needs-based funding be brought to the attention of the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories:
The Government notes the argument put forward by the Tasmanian representatives that funding from the Trust should be based on priority need.

Allocations from the Trust to individual States will be determined as program objectives and priorities are further developed, and will vary between programs, depending on the purpose of the program and the nature of the problems to be addressed, consistent with policies set out in Saving Our Natural Heritage , Reviving the Heartland and Sustainable Agriculture .

We have a lot of words there. All that means is that we do not need to look at needs-based funding for the various states and territories. We do not want the arguments that environments in some areas are more in need of spending than environments elsewhere. We want to keep totally under political control the disbursement of these funds, regardless of what the environment needs.

I return to a point made by a previous speaker. This fund is tiddlywinks compared to the huge job of repairing the vast damage done to Australia's soils, vegetation, biodiversity, coastlines and urban areas in the last two centuries. The government has to do better than this. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak on this government response to the report on the Natural Heritage Trust of Australia Bill 1996 prepared by the Senate Environment, Recreation, Communications and the Arts Legislation Committee, of which I was a member. First of all, I refer again to the report, which makes it very clear in paragraph 1.5 that the opposition and Democrat members of the committee, in dealing with the actual legislation before the legislative committee, in no way could be taken as supporting the principal position put by the government for the sale of Telstra to fund the environment issues contained in the government's policy. That is stated clearly in paragraph 1.5. Once we had stated that, the committee members did deal with specific issues. But we should in no way be taken as having weakened in our absolute opposition to the sale of Telstra to pay for the environment or any other policy programs.

BREAK.PARA: I have just had a quick glance at the government's response. After that disclaimer, the committee's recommendations were unanimous. The recommendations by the coalition, Labor and Democrat senators on the detail of the bill and its administration were unanimous. Government members supported them. However, in the government's response, I note that on several occasions the government has rejected these unanimous recommendations in detail. They have accepted that the words `board' and `trust' be changed and that it will now be called the Natural Heritage Ministerial Board.

However, they have rejected that the Minister for the Environment be the chair. They have rejected that a proper advisory panel of about eight experts from a wide range of backgrounds should advise the two ministers who make up the board. They have rejected that out of hand and will rely on a hotchpotch of other committees, which means that there will be no coherent advice going to the ministers. I suspect that the ministers want that. There is a rejection of needs-based funding, which is contained in recommendation No. 10. It states:
. . . that the matter of needs-based funding be brought to the attention of the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories.
That has been slipped away from. The government response states:
Allocations from the Trust to individual States will be determined as program objectives and priorities are further developed.

Generally, the government has slipped away from most of the important recommendations. This raises the issue of the sincerity of this government in how it is going to use the Natural Heritage Trust and the proceeds from the one-third sale of Telstra.

This report became irrelevant today when the Minister for Communications and the Arts (Senator Alston) announced in the Senate at the end of the second reading debate on the privatisation of Telstra that he was making further adjustments to the program and that further arrangements had been taken to suit particular conditions applied by Senator Harradine and Senator Colston. Senator Harradine wanted more money for Tasmania. As a Tasmanian senator, one can understand that that is an issue he would be pushing. Another $100 million would be going to the Natural Heritage Trust to take account of Tasmania's special needs. That is what we think it needs.

No detail was given by the minister today of how that extra $100 million will be allocated, such as whether it will be all for Tasmania or allocated on a priority basis for other issues around Australia. It was left wide open. There was no commitment to write as an amendment into the privatisation bill the programs that would be funded from the extra $100 million.

Again, it raises the whole issue that this has been a political fix. The government has negotiated a political fix in this outcome to take account of how to get a majority vote through the Senate against the principal opposition by the Labor Party, the Democrats and the Greens, who have always said that the environment is too important to be tied to the outcome of an assets sale. You do not tie the funding of defence to the outcome of an assets sale. You do not tie the funding of health, education or community welfare to the outcome of an assets sale. However, apparently the environment is tied to the outcome of an assets sale.

We have also seen today that the commitment for the extra $100 million is probably over four years. What happens after that? Will the government want to sell more than one-third of Telstra, or will there be a rapid decline after four years in the funding of the environment by this government if the government is still in place in four years? They are relevant questions that we in the opposition will still ask Senator Harradine and Senator Colston to look at. This funding arrangement is only for four years from the proceeds.

The remaining $300 million, even on the government's generous estimate of earning 10 per cent in the trust for ever and a day thereafter, means that, at the most, it would earn $30 million per year. There is no way that you can fund all the environmental needs of this country from $30 million per year. Substantial general revenue would have to be spent to meet the environmental needs of this country, which all Australians would support.

There is no mention in the government's policy about how they will raise the rest of that money after four years to supplement the measly $30 million a year. That is all left unsaid. The government believes that, by expending about $700 million over the next four years from the sale of Telstra, all the environmental problems in Australia will be fixed and that, subsequent to that, $30 million a year on the investment of $300 million will suffice for all the rest. In all of the hearings we had on this heritage bill, when we asked experts, `Do you believe that in four years there will still be demand for expenditure of hundreds of millions of dollars for overcoming the environmental problems of this country?', every expert of any credibility said, `You will need an ongoing program of increasing proportions, increasing size'—not diminishing—`to meet these commitments.'

For example, when we dealt with the issue of the salinity and the vegetation on the Murray-Darling Basin, all the experts said that, with the of money coming out of the natural vegetation program and the salinity program, the problem could not be dealt with and solved within the next four years. That would just be the beginning. They said that we were talking about decades of expenditure to overcome the soil degradation, the salinity problems, in the Murray-Darling Basin.

We have also had exposed in the last few days a letter from the Premier of Western Australia to the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) saying, `Further to our conversation in early November, you have agreed to give us $300 million at $30 million a year for the next 10 years to overcome salinity problems in Western Australia and that will be paid out of the Telstra fund.' All the money has already been committed. Is this $300 million on top of the billion or the now $1.1 billion and $350 million? Is another $300 million going on the top? That has all been left unsaid, all left unannounced, other than in a very broad application.

As I said today in the first part of the committee stage of the Telstra sale bill, I am astonished that a wily old campaigner like Senator Harradine would agree to allow the bill to go through without insisting that the increased money for Tasmania, the regional development of infrastructure for telecommunications, would be other than written into the bill to guarantee that it is achieved and that if he is so keen on the redeemable preference share that would not also be written into the bill. Surely he would have ensured that if he had felt so strongly about it, rather than having it referred to a committee, with the government not proclaiming the bill until after the committee reported. The government will proclaim the bill; it will chuck his report straight into the bin and it will take no notice of it. Once the government gets the bill through on the third reading, there is no way it will in any way hold it up by waiting for a Senate committee report. They will go ahead immediately and consign to Senator Harradine's waste bin of history his idea of redeemable preference shares. The government's response is a very mediocre response indeed. (Time expired)

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: National Capital and External Territories Committee

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brownhill, Sen David

TALKER.NAME: Senator BROWNHILL
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Trade and Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the government's response to the report of the Joint Committee on the National Capital and External Territories on Draft Amendment No. 14 (Broadacre Areas) to the National Capital Plan. I seek leave to incorporate the document in Hansard and to move a motion in relation to the document.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The response read as follows—

PARA.EMPHASIS: Background

SPEECH.PARA: On 10 November 1994, the Hon Brian Howe MP, then Minister for Housing and Regional Development, wrote to the Joint Standing Committee on the National Capital and External Territories inviting the committee to inquire into, and report on, Draft Amendment No. 14 to the National Capital Plan. The committee accepted the reference and tabled its report in October 1995.

Draft Amendment No. 14 refers to an area of land bounded by Oaks Estate, the ACT‐NSW border, Canberra Avenue and the Molonglo River Corridor. The area is included in the Broadacre Areas described in the National Capital Plan.

In general, the National Capital Plan does not permit industry as a land use in Broadacre Areas. However, the Canberra Tannery and Canberra Abattoir and Queanbeyan Sewage Treatment Plant were already operating there when the National Capital Plan came into operation in December 1990.

The National Capital Plan specifies a range of permitted land uses in Broadacre Areas which includes hazardous and offensive industries restricted to the area in question, subject to environmental assessment. The Plan also foreshadows that siting of future industry, defence installations, institutions and other activities requiring significant large sites, may be considered for Broadacre Areas in the long term.

Draft Amendment No. 14 sought to amend the National Capital Plan by deleting "hazardous and offensive" to expand the range of uses permitted in the Broadacre Area, marked A, B, C and D on the attached Figure, to encompass industries generally. The relevant permitted use would have read "Industries restricted to the land to the west of Oaks Estate on the north side of Canberra Avenue and subject to environmental assessment."

The Draft Amendment was proposed in order to make the National Capital Plan consistent with the Territory Plan and to facilitate the redevelopment and upgrading of the site of the ageing and obsolete Canberra abattoir. The formulation of detailed development parameters within the framework of the general land use policy is a matter for the territory government.

The recommendations of the majority of the committee have been accepted. As a result, the amendment will be revised to restrict the area available for industries to the areas marked A, B and D on the attached figure.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Majority Recommendations
Recommendation 1
