SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hogg, Sen John

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak on the annual report of the Australian Trade Union Training Authority. My colleague Senator Cooney spoke on this report last week. In his opening remarks, Senator Cooney referred to the fact that this was probably the penultimate report of this organisation, as it seems to have been killed by the current government. It is a report worthy of note. It is worth looking at what the Trade Union Training Authority has achieved over a long period of time.

SPEECH.PARA: If one turns to page 12 of the report, one can see there a reflection of the increase in trade union training that has taken place from 1990-91 through to 1995-96, where last year 5,714 training days were used. The significant point is that, of those 5,714 days, 4,653 days were used through the union training scheme which is under the umbrella of TUTA. That is a very significant number of days being devoted to the education of workers in the workplace as to their rights and their privileges. This training particularly fosters the development of industrial relations skills, negotiation skills, dispute resolution skills and life skills—including confidence and belief in themselves.

The union training schemes which I personally became associated with proved to be of great benefit to those people who showed a development in their own right. The training showed that they have a positive part to play in the work force in the development of a safe and healthy workplace and in the development of a cooperative spirit at the workplace.

Let us look at some of the issues that were covered in those courses, with some 20 unions taking advantage of the union training scheme during the year and with 200 trainers registered to conduct courses. They addressed issues such as: what an award is; what the actual law pertaining to the workplace is; dispute resolution; equal employment opportunity, which affects so many women who are now in our work force; enterprise bargaining, which seems to have been killed off by the workplace relations legislation; negotiation; superannuation; occupational health and safety; communication skills; the Industrial Commission; the role of unions; sexual harassment—and so the list goes on.

This report is really a sad report in one way in that we see the government trying to deny to people these basic skills and trying to deny to them the right to attain at least a minimum understanding of what their involvement in the workplace should be. What is most poignant in the industry from which I came—the retail industry—was that there were so many women and so many young people involved in the industry who gained their education through the union training scheme under the umbrella of TUTA.

There were full‐time, part‐time and casual employees; there was no discrimination as to who was taught their rights and privileges. The courses served to break down barriers with management. They provided people with skills that they would not otherwise have been provided with, and in many cases this helped people to achieve promotion. It cut down in some instances a suspicion that was held by the employers about what industrial relations was about and, in all, lifted a veil that is cast upon the trade union movement as some sort of demonic organisation.

It was quite clear that the people who were educated here were the battlers. They were the people who were equipped in some small way with the ability to defend themselves. The government's decision to axe TUTA will be lamented. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Brien, Sen Kerry

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support the motion to take note of the 1995‐96 report of the Australian Trade Union Training Authority. In doing so, I commend Senator Hogg for his very important comments. The Trade Union Training Authority, as Senator Hogg has just reminded the Senate, has been the subject of an excision from the industrial relations legislation as a result of the workplace relations bill. Senator Hogg says it has been vilified, and it has.

SPEECH.PARA: We have had a lot of debate in this chamber over the last few weeks about education matters. This government has talked about the billions of dollars they have been prepared to put into education, but in this case educating employees, workers, about their rights is a low priority for this government.

Having had personal experience of and involvement in trade union training courses delivered under the auspices of the Trade Union Training Authority, and particularly with courses delivered by my organisation, funded by them in accordance with the guidelines laid down by the Trade Union Training Authority, I can say that very important educational outcomes came from the funding of the Trade Union Training Authority.

It is remarkable to note that there are many, many people in the community who have no idea of their rights, who do not know what an award is, who learn about superannuation and how it affects them by attending courses run by the Trade Union Training Authority. I am talking about people who have been, in the main, elected by their fellow workers to represent them in negotiations with their employer. So these are the people that workers in a great many occupations have put forward and say, `We don't know enough about these employment issues, we want you to represent us.'

The Trade Union Training Authority has for many years performed a service to the community in equipping these people to go out and represent their fellows at a workplace level. This government has talked about the focus of negotiations being at the workplace. Look at the name of the bill that they put through this parliament—workplace relations. What do they want to do about facilitating negotiations at a workplace level? Absolutely nothing. They are taking away from Australia an organisation funded by the government which equipped workers to represent themselves. So on the one hand the government says, `Let us have a focus on the workplace,' and on the other hand we have a vast working community which have

been given no instruction, no training in terms of their legal rights, in terms of how to negotiate, in terms of the issues of negotiation, in terms of the complexities of the industrial relations system that applies to them.

Senator Hogg referred to the great majority of the workplace representatives who were trained as having been trained directly by employee organisations through funding from the Trade Union Training Authority. Obviously, that was a measure to get a better result from the dollars spent without having to rely upon the total infrastructure of the Trade Union Training Authority at its Clyde Cameron College and at its facilities in other states. In fact, the Trade Union Training Authority had wound down a number of its facilities. In particular, in my state of Tasmania, it had closed the TUTA centre and relied exclusively on hiring facilities, bringing trainers from interstate and also on the employee organisations providing facilities and getting a cost‐ effective service out of that method of funding.

There needs to be some thinking about this. If this government is sincere about wanting a workplace focus, they have to give some thought to how they are going to equip people to deal with these issues at a workplace level. I commend this report. This is an organisation that should have been fostered, not guillotined by the bill that this government has put through this parliament.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lundy, Sen Kate

TALK.START.PARA: —I also rise to speak to this motion to take note of the 1995‐96 report of the Australian Trade Union Training Authority. The authority has played an absolutely magnificent role in the training of workplace delegates, occupational health and safety representatives, and participants in the consultative committee process that is one of the fundamental platforms of enterprise bargaining.

SPEECH.PARA: The Trade Union Training Authority was an organisation that really went to the workers. Their programs were conducted not only in all the major cities, but where there was a demand they would actually go out to the workplaces and conduct the courses there. The sorts of things that are raised in a Trade Union Training Authority program or course are things like: what are your employer's legislative requirements? What are the regulations associated with occupational health and safety requirements? What is an award and what does an award contain?

While it is easy for senators to stand up in this chamber and to debate for 53 hours, or thereabouts, issues with respect to awards and allowable matters, unless the workers out there know what is in an award and what it means, what we say is irrelevant. Unless workers are aware of their rights, what point is there in having legislation? What point is there in having minimum standards? What point is there in having allowable matters if there are working people out there who are not aware of their entitlements and rights under those particular awards.

TUTA provided a way to educate working people. It provided the means by which unions could ensure that their representatives got the right information and got the facts. I have heard all too often coalition senators in this chamber saying that unions present a somewhat biased position. What do they think TUTA did? TUTA provided an independent education service for working people to assist them in understanding their rights. That is what this government has done away with.

The government has done away with it because the government knows that if working people know their rights it has a problem. It is quite obvious that this government is displaying sequacious behaviour, following the pattern of listening to the advocacy of the big employer groups. There is no doubt that the motivation of this government in abandoning TUTA is to do what the big end of town has asked them to do.

BREAK.PARA: That is a great shame because, in doing so, the government has blatantly removed the rights of people to have access to basic information—information that goes to forming the matrix of the rights of working people. A number of employer organisations advocate their own beliefs through various mechanisms, but this government is dismantling every single mechanism available to working people and to the trade union movement to educate their own.

It is ironic that we are looking at the dismantling of TUTA in the same week in which we saw this government make the most appalling changes to restrict the access of people to higher education. It is irresponsible. The chicanery of this government has no direction. (Time expired)
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Conroy, Sen Stephen

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the document.

I remind the chamber of the role that Austrade plays, which is so well explained in the Australian Trade Commission's annual report before the chamber today. Its fundamental role is to help Australian companies establish and market their products and services overseas and to attract foreign investment into Australia. It is part of the internationalising of the Australian economy.

There is a matrix of 99 offices in 67 countries around the world, and last year alone there was $6.65 billion worth of new exports throughout the world, particularly in Japan, Korea and other countries in South‐East Asia. That is up from $4.7 billion last year.

Austrade has helped 1,675 companies in the food industry, the beverage industry, information technology and communications. Seventy‐six per cent of export sales clients said that Austrade is doing a good job and is a positive factor in their achieving export sales. In rating Austrade, 78 per cent of all clients think that it is doing `good', `very good' or `extremely good' work, and that is a massive improvement over the last three years.

BREAK.PARA: Sixty per cent of clients are small or medium enterprises, and that is what Austrade has been targeting—not the big companies. This is not industry welfare; it is helping the small companies that need assistance in this country.

An economist group, the Economist Intelligence Unit, recently produced a report titled Australia's Foreign Investment Challenges: the Harsh Reality of a Foreign Investment Perspective on Australia. It demonstrated this government's chicanery on the question of industry policy. The clear warning to Canberra from this report is that, if the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) does not develop an interventionist industry policy, Australia will lose out to its Asian rivals for the new investment dollar. The sequacious members of the opposition who sit back and allow this to happen should be condemned.

We have seen almost a third of Austrade's budget and EMDG cut coming into this next 12 months. We will not have any industry policy. We will not have a say in what industries we want to develop. We will not have any incentives and support such as Austrade provides at the moment.

You might ask who was involved in this report. It included BP Australia, Caterpillar, Citibank, Dow Chemicals, DuPont Australia, Edison Mission Energy, Glaxo Wellcome, Hewlett‐Packard, Kodak, Mobil, Pilkington and Uncle Ben's. Those companies are all actively saying to this government, `When are we going to get an industry policy?'

The worst feature these investors found is that in Canberra there is no commitment to industry. But here in the Senate, there is a chance for us to stop the nonsense and make the Prime Minister and the Treasurer (Mr Costello) face reality. What we need is for the Senate to oppose the proposed cuts to export industry research and development and retraining programs. The report said:
Within the next five years most large manufacturing multinational companies will put their next global scale plant somewhere in Asia.
If Australia does not have an industry policy, our chances of attracting that investment are not great. The report also stated:

If there is a common response to the question of what changes in Australia would have most impact at corporate headquarters in changing negative perceptions, it is the need for a coherent, long term industry policy that runs across all federal ministries and across states.
Respondents in the report said
. . . we've worked hard bringing our operations up to global standards and in terms of competitiveness or productivity we can match most of the other locations in Asia.

PARA.EMPHASIS: (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Chee, Sen Bill

TALK.START.PARA: —I am glad to see my friend on the other side is taking an interest in Austrade. I would encourage him to do so. It is very important for senators from both sides of the chamber to be interested in Australia's export performance.

SPEECH.PARA: My comments basically relate to the direction on which Australia's export efforts should be based. I think it is always very tempting for people to say, `We will stick with the tried and true industries. We will stick with the manufacturing sector,' and so on. There are areas in the manufacturing industries where Australia is very efficient, particularly in the processing of food.

We need to also look at the new opportunities that are available for this nation when it comes to exporting services. Let me explain why I say that. The danger we have in this country is that labour becomes a commodity. My friends from the opposition would understand my concern because if labour is a commodity people get paid commodity prices for their labour and that is not in the interests of the workers nor in the interests of the country.

What we do have is a large number of people in Australia who have received 12 years of education and, irrespective of what state, generally the education is of a reasonable standard. We have a higher educational level than many of our neighbours, so we have the opportunity to be exporting services to them. Services mean that we can return a higher rate for the labour than we could get in the manufacturing sector. We really should be looking at how we can utilise our language and technology skills and our proximity to the region and turn Australia into a major service centre.

We should pay much more attention, when we talk about exporting education, to exporting vocational education. Hitherto, we have done very well—as others would know—exporting services in relation to university education. As Senator Brownhill would know, the universities in Asia are improving in standard and the government attitude in many of those places—correct me if I am wrong—is that they would prefer to see people to go to their own national universities for their undergraduate degrees.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is so.

—That is correct. But at the vocational training level, the other countries in the region cannot match what we have to offer, which has been developed over a very long period of time. We have a lot of potential to sell vocational training.

SPEECH.PARA: Madam Acting Deputy President Reynolds, being from North Queensland, you would understand the high contribution that has been made to vocational education by the Institute of TAFE in North Queensland. You would also be aware that, in the last 18 months to two years, we have significantly improved their export earnings. I have worked with them. We have put together a strategy to target vocational education in Papua New Guinea and the South Pacific. That is starting to pay off. Vocational education can be very valuable for other TAFE colleges around the country and for the private sector, because our neighbours do not have that capacity.

Another area that we should be concentrating on is the sale of services in things like data processing. Given the large body of people who speak English very well in Australia and the fact that most computer programs are in English, we ought to be a major service centre in Asia for the insurance industry and the credit card industry—for example, with Master Card, Visa, American Express and Diners Club, all the transactions that are made have to be processed. They should be processed here in Australia. We can utilise our proximity, our time zone and all of those things in our favour to get those exports from here.

BREAK.PARA: All I am saying to the Senate is: yes, manufacturing is important, and food processing is important—as a National Party senator I understand that very well. I am also saying that if we are to ensure that the workers of Australia receive more than commodity wages for their labour, we have to move them into high value jobs, particularly in the export of services. We have some national advantages here that the rest of the region cannot match. That is something that Austrade should focus on.

The other thing I would just say very briefly is that we need to make sure that our flow of investment matches our flow of trade. It is sad that we do a reasonable amount of trade with South‐East Asia but we have an insufficient amount of outward investment by Australian companies into the region. It creates a perception in the region that we are not interested in the long haul. This nation is interested in the region in the long haul, but Austrade should be more active in encouraging Australian companies, not just to sell goods and services into Asia, but also to make investments there, because future trade earnings will be based on the back of those investments. I know another senator wants to speak, so I will conclude my remarks there.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook, Sen Peter

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak to the Australian Trade Commission annual report 1995‐96 as well. Before I turn to the full remarks that I wish to make, I acknowledge the two previous speakers in this debate; I welcome Senator O'Chee to the debate on Austrade.

SPEECH.PARA: As a former minister for trade—and therefore having ministerial responsibility for Austrade—I say that Austrade is a very fine organisation. It is the international business intelligence unit for Australia that provides the lowdown on what is happening in the market economies around the world for Australian small business. Small business by definition is not big enough to be able to penetrate what is happening in a whole range of markets—particularly complex markets, as Asian markets often are, where different cultures and languages hold sway.

Austrade is the body that peers into those markets for Australian small business. That is why I think it is outrageous that Austrade's budget was cut so dramatically in this year's budget. That move limits the ability of Austrade to do the job for small business that it is there to do. Indeed, the sequacious remarks of backbenchers on the other side showed that they had overlooked that point, and I think that is a pity.

On the question of services, Senator O'Chee is right: 80 per cent of Australians are employed in the services sector and about 72 per cent of the Australian GDP is derived from the services sector. It is the biggest single sector in Australian industry and it is an area that we are extremely competent in.

We have achieved a lot of positive outcomes for the balance of payments in the education sector selling those services. I might say that the medical sector is another area in which we are extraordinarily competitive in this region. We have not achieved the same level of performance there, but that sector is working on it and I encourage its efforts.

Australia is a major financial hub as well. We are not necessarily, at this point, recognised as being a major financial centre for the region. One of the things that the former government sought to do with the innovation statement which was brought down in December last year—in fact, it was brought down on this date exactly 12 months ago—was to try to set up Sydney, or some other major Australian capital, as a major regional financial centre for this region. That required a number of small policy changes. Until Australia is seen internationally in those ways, the finances, the packaging of new projects, the new companies and all the rest of it in this region will go through Hong Kong and, after the takeover of Hong Kong, probably through Shanghai or Singapore exchanges—they will not be going through Australia.

This is a global economy now. For Australia to be competitive, we have to put our hand up and fight for our position in that economy. It requires private sector drive, but government support behind that drive, to realise those objectives. Sydney could be a world ranking financial hub for the Asia‐Pacific region, but it does require a bit of government backing to help it achieve that. It is a pity that the innovation statement was cut back in that respect as well.

Senator Conroy has put his finger on the matrix of associated problems here. We have had the drama of the cuts to the DIFF program, and we have seen how that has put back Australia's trade position in this region. We have had cuts to the export market development grants scheme. For a government that supports small business, this is an amazing piece of chicanery on its behalf. This move has meant that the small business area has had their access to export incentives reduced. We have seen the abandonment of ITES, which is the least understandable of all, because this is a revolving fund scheme.

We have seen as well that the government, which rode to the election promising Australian industry that it would engage in bilateral trade negotiations, was not able to say what it has done about that when confronted with questions in the estimates process. This is something they are working on and maybe will tell us about in the future. The government made a big feature of saying that bilateral trade negotiations were the new departure it was going to bring about. So far, there has been no work on that subject and, even when pressed at estimates levels, the government gives no information either.

I think Austrade is an extraordinarily important organisation for Australia. I commend the chairman, Alan Jackson, Nixon Apple, Elizabeth Bryan, Grant Latta, Graeme Lawless, Simon Lee, Mrs Martin and Mr Unsworth—all directors—who have done a fine job for this nation. (Time expired)
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.PARA: It has been a wise move on the part of the government of Victoria to refer their powers in the industrial relations field to the Commonwealth. I think all other states should do that. SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Brien, Sen Kerry

TALK.START.PARA: —I firstly have to, in supporting the motion to take note of this report, congratulate Senator Cooney on his fast eight minutes and thank him for his compliments. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hogg, Sen John

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to take note of the annual report of the Department of Industrial Relations. Primarily, I have done so on a similar occasion because I believe we will not see a report of this quality and this standard in the future because of the gutting of the industrial relations sector by the government.

SPEECH.PARA: In particular, I want to take note of pages 35, 36 and 37 of the report where attention is devoted to the private sector workplace reform and best practice. One of them was to `contribute to the development of industrial relations arrangements that improve Australia's economic performance through the development of a more cooperative and productive workplace culture.' That is not going to be achieved under the current Workplace Relations Act.

Another objective was to `promote the adoption of the government's industrial relations policies including workplace performance, best practice and workplace bargaining.' That objective is very important because I believe one of the ways Australia will gain an edge on its rival nations will be at the leading edge if we have the skills, if we have the technique, and if we can develop the quality within our industry to promote a better product at a smarter and cheaper price.

One of the objectives also espoused in this report was to `maximise community understanding of employment rights and responsibilities under federal awards, agreements and legislation and to secure better observance of these and related obligations.' This was not just mere words. It was, as the report highlights at page 202 through to page 212, backed up by cold hard cash. The Australian public should be aware of the wide range of organisations that were funded through the department to achieve best practice and to achieve workplace bargaining in a cooperative environment, a cooperative spirit.

TALK.START.PARA: —And the matrix.
—Yes, and the matrix was absolutely important. The organisations listed on pages 202 to 212—
—Can we spell that?

—No, we cannot. The organisations listed were not simply trade unions but covered a wide range of organisations. I think the significance of this report is that it covers such a wide range of organisations, such as employer organisations, as I said, trade unions, peak councils of trade unions and peak councils of employers, all heading down the path of what I believe is the long-term necessity for the workplace in this country—that is, the development of best practice and the development of a cooperative spirit.

BREAK.PARA: Alas, I believe that now has been put to one side. Whether we will see this government prepared to put money into developing and fostering best practice in the same way that this report outlines is one matter that is completely open to conjecture.

I commend to the Senate and also to the public the section of the report that I have drawn to the attention of the Senate today. I believe that it is an important issue which needed to be addressed, and continues to need to be addressed, if we are to have a competitive marketplace to counter the developments that are going on around us in foreign countries. I commend the report to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins, Sen Jacinta

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to make a few comments on the annual report of the Department of Industrial Relations, following on from those made by Senator Cooney—thank you very much for the compliments, Senator. I would like to take this opportunity to commend the work of the staff of the Department of Industrial Relations. Unfortunately, in the brief 10 minutes I had to present my committee's report into the workplace relations bill, I did not have the opportunity to commend their work and, in particular, the work of those officers who were assigned to the committee in dealing with the very complex matrix of issues associated with both this legislation and the legislation we are now being confronted with in respect of Victoria.

SPEECH.PARA: Despite the chicanery that has already been referred to on page 92—projecting the bill as a fair go for all—we can all reflect on the fact that the bill has been amended so that it is somewhat fairer and no longer relates quite as much to the sequacious projection of coalition ideology that the Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Reith) first presented to us.

At this stage, I would like to give the opportunity to other members to speak to other reports as we have been moving somewhat slowly through them. I simply want to thank Senator Cooney and highlight the very fine work that has been done by members of the department under significant cuts in the budget. I suspect, following on also from Senator Hogg's comments, that they will have much more difficulty in presenting such fine reports as this in the future.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney, Sen Barney

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the document.

The 1995‐96 annual report from the Australian Institute of Family Studies is a very important report and deals with some very vital issues. Pages 16 and 17, for example, talk about a family law evaluation project, remaking families, the Australian divorce transition project, the Australian law and children's rights, parenting and child abuse prevention.

It is time in Australia that we had a unified approach to the family, including children. When I say unified, I mean that it be brought under one body or at least one group of bodies. The Family Court of Australia should be just that: it should deal with all the problems that arise in a family. A very eminent judge of that court, Justice Linda Dessau, whom I think you had the pleasure of meeting last night, Madam Acting Deputy President, has had vast experience not only in the Family Court but in the magistrates and children's courts and knows all areas of law well, including criminal law. An example of why there should be this unified approach to the whole area of family is, she says, that a lot of the crime that children commit can only be understood properly and can only be remedied if seen in the family context. I raise that issue about which the judge has spoken as a future policy direction that we as a parliament might pursue.

We should make use of the vast resources in the community that we often do not tap in this parliament to get the proper approach to the problems that we face as a nation. As we would all agree, the family is central to the state and health of this country. If we can get a national approach and if we can get the sort of approach that Justice Dessau speaks of, we will get along a lot better than we presently do.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Forshaw, Sen Michael

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the document.

Out of the great matrix located just down the road here, the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade, has come their 1995‐96 annual report, on which I wish to make a few remarks. This report, 460 pages long, is comprehensive in that it covers the great range of activities that we are involved in around the world in foreign affairs and trade. In the short time I have available, I would like to refer to a couple of these.

Firstly, the report notes the great role that Australia, I might say under the previous government, played in the development of the chemical weapons convention. That is of course something Australia has led the world in. Similarly, it notes during the past year the signing of the South‐East Asian nuclear weapons free zone arrangements—again, an area where the previous Labor government under the previous foreign minister, Gareth Evans, showed such pioneering initiatives. Gareth Evans was certainly no sequacious Minister for Foreign Affairs. He was out there pioneering, not just following the leader and being a long way behind like, unfortunately, our current minister, Mr Downer.

Similarly, the last big issue in our own region was the French resumption of nuclear testing. We came through that difficult time with the final decision by France to become a signatory to the South Pacific nuclear weapons free zone arrangements—great achievements that continued the long leading role that Australia under Minister Gareth Evans played in foreign affairs and similarly in trade under former Minister Bob McMullan.

This report which covers the years 1995‐96 largely reflects the great work done in these areas by the previous Labor government. It is appropriate that two photographs, I think, sum up the comparison between the previous performance and what we are now seeing. For instance, one photograph shows then Senator Evans and Indonesian foreign minister Ali Alatas signing the very important Australian‐Indonesian security agreement. The second photograph shows the current Minister for Trade, Tim Fischer, inspecting a plate of oysters.

Since the current government has come to office we have seen one piece of chicanery after another, typified by some of the events that happened today with Telstra; but also in foreign affairs and trade through the removal of DIFF. This has been dealt with in another report but it clearly is recognised within this report as a very important aspect of our promotion of export trade as well as part of our overseas aid program. What happened? Not long after coming to office, the government simply abolished the scheme with no notice, really, to the companies involved. We are still waiting to hear the reason why, as are at least 70 to 80 companies after having invested hundreds of thousands of dollars in these programs.

The report covers, very substantially, many of the important issues around the world, for example, Latin America, which is now the second fastest growing economic area in the world behind Asia. It is an area on which Australia will have to focus more in the future. In my capacity as chair of the Senate foreign affairs committee, along with other members, I met with Latin American ambassadors last week to further consider how we can promote trade, cooperation and contact between our countries.

Similarly, the report looks at the incredible change within Europe and the impact that the changes there are having on such areas as economics, trade and particularly our security. It is a very fine report recognising fine achievements of the previous government and the previous ministers. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hogg, Sen John

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to continue my remarks on this report later.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted; debate adjourned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crowley, Sen Rosemary

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the document

I urge honourable senators and anyone with an interest in family studies to note the report of the Australian institute. I had the great pleasure of having ministerial responsibility for it and I note in the report that the institute is now working with Minister Moylan. It has been a very interesting program of trying to get serious research done to assist governments to make policies in the family area.

One of the most important points here is that the National Child Protection Clearing House became a responsibility of the Australian Institute of Family Studies. There is much here that would assist people who are concerned about the best ongoing formulation of policy for child protection. It is quite clearly an area where there is going to be a need for a major statement and major addressing of policies. I believe this report would help. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Chee, Sen Bill

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the document.
I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Faulkner, Sen John

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate condemns the Government for abandoning older Australians to the mercy of market forces.

This government has been absolutely duplicitous in its intentions towards the elderly in this country. We have all become painfully aware of this because of the department of health's working party report for the minister, now called the `minister on nursing homes', Mrs Moylan, who used to be called the Minister for Family Services.

This minister, Mrs Moylan, claims that the nursing home system is under stress and needs capital contributions to build and refurbish ageing infrastructure. But, of course, it is not helped when John Howard and Peter Costello remove $500 million from capital funding for nursing homes in a budget that they claim would not hurt the poor, the sick and the vulnerable. Has Mrs Moylan stood up to Peter Costello and John Howard, or has she been absolutely servile?

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise a point of order, Madam Acting Deputy President. I think that twice now the Leader of the Opposition over there has referred to the Prime Minister and the Treasurer in an incorrect manner. I ask you to call him to order.
—Senator, could I remind you of the appropriate way in which to address the Prime Minister and other ministers. Please continue.
—Could you explain to me: did I refer to them unkindly?
— I don't think it was that you referred to them unkindly.
—I meant to.
—It was a question of not using their correct titles, which is part of the appropriate way of referring to ministers in the other place.
—I didn't say `Mr'; I said `John Howard' and `Peter Costello', not `Mr John Howard' and `Mr Peter Costello'.
—There are other John Howards and other Peter Costellos.

—We have heard from the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs that there are other John Howards and other Peter Costellos. That means there are other Mr John Howards and other Mr Peter Costellos. I stand corrected. That is a telling point that you have made, Minister. At that rate, you really will be promoted very quickly. You keep defending John Howard; you will get on. You will get a new portfolio.
—What about Nick Sherry calling me senator?

—He called you senator; you are a senator. He is very well mannered. The point is that Mr Howard and Mr Costello have sold out the aged in our community. That is the truth of the matter. The issue before the Senate, the question that senators are looking at is whether sick, elderly, frail people—after a lifetime of contributing to this country, after working hard, after being so important in making an contribution to the Australian community—are to be told that they might be sick, they might be elderly but they are going to have to sell the family home to pay for a health care service that should fundamentally and primarily be funded by government through the taxes that those people have paid throughout their working lives.

SPEECH.PARA: The truth is that 60 per cent of people who go into a nursing home go directly from hospital care. You have no choice when you go into a nursing home. You are often infirm. Senator Herron, the minister at the table, ought to know more than most, because of his experience as a medical practitioner, the sorts of reasons why the elderly go into nursing homes. Obviously, Senator Herron does not have the opportunity to shop around.

TALK.START.PARA: —No, there is a tremendous shortage. After 13 years of labor there is a desperate shortage.

—I understand why you will not respond—because you are so guilty about what the government, which you are a member of, has done. This is a time, when people need nursing home care, when a government has a responsibility to hold out its hand and help. It is a time when people who have made a great contribution to society, who have paid their taxes, have their lifetime of contributions returned.

SPEECH.PARA: But Mr John Howard's government does not see aged care as a particularly important role for government. The Minister for Family Services (Mrs Moylan) in the House of Representatives on Tuesday agreed that nursing home charges should be left up to market forces, that fees should be negotiated between the patient and the nursing home proprietor. She did not deny in a question this week that up-front fees might be as high as $80,000.

This same Mrs Moylan is weasel-worded in the extreme when she says that the government will not force anyone to sell their own home. Documents that the opposition has obtained show precisely that it is the market that will force people to sell their own homes. The Department of Health and Family Services have ascertained—no doubt through the minister's own request—that 75 per cent of elderly Australians are able to fund a $26,000 up-front entry fee and 63 per cent of these will fund it through the sale of their house. That is in their own documents.

Madam Acting Deputy President, I take a point of order. There is no minister at the table to hear this very important debate on elderly Australians. This is indicative, in my view, of the contempt that this government has for aged people in our community.

TALK.START.PARA: —He will be back very shortly. He had an urgent reason for just popping outside for a moment. He has just excused himself.
—Madam Acting Deputy President, I ask that the clock be stopped. I will wait on the minister's attendance in the chamber.
—I am advised that there is no technical point of order. I would ask you to continue.
—There's no Liberal Party member in the House now.

—What contempt for those in our community that not one member of the Liberal Party is even in the chamber. Now, tail between his legs, the minister comes back into the chamber. How contemptuous can you get!
—I take a point of order. I regard that as a reflection on me. Madam Acting Deputy President:

BREAK.PARA: Nature hath fram'd strange fellows in her time:
Some that will evermore peep through their eyes,
And laugh like parrots at a bagpiper;
And others of such vinegar aspect
That they'll not show their teeth in the way of a smile
Though Nestor swear the jest be laughable.

TALK.START.PARA: —Minister, there is no point of order in your comments.
—Madam Acting Deputy President, I do not have my tail between my legs. I regard that as a reflection which should be withdrawn.
—Minister, you were making a personal explanation, not taking a point of order. I ask Senator Faulkner to continue.

—I was exposing the Department of Health and Family Services in their own words—documents that have been produced by the opposition in relation to the fact that 63 per cent of the 75 per cent of elderly Australians will be funding the $26,000 up-front fee through the sale of their own home. That is in government documents. I would also like to draw on another government department, the Department of Finance, and its contribution to the National Commission of Audit when the government in its early days was just cranking up the pay-as-you-go approach, the pay-as-you-go option, in the health area.

SPEECH.PARA: Mr John Howard, after the budget, saw no reason why people should not pay for their own nursing home care. He said in the West Australian newspaper on 31 August that it was fair and reasonable to say to a person who is going into a nursing home that `you should borrow some money against that house and, if it's not paid before you die, it will be paid out of your estate'. They are Mr Howard's words. It sounds like de facto death duties to me. But yesterday in the House of Representatives, the Prime Minister confirmed that he regarded money being taken out of someone's estate to pay for a health service as the repayment of a debt, not a death duty. The Prime Minister, out of his own mouth, has confirmed that when you are old and infirm, the government expects that, along with the doctor, nurse and social worker on your aged care assessment team, you will have to have a bank manager and perhaps a real estate valuer. They are the two new members of your aged care assessment team. That is the future of nursing home care according to the Liberal Party.

The Prime Minister might see it as merely a pay-when-you-go debt, but we regard the Minister for Family Services—a junior minister in their outfit—as really being the minister responsible for the invidious duty of pushing through a de facto death duty on the aged and infirm. No-one else in Australian society has to pay for their health care in this way, just the aged and infirm. It is almost like—I think Senator Conroy would be interested in this—the aged and infirm having a tattoo saying, `I am aged and infirm.'

TALK.START.PARA: —Across the forehead.

—I do not know about that. But, it could read `I am aged and infirm. I will have to pay my way in this fashion after the contribution that I have made to Australian society.' It is an extraordinary ask, an extraordinary demand, on the part of this government. In the Senate, we really hear a lot of claptrap about mandates and pre-election promises. The coalition never promised up-front fees before the election. As a result, of course, this new policy of the Liberal Party has hit the aged in our society like a bombshell. It is a complete betrayal of the aged in Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: I think the 12,000 self-funded retirees will not be too pleased about being interviewed and data-matched by the Department of Social Security either. This is a group that was so intent on protecting their privacy that they led the vanguard against the Australia Card in 1988. They were not told that the Minister for Social Security (Senator Newman) would be nosing around their houses in typical—as the workers refurbishing her office said—Hyacinth Bouquet mode checking the value of their Royal Doulton. They were not promised that, were they? They were not promised that by Mr Howard—no way. That is the truth of the matter.

There is no doubt that the Labor Party will be accused by the chorus of economic rationalists and apologists on the other side of the chamber of having brought in a similar up-front fee system for hostel accommodation, thus making the new nursing home model okay. That is the argument that you always hear. Let me warn opposition senators that you are likely to hear it in this debate. The fact is that hostel accommodation for the elderly is a choice. It is an accommodation option.

TALK.START.PARA: —Oh, rubbish!
—Even someone as ignorant as Senator Patterson should know that. Nursing homes are a health care service that is not an option. You would not wish—
—Order! Senator Faulkner, I ask you to withdraw that remark.
—What is that?
—The word `ignorant'. It is unparliamentary.
—I do not believe that it is.
—Well, I ask you to withdraw it anyway.
—The word `ignorant' is not unparliamentary, I can assure you. On the point of order, I suggest that you seek advice, because the word `ignorant' is not unparliamentary, let me assure you.
—In my opinion, in reference to Senator Patterson, it was not used in an endearing way.
—It was not endearing, but it was not unparliamentary.
—I believe it was. I am in the chair. I ask you to withdraw it.
—There is no point of order.
—I am letting you apologise.

—I am not going to apologise. I am not required to withdraw remarks in the chamber that are not unparliamentary. I respectfully submit that you reconsider your ruling that the word `ignorant' is unparliamentary. This is an extraordinary ruling. I ask you to take advice on it. If you insist, in the interests of the debate progressing, I will very reluctantly withdraw it. I suggest to you that it would be more sensible for you to consider that ruling before you insist on my withdrawing it. On reflection, you would not be suggesting that the word `ignorant' was unparliamentary.

—I am not suggesting that the word itself was unparliamentary. I am suggesting that the way in which you used it was unparliamentary. That is the reason I ask you to withdraw it. My advice is also that it was unparliamentary. We will take the matter up with Madam President, if you so wish.
—I would appreciate it if you did take the matter up with Madam President.
—We will consult the Hansard tomorrow.
—I withdraw the remark.

—Mr Acting Deputy President, I raise a point of order. When you are taking the matter up, would you also seek advice on whether it would be now appropriate or allowable for me to call the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate ignorant in that he was referring to a specialist in the field of the aged. Senator Patterson, as we all know, is a gerontologist. It is quite ignorant of the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate to describe her as ignorant in her own specialist area.
—On the point of order, in all the time I have been a senator, I have never asked anyone to withdraw any comment made about me. Say what you like, I could not give a damn.
—You don't have a reputation to lose.
—That is a matter for you. You can say what you like.

—Senator Faulkner, come to order. It is not a question of what you like or what you don't like. Whoever is in chair is in charge of the chamber. I would ask you, or Senator Newman, or whoever else has the call, to respect the chair. I disallow the point of order and ask you to continue.

—I make the point in this contribution that I have never in my time as a senator asked any senator to withdraw any comment they have made about me; nor will I ever do so. I could not care less what you say about me, to be honest. It is no wonder that this crew over here are trying to deliberately interrupt the flow of this very important debate, because they are ashamed of what they are doing on this matter.

SPEECH.PARA: As I said, the facts are that hostel accommodation for the elderly is a choice, and it is an accommodation option. Nursing homes are a health care service and they are not an option. That is the difference. You would not want to end up in a nursing home, however good the facility was. No-one would. There is a vast difference between the two systems, although Minister Moylan, in her pathetic defence of her actions, probably wishes they were similar, because it is her only excuse when it comes to up-front fees on nursing home care.

The Department of Health and Family Services' own document flags that people might pay the $26,000 up‐front fee for a hostel and in a co‐located facility they may have to pay a second entry contribution when they are shifted across the corridor to a nursing home. The document states that this manipulation by some proprietors should be `monitored'. How weak can you get? Why doesn't the Department of Health and Family Services and its working group just point blank advise that the government regulate to protect the elderly person from this double whammy?

As this is motion indicates, this is the free market. What regulations are left are being ditched. Hopefully, the states pick up and carry on the responsibility. But the free market will basically dictate that, in many cases, the elderly will pay twice.

Anyone who has been involved in the field of aged care will remember the absolute horror conditions that existed prior to the election of the Hawke government. I hope that is something that would be acknowledged by those on the other side of the chamber. The Giles report in 1985 revealed a national disaster when it came to our nation's elderly and conditions which pertained in private nursing homes. I would encourage those opposite to read that report. It was written when market forces were in control of the aged care system.

The Labor government created a national system so that national standards were set. Regulation and accreditation made sure that standards were lifted. We poured billions of dollars into the aged care system to improve conditions, and those conditions did improve. We inherited an appalling aged care system left to us by a succession of previous coalition governments. Between 1985 and 1996, we put more than $12 billion into Australian nursing homes in both recurrent and capital funding. If you cut capital funding back to the tune of $500 million, as your vindictive government has done, and if you loosen the grip on national standards, as your government wants to do, you return to the appalling pre‐1985 days. If you allow market forces to choose the patient—

TALK.START.PARA: —Resident, they are called.

—If you allow market forces to choose the resident who has more money, rather than the person who has little, then the system will become two tiered. We will return to the horror conditions for poorer Australians. For those who are better off, who have investments, there will be better run, higher standard facilities.

SPEECH.PARA: None of this inhumane policy was promised prior to the election by the Liberal Party, who were into the politics of the big con. I believe that the government stands absolutely condemned for this betrayal of older Australians, which has been so effectively exposed by the opposition in both the House of Representatives and the Senate. I commend this important motion to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn

TALKER.NAME: Senator NEWMAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Social Security and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women)

TALK.START.PARA: —I just could not believe all that stuff that we have just been listening to. It is clearly an area which Senator Faulkner has not addressed his mind to in the past. He seems to be grossly ignorant.
—What mind?

—`What mind', says Senator Herron. But let us be kind; he knows no better. His own party went to the last election with half a page of policy on aged and community care. That has to about take the record for inadequacy especially when you consider—
—They were in government.

—They had all the resources of government and they produced half a page on aged care for the last election. By comparison, the coalition—who won government—had a 30-page, extremely detailed policy which refers to the crisis in the aged care area and gives very detailed measures that we were going to implement—
—Which turned out to be a pack of lies.

—Which were nothing of the sort. It just makes it quite clear that Senator Faulkner has not read it. I think that the Australian people recognised who cared about older Australians. I was really interested to see the brevity of the motion, which talks about `abandoning older Australians to the mercy of market forces'. The previous government simply abandoned older Australians. Do not worry about market forces, they just abandoned them altogether.

SPEECH.PARA: There are about two million Australians aged over 65 and that is going to rise to some 4.8 million by 2031. These people have their own needs and requirements as well as being valued contributors to our society. We recognised that in our very comprehensive policy on older Australians which we released before the last election. The policy covered not just aged care—after all, this motion does not refer to aged care. It talks about abandoning older Australians.

We saw very clearly how the previous government had abandoned older Australians. What did our election policy for older Australians cover? Retirement incomes, assistance to carers, stabilising Australia's health system, aged care including nursing homes and dementia facilities. Let us face it, Senator Faulkner said that they took over in 1985—

TALK.START.PARA: —I didn't say that.
—You said you took over an inadequate system in 1985.
—We won government in 1983.

—Yes, in 1983, so you had 13 years of inaction. You did little or nothing about dementia facilities. I will give former Senator Grimes some credit in that he tried to originally but, as soon as he was gone, dementia care went out the window with your government. You do not even know your history.

SPEECH.PARA: We included policies on community aged care, home and community care, and the particular needs of indigenous Australians and those living in rural and regional areas. We covered appropriate and affordable housing as well as improving employment access and voluntary work opportunities for older people, which we have implemented in the bill that is coming before the House. We talked about measures for crime and personal security, access for older people from ethnic backgrounds. The list went on and on, for 30 pages of detail. We contrast that with half a page of motherhood statements from the Labor government of the time, which runs to just over 200 words, I think. There is not a word in there about the crises of capital funding and of nursing homes.

In May 1994, the former government received the Gregory report after Professor Gregory had investigated 150 nursing homes. He concluded that 75 per cent of homes needed fixing or rebuilding to meet Australian design standards, that 70 per cent of homes needed fixing or rebuilding to meet the Commonwealth outcome standards, that 13 per cent of homes did not meet fire authority standards and that 39 per cent of residents were in rooms with four or more beds. That is your concern for older Australians. That is the Labor Party's handing over of the baton to the incoming government. That is your record in government. After all those years, that is the crisis that you handed over to us. You left your heads in the sand. We were left to pick up your mess.

We have a sound policy towards nursing homes, yet we have the Labor Party decrying the proper and responsible action that we are taking. The Minister for Family Services, Mrs Moylan, who is the responsible minister, has given guarantees to older people to protect them. Yet we have the extreme hypocrisy of the shadow minister for social security, Senator Faulkner, who never talks about social security but managed today to evince some rage. He comes into the chamber and complains about our actions to fix up the nursing homes capital crisis.
I would just draw your attention to an extremely important letter that appeared in the Australian on 19 September. I will just read some very representative extracts from that letter. The first one:
The fact is the system already applies to hostels, so why not extend it to nursing homes? Essentially, people will be asked to make a contribution out of their assets to the upkeep of the home.
The second one:
It is entirely fair that those who use those facilities should make a contribution.
Pity the poor soul who dies young but has to pay taxes to keep someone going in their nineties, who themselves ceased paying taxes 30 years earlier.
I think the welfare State can stand a bit of user‐pays, because the great levelling hand of the system can impose inequities as well as abolish them.
The third extract:

The taxpayer has already paid for the enormous amount of care and attention that the elderly receive. They pay through Medicare, the public hospitals, home and community care, Meals On Wheels, carers' pensions, and so on.
The final extract:

My generation will inherit the largest stock of capital ever in the nation's history, and generally we earn better than our parents. It seems fair, then, to use some of that inheritance to keep up a good quality of care for those who need it.
That was signed by Gary Johns, Northgate, Queensland—a Labor leader. Certainly, the rabble have been left behind.

If we look at what the Labor Party did for carers, this is another area in which for 13 years there was only marginal action. Let us look at what happened when our first budget was introduced. There was a press release from the Carers Association of Australia entitled `Forgotten people recognised in budget'. Doesn't that say what 13 years of Labor neglect for older people really meant?

We have announced and are implementing a national carers action plan. We recognise the sacrifice and enormous contribution made to our community by carers. We have announced a range of very positive measures which they strongly support. That includes retaining the carer pension and renaming it the carer payment, and allowing recipients of the carer payment to undertake paid or voluntary work, training or study for up to 20 hours a week, rather than the existing 10 hours a week. That is very important because it maintains their involvement with the community, their connection with the paid or the unpaid work force. It retains their confidence in themselves and their status in society.

In addition, we are allowing carer payment recipients to have more respite days, moving from 42 to 52 days a year. Of course, that is very important, too. Everybody, surely, deserves at least one day a week off. It would mean nothing if there had not also been a substantial increase in funding for respite care.

These measures have also been supplemented by our commitment to provide a tax rebate for older Australians who have private health insurance. Many senators would recognise that, at the time of their life when they may have more call on the health system, many older people see private health insurance as a major priority. During the last 13 years of the Labor government, private health insurance became progressively more and more expensive for older people. During the short period when I was the shadow minister for the aged, people would constantly come to me and say that they wanted to maintain their private health insurance and they were facing a crisis as to affordability. They were having to choose between fixing the spouting or maintaining their private health insurance. For some people, it was even more basic necessities that were being called into question for the sacrifice of private health insurance.

BREAK.PARA: It means a lot to older people to have that security of knowing that, if the need arises, they will get the care they want and need. But the Labor Party is so out of touch with older people in our community they simply cannot accept the validity and the merit of our incentives in the health insurance area for all Australians, which includes older people.

In my own portfolio, the government has kept the critical commitments to older Australians. We committed ourselves to underpinning one of the most important aspects for the financial security of older Australians. By that I mean committing ourselves to keeping the pension at 25 per cent of average male weekly earnings. Not only did we make that commitment; we put the provision in the forward estimates. That gives the security of knowing that that money will be there if and when it is needed. Surely, security of income has to be one of the most important ways that you can protect older people.

We are the first government to ever make that commitment. It is almost unbelievable, but we are the first government to provide that security by taking the step to have the future cost factored into the forward estimates. I think it is something this government can be proud of.

The previous government had 13 years to do that and could not be bothered. It could not find the time to make a decision that would provide some certainty for those older Australians whom they now would cry crocodile tears over and suggest that they care so much about. It just was not a budget priority for the previous government.

In addition to that commitment in the forward estimates as to the pension as a proportion of total average male weekly earnings, we have also maintained the commitment to the regular six‐monthly indexation of pensions. I well remember when we came into government that there were cries of gloom and doom from the Labor Party and their friends, suggesting we would be junking those commitments and that pensioners would be the sufferers. The proof is in the pudding. Our commitments were in the budget.

I draw the Senate's attention not only to our 30‐page policy for older Australians prior to the election, but also to the fact that in our first budget we produced a 25‐page document, Meeting our commitments—recognising older Australians. We are putting our policy substantially into place, and more will come in succeeding budgets.

The government has also maintained its commitment to keeping the income and assets changes to a minimum for age pensioners. We believe that by simplifying the extended deeming rules to remove the confusing deeming exempt limits of $2,000 and $4,000 for single and married pensioners respectively, we will be helping in that area.

I have been advised by my department that over 30 financial institutions already offer interest at the current deeming rates on amounts under $2,000. This new measure will have the effect of increasing overall pensioner income for those pensioners who choose to earn the deeming rate on their small account balances.

We have announced we will be improving the fairness and equity of treatment of investments for those aged over 55 but not yet at age pension age, because by including superannuation assets in the means test for the over 55s who have been receiving government support for a period of nine months, we are removing the preferential treatment reserved for one financial investment over another, and that is for one Australian over another.

We are not going to force older Australians to spend, waste away or otherwise divest themselves of their superannuation before being eligible for government assistance, as is claimed by the Labor Party and some other opponents of the measure. The Labor Party and others have caused a great deal of confusion in the community over this measure by continually suggesting people will have to spend all their superannuation. It simply is not true. Older Australians with smaller or more modest amounts of super will continue to be protected by the income free area.

With my announcement on the reduction of the deeming rates this afternoon, a single pensioner whose only other source of income is from financial investments will be able to have up to $52,500 in financial investments and a pensioner couple can have up to $91,200 before they are affected by this measure.

The Labor Party obviously does not understand it. Yet the honourable member for Jagajaga, Ms Jenny Macklin, said in August that the average amount held in superannuation is $38,000. Therefore, most people will not be affected. But for those with larger amounts of superannuation, they will generally be able to replace any reduction in their government benefit from the interest that their fund earns. Where individuals are unable to access this superannuation, exemptions from extended deeming under the incomes test may be requested and, for those affected by the assets test, other measures are available.

It is a very simple question: why should someone with $250,000 in superannuation be able to receive a government benefit when someone who has not had access to superannuation and has invested their savings elsewhere cannot get assistance? Our measure simply treats all investments equally, and all older Australians equally.

In addition to these measures, the government, in accordance with its election promise, has maintained its commitment to providing a tax rebate for low income older Australians. As a transitional measure, the rebate will be phased in during 1996‐97 at half the pensioner rebate and will be available at the full rebate level for the 1997‐98 income year.

Furthermore, the government will allow older Australians to continue contributing to superannuation up to the age of 70 if they so wish. This measure, and the retirement savings accounts—which will be very important to women—will help all those who have had poor access to superannuation. I say that it will be particularly beneficial to older women because so many of them have had broken periods in the work force.

It is clear that the Labor Party does not have credibility with older people. It was deserted by older people at the election, and who could be surprised when, as we saw, it was something like only 200 words that the former Labor government used to demonstrate any interest at all in older Australians. After 13 years in government—and inaction on a number of fronts, as I have highlighted—it was quite clear to those who went to the polls on 2 March that Labor was not even trying for older people.

Yet Labor Party members have the gall to come in here and portray themselves as representing the interests of the elderly. What is the reality? This new, vital, energetic, active government has delivered already for older people in a range of areas, such as social security, carers, aged care, private health insurance, tax rebates, and I could go on.

We have opposite a true opposition, opposing every measure that can benefit older Australians, including areas such as aged care where they knew there was a problem. They were told of the scope and the scale of the problem through the reports that they commissioned, yet they did not act. I do not think there can be any clearer indictment of the former Labor government, and that is what was recognised by older Australians on 2 March.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Woodley, Sen John

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Australian Democrats, I rise to speak to Senator Faulkner's motion. I draw the attention of the Senate to the three phrases in the motion, which I want to underline this afternoon.

SPEECH.PARA: The first phrase is `the Senate condemns the Government'; the second phrase is `for abandoning older Australians'; and the third phrase is `to the mercy of market forces'. This afternoon I want to try some definitions.

There is a new religion here in Canberra called `market fundamentalism'. It is a religion that needs definition because it is sweeping this country. It is a religion that I do not regard favourably at all.

The word `market' is about shifting figures around on a balance sheet; numbers are elevated and people are discounted. `Fundamentalism' is a world view. There are many forms of it. You can have Christian fundamentalism, Muslim fundamentalism, economic fundamentalism, Marxist fundamentalism. But in each case the world view is similar, although there may be a few different words in the definition.

BREAK.PARA: Part of that world view is the idea that everyone who does not belong is the enemy and that only believers have value—except that in market fundamentalism, even believers are discounted. It only values those to whom it can assign a dollar value. I think that is a fair definition and I would like to examine whether this government is comprised of market fundamentalists, and whether the motion we have before us fits that definition.

Let me first of all talk about Labor in government because, in government, Labor were half‐hearted believers in this particular religion. I am pleased to see that they are now agnostic, if not atheistic, in regard to the new religion. That is heartening.

The coalition are true believers in this new religion. I want to examine some of the creed of that new religion to see whether what the government has done fits with it. The first part of the creed reads, `Market fundamentalism asks for acceptance of its vision, not on the basis of economic reality but on the basis of blind faith.' It says, `We may have broken over two‐thirds of our promises but you can trust us.' That is blind faith.

When did the government say they would impose increased co‐payments for pharmaceuticals? The co‐payment contribution for pharmaceuticals will increase from 1 January 1997 and it will significantly hit older people. This means that the out‐of‐pocket costs for prescriptions for pensioners will rise from $2.70 to $3.20. That might not seem much to people like us on the income we enjoy but, certainly, to a pensioner who is already having difficulties surviving financially, such an increase might be the difference between making ends meet and not making ends meet.

This government says, `They will be able to manage. It will be okay.' Let us not forget that pensioners, at their time of life, are more likely to need a greater number of prescriptions than most other people. The government wants blind faith: `You can trust us. Even if we did not tell you we were going to do this or if we told you something else, that is okay. It was not really one of our core promises.'

Did the government indicate before the election that it was going to abolish the Commonwealth dental health program at the end of 1996? I did not read it. Perhaps I missed it; perhaps it was an addendum. The dental health program has been very important for age pensioners and many other people on low incomes. The prohibitive cost of private preventive dental care in this country makes it impossible for those people to have that kind of dental health without the help this program had provided. For the majority of older people, who are trying to survive on the age pension, accessing privately provided dental care is simply not an option. This government should be ashamed of itself for this swipe at those who are financially disadvantaged in our society. For many of these people there simply are not any alternatives.

Let us look at the second aspect of the creed of market fundamentalists. It says disagreeing with the creed of market fundamentalism is not simply a disagreement about an alternative way; it is regarded as heresy. And you know what they did to heretics! There is in Canberra a new inquisition—slow lingering death by strangulation for people who do not belong and who do not fit.

Let me give you an example of this. By increasing the user‐pays component for HACC services, what we have is old people at home with few options, wondering whether or not they will be able to survive independently. If that is not torture, I do not know what is. The home and community care services are very important to many older people as they help them to remain independent and to stay in their own homes for as long as possible. HACC services, which are jointly funded by the Commonwealth and the states and territories, provide older people with things like meals and in‐home nursing care. Increasing the user‐pays component for HACC services basically means that this government is choosing to make it much harder for pensioners to stay in their own home once they begin to become frail or unwell.

Let me give you the third element in the market fundamentalism creed. This creed believes in the new world order from which all notions of community are eliminated and society is just a collection of competing individuals. Remember it was Margaret Thatcher who said there is no such thing as society. There are competing individuals. And certainly in this new world order those who have money will win and those who have very little will lose significantly.

I give you the example of the entry contributions for nursing homes. I can tell you there is an incredible amount of fear amongst older people about the impact the introduction of entry contributions for nursing homes would have on them and their families. We do appreciate that many nursing homes are in critical need of an injection of funding for capital infrastructure. We will not stand by and see this happen at the expense of nursing home residents and those who are old and vulnerable within the community. They are not competing individuals; they are people who have learned to cooperate and who would like a little bit of cooperation at the end of their lives. The Democrats will work hard to ensure that any legislation which passes through the Senate is accompanied by very strong safeguards to ensure that the interests of older people are protected in this area.

The fourth element in this creed reads like this: market fundamentalism refuses to consider any restraint because such restraints delay the coming of the kingdom—even if it means broken promises. Let me give you one of the broken promises which is probably one of the most scandalous. The election manifesto of the coalition read:

The Coalition is fully committed to engendering stability, security, simplicity and flexibility into the superannuation system. This commitment will enable all Australians to plan for their retirement with a greater degree of certainty.

Well, I am sorry. If this government does not realise it, what it has done and what it is doing to superannuation does not introduce simplicity, does not introduce security, stability or flexibility, but is further designed to confuse people.

Let me point out that superannuation is not like other savings or other financial arrangements. Very deliberately, superannuation, with multiparty support, has been designed as a specific instrument that people can use and, until this government brought in its alterations, had been designed to give people confidence that they would have sufficient income when they retire to be able to support themselves. It seems to me that the government's agenda will allow nothing to stop its ideology. Even what was a previously multiparty approach can be discarded once this government puts in place its own ideology.

So the government's approach to super now is that it will destroy the confidence of people in superannuation. I can say to the government that, if there is any more destruction of public confidence, it will be impossible to maintain the superannuation system, and that is exactly what this government is doing.

As far as I am concerned, the proposition that people over 55 who are sacked will have to draw down their superannuation is an appalling one. It breaches the central principle of superannuation that savings must be preserved for retirement. No-one under 55 will be forced to cut into their super. People are saying to me that, for them, this is similar to the Menzies government raiding the pension funds in the 1950s.

This religion is a most destructive one. It is one with a very clear creed and it is one that ought to be of concern to all of Australia, but especially to older people in this nation. For those reasons, the Democrats support this motion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Denman, Sen Kay

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak to Senator Faulkner's motion. I believe it is important, before launching into this debate, to first discuss what is meant by market forces in the terms of this debate. Markets, in very wide terms, means virtually everything competes with everything else for the buyers' dollars. In this case, we are talking about dollars of older members.

SPEECH.PARA: In the perfect world, if the supplier of a service or product decides to increase the price, on the demand side members of our community can switch their patronage and seek some other source of supply. In many cases, that is difficult for older people who, as customers, have become accustomed over time to particular products or services. Older people, understandably, are loathe to switch to something cheaper, especially when they are wise to the fact that, on the supply side, sellers can adjust their product plans by substituting one service or product for another, resulting in most cases in providing less and charging more.
