It would be fair to say that, in some sections of the Australian aged care system, there has been in existence a quasi market. Nursing homes, which I will mention later, have for many years had a private for profit component, and hostels are now in the same category.

As we know, the previous government stuck by its commitment to older Australians to ensure that they—and I refer especially to pensioners, but not solely—should be entitled to live with dignity, have a secure income and have access to appropriate support services. There is a realisation on this side of the chamber that, if pensioners in particular were left to market forces, they would be faced with crippling costs and a dilution of services.

Apart from limited income, in many cases pensioners are unable, because of attitudes developed over their lifetime, to simply switch their patronage. They are also less likely to complain—but complaining they are, I am happy to say.

The stress and pressure that will be placed both physically and financially on our older Australians because of the budget measures are only just being realised in our community. Many peak bodies representing the elderly are most concerned and are expressing dismay at the increases in fees and the withdrawal of services.

The Council for Ageing in my state of Tasmania advise that many within their membership are contacting them and expressing their despair that the state government is unlikely to provide adequate dental services, with a consequential deterioration in the oral health of their members. I have raised the issue of the withdrawal of Commonwealth dental health program before in this place.

But how will older Tasmanians in the future be able to access dental care with the cessation of the program? One filling alone can cost between $50 to $100. I would not like to guess what a set of new dentures would cast. Old age pensioners, for example, cannot meet that cost as they simply do not have sufficient income to cover the costs of private dental care. So the market does not supply them with a dental service they can afford.

What about the proposal to set the new maximum rate of rent assistance for single people who share accommodation? In that case, older women will be penalised and we will need to review where they live and how they will survive. They will be at the mercy of market forces in the rental market.

One of the most fundamental areas where older Australians will be at the mercy of market forces will be in the area of charges under home and community care. As yet, we still do not know what the full implications will be from the joint venture between the Commonwealth and the states on the HACC program.

It is very concerning for the older members of society as to who will be determining the price of these fees. Will these fees, for example, be driven by market forces? Many older Australians who are HACC clients receive multiple services and are concerned as to whether some of these services will become too costly. In Tasmania we have one of the highest provisions of home meals and home help. There is a real possibility that these services will end up being provided at a cost which will be prohibitive to some of the elderly.

I mentioned earlier that nursing homes have for some years operated in a quasi market. Older Australians who need to enter into a nursing home will be faced with daily charges under changes introduced by the government. This is an important issue across Australia.

In my home state of Tasmania, the proportion of the population aged 80 years living in nursing homes is one of the highest in the country. The daily fees that will need to be paid will be in addition to the up-front fee of $26,000. It is also now clear that many older Australians will need to sell their homes. They will have to put their homes on the market at a time not necessarily of their choosing. The need to sell the home so as to be able to enter into a nursing home may not be timely, as the market may be depressed and the best price will not be attainable. Here is another example of older Australians being at the whim and the mercy of market forces. The ability to choose the appropriate time to sell the home will be taken away from older Australians because of the pressing need to enter into a nursing home.

Another impost on older Australians is the measure to increase the cost per prescription for concessional users by an additional 50c. This may not seem like a large amount of money, but the increase for the approximately 242,000 aged pensioners who rely solely on the $173 a week is just another impost on the elderly.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Patterson, Sen Kay

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise tonight to speak to the motion before the chair. I have to start by saying that I found Senator Faulkner's attack on me today—I do not know why I seem to have been at the end of his forked tongue twice today, but, I was, and he called me ignorant. Well, the truth hurts. It does not hurt me because it is not the truth. If there is one area in which I can claim not to be ignorant, it is the area of aged care. If anybody has taken an interest in this area in parliament and in the Senate, I think I could say that I have taken an interest and that there are, most probably, not many others with the same level of interest. I am not saying that there are not others with an interest, but I think I would share that with few around the parliament.

SPEECH.PARA: I was interested to see what Senator Faulkner's record was. I looked through the database and discovered that he has not previously spoken on aged care. In fact, the only time he mentioned older people when he was in government, either on the backbench or as a minister, was when he answered questions in relation to veterans' affairs in his representative role. Otherwise, he was not interested in older Australians at all. That is evident by his record. Since coming into this place, that is the first speech that he has made on older people. He has asked a couple of questions in the last few weeks on nursing homes and veterans' affairs and given notice of his motion yesterday.

BREAK.PARA: His record stands on its own. It does not need close examination because there is nothing really to examine. For Senator Faulkner to come in here and call me ignorant is worse than the pot calling the kettle black. It just demonstrates that he really knows nothing about the area; therefore, what he said about me was like water off a duck's back.

When he was speaking, Senator Faulkner continued to spread the furphy that people will be required to pay $26,000 to go into a nursing home. That is an average figure. Also, what the Labor Party continually fails to point out to people is that that total amount of money is not taken. It is an entry fee which is set. The people entering a nursing home will negotiate an entry contribution with the provider, and the government will ensure strong safeguards. Entry contributions cannot be charged to full pensioners or to existing residents. Anyone who has assets of less than $22,280 will not be charged an entry contribution. Financially disadvantaged people will not be required to make an entry contribution. Entry contributions will not apply for short stays up to six months.

The provider can only take $2,600 per annum from the entry contribution. There will be no drawdown for the first six months. The maximum that can be drawn down over five years is set at $13,000. So whether you pay an $80,000 entry fee or whether you pay $26,000 entry fee, the nursing home can use the interest on that money and draw down from $2,600 to a maximum of $13,000.

The money—the capital—that is in there will be protected by prudential arrangements. If the resident leaves the nursing home, the residual in the account will be refunded to the resident or the resident's estate. That is a very different picture from the glib $26,000 everyone will have to pay to go into a nursing home. What those opposite do is just present a very glib figure and scare older people.

Senator Faulkner said that hostel accommodation is a choice and nursing homes are health care. I do not know when we suddenly made this distinction, but it seems to be something that the opposition have suddenly dreamt up to suit their purposes. Senator Faulkner only needs to go into hostels now with residents with an average age of something like 82 and see the level of dependency in those hostels. He will learn that it is not choice for most people who go into hostels.

It was bizarre to say the least that the Labor government had a system in place of having an ingoing—there was not all this argy‐bargy about having to sell your home and isn't it terrible because people made an ingoing—for a hostel and not for a nursing home. You had the ludicrous situation of having a hostel and a nursing home on the same campus—on the same property—run by the same organisation. The person would make an ingoing into the hostel on that same basis with controls about how much could be taken by the proprietor or by the organisation running the hostel. They moved across the corridor—literally across the corridor—to the nursing home, and the organisation had to give their money back.

I do not understand the logic. I do not understand why they could justify it. People used to say to me over and over and over again when I went into nursing homes and hostels, `I don't understand the logic. How can you justify an ingoing for a hostel when you move the person across the corridor to a nursing home and you give them back their ingoing?' The Labor Party, when it was in government, was quite capable of rationalising and justifying an ingoing for a hostel. But, somehow, they have some problem with an ingoing for nursing homes.

Senator Faulkner talked about nursing home standards before 1985. I have given credit where credit was due. There was a lot of reform that needed to be undertaken. I must say that the Labor Party in government undertook some of that reform. They are never prepared to give an inch on the other side. One of the reasons I became very interested in the issue of aged care was because I saw the standard of some of those nursing homes when I was teaching in the area at Lincoln Institute.

There were definitely reforms that needed to be made. I must say that, had we been in government, it would not have stood still. The world does not stand still. People in government carry on as though the opposition would never have done anything if they had been in government. Yes, the Labor Party did do some things, but they failed to really address some of the major issues.

One of the major issues is the capital stock of nursing homes. They commissioned their own inquiry by Professor Gregory. Professor Gregory brought out a report—Gregory report stage 2—which was a condemnation of the Labor Party's management of nursing homes. They had failed to bite the bullet and find some way to increase the capital funding.

I have to say that I have a vested interest, as do most of the people in this chamber—other than somebody like Senator O'Chee. Most of us sitting around here at this very moment ought to declare an interest because in 30 years time, which is about the time those of us sitting around here may be looking at being in a nursing home—and 25 per cent of us will be—we will need double the capital stock that we have now. Not only do we have to upgrade the stock we have but we also have to double the capital stock to accommodate people of the baby boom in nursing homes and hostels. Nothing was being done.

Mr Keating used to talk about the vision thing. Where was the vision? It was missing because the vision is that we will have an increasingly dependent ageing population reliant on a decreasing youth population. Not only will they have to pay for our nursing home and all the other support that we will need but they will also be paying back a debt that has been racked up. So they will have a double whammy.

What did Professor Gregory say about nursing homes? I will just summarise his points. He said that there was a need for substantial improvement in nursing home buildings. Because of the government's funding formula, there was a lack of incentive to maintain good quality nursing home stock. He found that 18 per cent of residents lived in rooms with five or more beds.

Senator Faulkner cannot get up and talk about the standards in 1985. There were still nursing homes that were not acceptable when Labor went out of power. There were toilets not large enough to allow elderly people with frames or wheelchairs to receive assistance, and that was the most common structural fault.

Professor Gregory said that the present funding system was not providing sufficient funding and not attracting the applications necessary for the replacement and upgrading of nursing homes in the voluntary sector. He said that, across the voluntary sector, 670 beds a year needed to be replaced to ensure that all beds were replaced over a 40-year lifetime, and this level had not been achieved at any time in the last eight years. That report was brought down in 1994—an indictment of Labor's management.

We have to get the capital from somewhere. We must get the capital from somewhere to actually upgrade current nursing homes to bring them up to world standard. I must say we have many nursing homes in Australia that are world standard. They ought to be a beacon on the hill to countries around the world of world class, quality aged care, but we have some others where none of us would want to put our mothers. The policy ought to be such that it develops capital funding to enable upgrading, replacement and development of new stock. We have all those jobs to do to face the future. Senator Faulkner can look back all he likes to the past but, if you just look back to the record that they have had so far, it is pretty poor.

I have to say that I do not often agree with members on the other side, but I had to agree with Gary Johns, basically. In a letter that he wrote to the Australian on 19 September 1996, he got it right. He said:
The fact is that the system—
the system of making ingoings—

already applies to hostels, so why not extend it to nursing homes? Essentially, people will be asked to make a contribution out of their assets to the upkeep of the home. The amount charged will vary according to the customer's assets. The important part, though, is that the proprietor can only make money from the interest earned from the contribution, and $1300 for every six months up to five years. The unused portion of the total contribution is returned at the end of the stay.
I have to say that Gary Johns got it right. He was one of the few people who was prepared to actually outline the policy. He goes on to say in his letter:
There are more than 400,000 people over the age of 80, and that number may well double by 2021, so the capital required to upgrade and build homes will be huge.
He has seen it. I do not know why Gary Johns is not there making some of the policies and addressing some of the issues. He has seen it, and he says:
It is entirely fair that those who use those facilities should make a contribution.

Earlier on in his letter he said he could not understand how you could have a policy where Kerry Packer pays the same as Mrs Smith. That is the system we have now. That is the system that Labor has left us with. Any one of us on a parliamentary pension would pay the same as a person on the pension. That is not fair. Some of us will be required to make a greater contribution to the capital upkeep and the capital replacement of nursing home facilities. He says in his letter:

The taxpayer has already paid for the enormous amount of care and attention that the elderly receive. They pay through Medicare, the public hospitals, home and community care, Meals on Wheels, carer pensions, and so on.

Yes, he is right, and so we ought to, but there is a limit. We do not have a bottomless pit. We have to find some other ways of ensuring that we get a first‐class system that is fair and equitable and find a way of funding the capital for both upgrading, replacement and new capital.
Until the Labor Party can come up with a better solution than what we have suggested—and they did not do it in the 13 years they were in government—they ought to be quiet and listen to Gary Johns.
I do not know how they had the gall to come in here and move the motion they have today. In September last year I moved a motion in this place. I will point out the record they have had. I moved:
That the Senate—
(b) condemns the Keating Government for its failure:
(i) to remove the iniquities that self‐funded retirees face through the taxation system and in relation to eligibility for the health care card and other concessions . . .

We had self‐funded retirees on the same income as pensioners not having the same tax free threshold. What is fair about that? When did we see the then government take the opportunity to abolish the compulsory retirement age for Commonwealth public servants? Nearly every other legislature had done it, and the Commonwealth failed to do it. They found every excuse under the sun not to do it.

Where were the incentives for people of all ages but particularly those over 65 to maintain their participation in private health insurance? They bleat over there saying it will all get evened up in increases. If Labor had been in power, they would have had to pay the increases with no rebate, with no assistance. So do not sit there saying that it has been taken up by increases. People would have been left to pay the increase with no assistance at all.

The motion also went on to condemn them for inflexibility of recurrent funding and the crisis in capital funding of nursing homes and hostels, which I have mentioned. What else? It also went on to condemn the failure of the Labor government to adequately fund dementia‐specific facilities and to provide appropriate and affordable respite care for people with dementia and their carers. Senator Newman has outlined what we are doing for carers and the fact that we are prepared to have dementia‐specific facilities.

The home and community care program was so disjointed that people were falling between the cracks. We are looking to have a review of that. Also, the Labor government failed to really address superannuation, particularly giving women who move in and out of the work force greater flexibility through retirement savings accounts. Their record on older people is absolutely abysmal.As for the l‐a‐w tax cuts that they promised older people, they did not get those either. They were actually going to keep that promise through a legislative process. So the record of those on the other side with regard to older people stands condemned.

In 1999 we will have the United Nations International Year of Older Persons. What happened when some people from the community went to Dr Carmen Lawrence at the end of last year and said that we ought to be planning for this? Do you know what she said? `It's too early.' What happened with the international year of the family? It was a disaster. We wasted hundreds, thousands and millions of dollars of taxpayers' money because the Labor party failed to plan.

When there was a push, which I was encouraging because I believed that something needed to be done, and something is being done about the international year of older persons, all Mrs Lawrence could say was, `It's too early.' That was the sort of vision that that party had. No wonder they are sitting on the other side.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gibbs, Sen Brenda

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak in support of the motion that the Senate condemns the government for abandoning older Australians to the mercy of market forces. This is a government which continues to praise itself for having the courage to take the hard decisions. But this is also the government which coined the term `non‐core election promise'.

SPEECH.PARA: Since then it has become apparent that the chief distinction between `core' and `non‐core' commitments is who they were made to. Pastoralists, miners and media magnates are among those to which the Howard government has managed to keep its word. Other minority groups, however, have had a very different experience of this government.

Welfare recipients, those with physical and mental disabilities, the homeless, the jobless—all have found the word of the Howard government to be worthless. Even more disturbing, some groups have been singled out by this government for special attention.

These victims I refer to as the three A's—Aborigines, Asians and the Aged. These are the people upon whom the greatest burden has fallen since the March election. But while indigenous issues and immigration have attracted heated debate, the plight of the elderly has gone largely unnoticed.

Perhaps no other group in this country has been so badly betrayed by this government as the frail and aged. For many of our older people, the first nine months of the Howard government have meant increasing confusion, insecurity and fear. This fear has not been created by the opposition or minor parties.It has been created by the policies of the Howard government, policies which would see the role of government in providing security for the aged replaced by the uncaring interaction of supply and demand.

Consider the Howard government's plan to replace public housing by subsidising the private rental market. There can be few clearer examples of this government abandoning older Australians to the mercy of market forces. In Australia, the need to provide public housing has been recognised by successive federal and state governments since 1945. The first Commonwealth‐state housing agreement was developed by the Chifley Labor government in November that year.

Ever since, the Commonwealth has invested directly in public housing on a dollar‐for‐dollar basis with the states. Fifty years later, the Howard government says it has a better idea. It plans to take the $1 billion of taxpayers' money allocated for public housing and simply hand it to private landlords. The results of this move are likely to be disastrous.

Already, this government has reduced the current Commonwealth‐state housing agreement from three years to one, ruling out any long‐term capital investment in new public housing by the states. As a consequence, the states will cease building public housing and rely on the private market to make up the shortfall.

In contrast, Labor remains committed to: the maintenance of overall levels of public housing stock; an increase in public housing in well‐located areas, especially in the inner parts of cities and those close to jobs and services; the redevelopment of old housing estates; and a guarantee that no public housing tenant pays more than 25 per cent of their income in rent.

The government says its policy is more equitable for those in the private rental market receiving rent assistance. Every age pensioner in public housing has at one time or another been in the private market. Many of them exhausted their life savings paying rent, waiting up to three years for accommodation to become available.

The irony of this policy is that those struggling in the private market are probably on waiting lists for public housing that will now not be built. Rental assistance was never intended as a substitute for public housing. Where public housing has been replaced with rental assistance overseas, it has failed.

In October, Auckland University's Dr Larry Murphy warned the government that the introduction of this policy in New Zealand had led to the formation of ghettos. He said that the scheme had forced people to spend more than half their incomes on housing. Landlords had simply increased rents because they knew people had access to the subsidy.

Not surprisingly, government spending on housing has tripled since the scheme was introduced. By continuing with its policy, the government is demonstrating it is not listening to the legitimate concerns of those who will be most affected—the elderly. Nor is it listening to the arguments against its plans to introduce up‐front entry fees for nursing homes. It would seem that the Howard government is the only group that cannot distinguish between nursing homes and hostels. Nursing homes are not retirement villages or hostels. Nursing homes have patients, not residents.

For many older Australians, nursing homes represent their only chance of receiving the care and attention they not only require but deserve. But this government says to them, `If you want to receive that care, then you can expect to have to pay an average of $26,000 up front.'

TALK.START.PARA: —In the very short time I have, can I say that this is quite obviously the debate we had to have because it is a long‐held dictum in the Labor Party that when things are really going bad, when you have lost it all—and, boy, have you had a bad day today.
—Order! The time set aside for the debate has expired.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 2 December 1996, on motion by Senator Campbell:
That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney, Sen Barney

TALK.START.PARA: —My remarks lead on from the speech you were making, Madam Acting Deputy President, about the elderly and the need for hostels and for nursing care. That issue leads into this response to the report from the Legal and Constitional References Committee about national citizenship indicators and benchmarks because that is what this is aimed at. Senator Parer talks in the Senate about the fall or the rise in interest rates and the balance of payments—and these economic indicators are very important—but we tend to overlook those other issues that are more important, I think, in terms of the sort of society we want.

SPEECH.PARA: Madam Acting Deputy President, you no doubt want money to see that the elderly are well looked after—we know your work in this field—and you have said that we need money for that. But it is not the money that is the important thing; the important thing is what is done with the money, what ends up happening as a result of us all paying taxes to the Commonwealth.

This report and the reasonably sympathetic response from the government are about ways of measuring that quality of life that we want: how many people are able to live in reasonable comfort, how many of our people are being properly educated, what sort of cultural activities we engage in—how many national galleries we have, where we can enjoy great works of art, how many sporting fields we have—and how we get on as a community. If we can see a consistent measurement of those things in the same way as we see a consistent measurement of the economic matters that affect our lives, if we can see those sorts of indicators in terms of the things that are really important in our existence, then we are making a big advance.

Unfortunately, there will come a time for all of us when we are on our deathbed, looking back on our careers—here and elsewhere. Will we at that stage be saying, `Yes, I got an extra tonne of coal out of the mine' or `I opened a hotel at Currie on King Island, which one of my fellow senators perhaps should have opened'? Are we going to do that, or are we instead going to say, `What have we done'—to use the old phrase—`for our fellow man and our fellow woman?'

This report entitled National wellbeing: A system of national citizenship indicators and benchmarks is about those great issues of life. The report had its genesis in the mind of many people but it was brought into the Senate by Senator Sid Spindler, as he then was. It was a report that commenced under my chairmanship—

TALK.START.PARA: —You were a very good chairman.
—Thank you, Senator West. I will have to get that on the record. And the report was completed under the chairmanship of Chris Ellison.

SPEECH.PARA: There are a lot of problems with the concept because the issue of what is the proper measurement of a particular factor—such as how to measure the sort of social security we have in the community—can be a matter of opinion, a matter that leads to political tension because, as is clearly illustrated in a chamber such as this, different people take different views as to how our human needs are responded to by government—and not only by government but by other agencies, such as hospitals, schools, churches, trade unions and associations of employers.

In any event, the important thing is that we should get down to determining some sort of measure that we can all agree upon in spite of our different beliefs, our different political outlooks, our different social concerns. If we can get this system of indicators, then we can argue in this chamber on a more sensible basis. The community can look to itself, can look to the way it is going, in a much better way than it does now. There is no reason why that should not be done.

PARA.BREAK: The committee made some recommendations and the government has responded. It is good to see in the response that the govern ment accepts—this is set down in the response:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the on‐going need for the Australian Bureau of Statistics to audit national statistical collection activities with reference to other agencies such as the Australian Institute of Health and Welfare and the Australian Institute of Criminology. This will ensure the availability of statistics on human wellbeing to support the government and community in the development and evaluation of policies and programs.
That is a very encouraging response. It would be a good thing if all of us, no matter what party we are from, could ensure that the government keeps up with that very positive response.
The second recommendation is as follows:
The Committee recommends that the Australian Bureau of Statistics be resourced to collect relevant data and develop indicators in the area of social and political participation.

It should be not only in the area of social and political participation but also in terms of the cultural life of a country and every other aspect of life, even the sporting life of a country, because it is these things that make up the sort of society we enjoy. The government response is this:

The Government has asked the Australian Bureau of Statistics to establish, in consultation with other relevant agencies, the level and nature of the unmet demand for information in the area of social and political participation and to assess its priority in the context of the overall ABS work program.

It is not simply a matter of collecting information, although that is an essential first step; it is a matter of putting that information in such a state that we can draw conclusions from it that we as a society can act upon. Having acted upon it, the community we live in becomes a much better place. Recommendation 3 says:

. . . the Australian Government give high priority to the establishment of a National System of Indicators and Benchmarks capable of measuring performances in the area of legal, economic, social and cultural significance.
That is a good thing. Then it goes on to other matters. I will read recommendation 5 and the government response. Recommendation 5 states:

The Committee recommends that the Government provide appropriate support to establish links with the relevant activities, notably the proposed United Nations Research Institute for Social Development Conference on Globalization and Citizenship to be held in Australia this year and the various civics and education programs.
The government response is as follows:
The recommendation is supported.

Talking about the United Nations Research Institute for Social Development and the proposed conference, one of our very eminent members of parliament, Mr John Langmore, is to take up an important place in the United Nations. No doubt you, Madam Acting Deputy President, with the rest of the chamber would wish him all the best when he does that.

TALK.START.PARA: —And deliver his seat to us.
—I was making what I hoped was a very bipartisan appeal and Senator Panizza, it is very unlike you—
—Uncharacteristic.

—Very uncharacteristic. It is not like you at all. You are a man usually of generosity, a person who would normally give great praise to Mr Langmore. This is a very important report. Again we have to give credit to Mr Neil Bessel and the rest of the committee secretariat. (Time expired)

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade References Committee

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 17 October 1996, on motion by Senator Forshaw:
That the Senate take note of the report.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak to this report this evening because, whilst the issue might seem dead to some people, it still is very much alive. This report bears some very close study indeed. The problem with the cancellation of the DIFF scheme, as it is known, was that firstly it took no cognisance of one of the projects that was in the pipeline and the loss in monetary and employment terms to those firms in the pipeline and, secondly, the damage to relations with China, Indonesia, Vietnam and the Philippines.

BREAK.PARA: The very nature of the processing of DIFF applications made it a nonsense to cut the scheme unilaterally, as the government did. All that did was hurt small business, and it insulted our neighbours. The process of the operation of the DIFF scheme is outlined clearly at page 18 of the report.

There were two major hurdles that companies seeking DIFF finance had to overcome. The first was the letter of advice and the second was the formal offer. That is important in the scheme of things because it leads on to the big unanswered question which, if I do not get the time to pursue this evening, I will pursue at another time. To jump these hurdles, the projects had to be consistent with the OECD arrangements covering export credits, including the Helsinki guidelines. There is no doubt in my mind that the projects in this pipeline constituted genuine aid. That was part of the real sticking point with the government in its cancellation of this scheme.

At page 45 of the report, a table shows clearly that the number of projects that had reached the stage of formal offer of letters of advice was indeed substantial. The grand total was 57 projects worth $1.284 billion to those companies that were in either the stage of formal offer or the stage of letter of advice. While some of the projects that were at the stage of letter of advice would not have reached the formal offer stage, the vast majority would have. This is the evidence that was presented to the committee. To reach that stage, these companies would have been spending hundreds of thousands of dollars, as instanced on pages 48 to 50; that is, they outlaid money to get themselves to the stage of formal offer. A cursory glance at pages 48 to 50 shows companies spending in the order of $120,000, $200,000 and $700,000. These are not insignificant amounts for small businesses, in particular, which were affected by the government's unilateral decision. It was chicanery once again on the part of this government.

This outlay, though, was done in good faith by many of these companies and it was done cold. There was no consolation whatsoever for the Australian businesses seeking to make breakthroughs in very competitive markets only to see valuable capital laid to waste. For example, LABAX International Pty Ltd and the University of Queensland stood to lose $1.2 million alone through the cancellation of DIFF.

In the first instance, the DIFF scheme may have supported aid projects, but there was invariably follow-up business which did not attract DIFF funding. The follow-up business was estimated to be in the order of at least five to one. The committee heard varying reports about the contribution of follow-up business, which has now been denied to small business.Follow-up business had been really good for the long-term future of our industries, for employment and the sustainability of small businesses in particular. The DIFF scheme undoubtedly provided access to markets through concessional finance, which is provided by many of our trading partners and competitors throughout the world. As part of that matrix of competition, one sees that we deserted the matrix and left it to the others.

There is no doubt, though, that there is a place for such a scheme, as the majority report findings state at pages 95 and 96. It is important to reiterate it for the sake of the Senate. At page 95, the committee report says:

The Committee recommends that the Australian Government not wait for the financial year 1997-98 but introduce, at the earliest possible time, another mixed credits scheme to replace the Development Import Finance Facility.
Further, the report says:
The Committee recommends that the replacement mixed credits scheme be based on the following criteria:
. that it be primarily a development aid scheme;
. that emphasis be given to projects of an humanitarian, poverty alleviation or environmental nature;
. that all projects be nominated by recipient governments;
. that it be integrated in AusAID's bilateral programs for individual countries; and
. that all projects be open to competition among Australian companies.
Whilst that is there, we still hear silence from this government, which is damning indeed.
Debate interrupted.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 7.20 p.m., under sessional order, I propose the question:

INTERJECT.PARA: That the Senate do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Abetz, Sen Eric

TALK.START.PARA: —This evening, I wish to address some remarks on the report tabled earlier this day by the Senate Select Committee on the Victorian Casino Inquiry. May I commence my remarks by congratulating the deputy chair of the committee, Senator Troeth, on her professionalism and the erudite report she produced on behalf of government senators. On behalf of not only myself but also government members of the committee, I also wish to place on record my thanks to Frank Nugent, the committee secretary, and his secretariat for their dedication and work.

SPEECH.PARA: This select committee was born out of the personal animosity to the Victorian Premier held by those opposite. This animosity is based on his huge electoral success and the fact that he has so comprehensively routed the Labor Party in his state of Victoria. It was such a comprehensive rout that Labor in Victoria is now engaged in a most bitter and divisive factional battle over the spoils of defeat.

The terms of reference for the committee were basically fourfold. In brief, they were the following: firstly, to look at the adequacy of Commonwealth legislation in relation to casinos; secondly, the adequacy of the Financial Transaction Reports Act 1988; thirdly, whether the granting of any licence to any casino within Australia has affected Australia's overseas reputation; and, fourthly—the sting in the tail as far as Labor was concerned—to inquire into the Victorian casino. There was nothing stopping the committee from inquiring into the first three terms of reference if those opposite were genuine about inquiring into the casino industry generally in order to clean it up. However, we all know that they only put those three terms of reference in before the Victorian casino reference to try to give the inquiry some facade of respectability.

BREAK.PARA: Once it became apparent that they could not lay a glove on the Victorian government, they deserted the whole inquiry and no longer wanted to pursue it. There was nothing stopping the committee from looking at the Financial Transaction Reports Act. There was nothing stopping us from looking at the adequacy of Commonwealth legislation. But once their chief political target had evaded them, they were no longer interested in those other terms of reference.

Listening to Senator Childs and Senator Ray this morning I was reminded of one of those options you can now get on new cars—dual air bags. With all the wind and allegations and hot air that they produced this morning, they did not provide us with any substance. If Senator Childs wants to talk about grubby deals, let him explain to the Senate why a democratically elected senator such as he has to resign to make way for a left wing trade union hack like George Campbell. Do not lecture this side on grubby deals, Senator Childs; it ill behoves you.

Senator Ray promised us that he would raise allegations under parliamentary privilege next week. Senator Woodley did likewise. For the record, let it be quite clear that neither senator raised the information that they allegedly had with a committee—information which, of course, would have attracted parliamentary privilege. Let me say to that Senator Ray and Senator Woodley: if you have the evidence, instead of waiting until next week, take those 10 steps to courage and repeat it right now outside this chamber. Of course, they will not do that. There is no need to wait—they can do it right now.

They both raised their voices during the discussions today and spoke with a great degree of pretend passion, but the volume of the noise did not overcome the fact that they failed tactically and practically. Those opposite need to realise that mere repetition does not overcome the void occasioned by the absence of merit.
Senator Woodley's announcement on 1 October really showed us what it was all about. During our considerations he told a journalist working with the Age:
We have a whole raft of documentary evidence and if they—
the Victorian government—
do not allow the public servants to appear, we will simply present that which would not be in the Victorian government's interests at all.

So did we expect an unjaundiced, fair, open‐minded approach to this inquiry? Of course not. It was quite clear that Senator Woodley and those opposite had already made up their minds. I simply say to Senator Woodley: where is this whole raft of evidence that he said to the community at large the committee held? We got 10 submissions, most of which were irrelevant. Some were relevant, but did not touch on the specific matter of any wrongdoing in relation to the Victorian casino inquiry. The evidentiary part aside, Senator Woodley and Labor Party senators lived up to their promise to `simply present that which would not be in the Victorian government's interests at all.' An approach like that to a Senate committee report would make the Spanish Inquisition blush. At least the Communist show trials of past decades had a facade of procedural fairness about them; they had the facade of doing things right. But Senator Woodley really let the cat out of the bag by saying, `We will simply present that which would not be in the government's best interests at all.' I have to say to them that they did deliver on their promise by recommending a royal commission.

In contrast, the government senators took a very principled stand and agreed with the Labor senators on some fundamental principles and guidelines that Senate inquiries or committees ought to follow in the future. They are: firstly, that current and former members of state parliament should not be summoned or required to answer questions on matters which relate to their activities as members of parliament or ministers. Secondly, current and former senior public servants, ministerial advisers and members of statutory bodies should not be summoned or required to answer questions on matters which relate to their activities as advisers to state ministers or cabinet on policy issues. Thirdly, the production of documents which were prepared for the purpose of informing, advising or decision making by state ministers or state cabinets should not be demanded. We joined with the Labor Party on that, and I congratulate them for coming to that conclusion. But, unfortunately, the temptation to take a swipe at the Victorian government on the way through was a little bit too great. Senator Woodley, in an amazing little number in his dissenting report, tells us this:
What has happened here today is that the Premier of Victoria has manipulated a Senate inquiry with the express purpose of avoiding scrutiny of a highly controversial government decision.

TALK.START.PARA: —Hear, hear!

—Senator Conroy says `Hear hear'. So what you are saying, Senator Conroy, is that your big chief and leader, Senator Ray, was manipulated by the Premier of Victoria, Mr Kennett; that Senator Collins was manipulated; and that Senator Childs was manipulated. That is hardly something that stands up to any analysis. It really does go beyond the limits of credulity.

BREAK.PARA: The Labor senators at least had the decency to realise the ill‐considered nature of this inquiry. The reality is that the Labor senators got a bit excited about the potential of this inquiry and let the blood rush to their head. But, unfortunately, in rushing to their head, the blood bypassed their brain.

But they did finally agree that they could not pursue this inquiry. And no wonder! Who was the instigator of this inquiry? Senator Kim Carr, the great tactician of the Labor Party. It is no wonder the Labor Party said, `Senator Carr, you've got it started, but we are not going to allow you to serve on the committee.' I agree with the Labor Party's stance on that.

The reality is that we as a Senate should view very seriously the rights of state governments and parliaments to conduct their business without the sort of intervention that was proposed in this inquiry. I congratulate the Labor Party senators on their principled stand, but I do take objection to the cheap political swipe that they took at the Victorian government on the way to coming to a very principled resolution to this matter. I am pleased to see the end of this inquiry. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lundy, Sen Kate

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise this evening to address the issue of telecommunications. Despite all of the action that has taken place over the last few months and the inquiry that I participated in which explored the partial privatisation of Telstra as part of its terms of reference, it is interesting to note that the issue of telecommunications has had very little time spent on it in the chamber this evening. It is telecommunications that I wish to speak about. When we talk about the future of the Australian telecommunications industry, we are talking about an industry that probably has the greatest potential to carry us as a nation through into the next millennium.

SPEECH.PARA: Telecommunications is an industry that is going through a major revolution and evolution. It is an industry in which we have proven we can really ride the crest of the wave of that change and be at the forefront of technological development. For a government to have such a void in their policy in the area of telecommunications is something that we will suffer well into the future.

This lack of vision has been exposed today by the very fact that, upon the issue of the privatisation being brought before the chamber, where our telecommunications industry is going did not even rate a mention. What we have heard about is the environment, the various deals and all the rest of it. But that is not what I want to speak about tonight. I would like to talk about telecommunications and how important I believe it is to where we are going with this industry.

Telecommunications has great potential. Whilst we struggle with the current debate—I believe this was brought out in the committee inquiry into the privatisation of Telstra—we are talking about telecommunications, which is a very complex industry with so many facets that it is worthy of great attention. In the lead-up to the consideration of what happens with full and open competition post‐1997, I believe those issues need to be confronted specifically and in great detail.

This government has put before the nation its plan for the transition to full competition in telecommunications. That is the issue that we need to focus our attention on. The fact that its attention has been diverted to other issues—that is, ownership—just means that this government has left itself exposed to doing a great disservice to the whole telecommunications sector. Why is this government so myopic in the area of telecommunications? Why has it chosen to see public ownership of its major telecommunications carrier not as an opportunity—

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I raise a point of order: I am very interested in what the senator has to say on telecommunications but I would remind you, Madam President, that the partial sale of Telstra is still on the Notice Paper . I was wondering if you would bring the senator into order and ask her to keep away from the sale of Telstra and to return to telecommunications, which I am quite interested in listening to.

—On the point of order, Madam President: I am trying to address my comments to the telecommunications industry. It is because of the current circumstances in which the major carrier in the telecommunications industry is involved that it is necessary for me to make reference to that as part of my comments—albeit the general thrust of my remarks this evening is on the future of the industry as opposed to the partial privatisation.

—As far as the future of the industry is concerned, you are certainly able to comment on that. But it is quite clear that the partial sale of Telstra, which is before the chamber at the moment, is not a matter that ought to be discussed by you at this time. I do not believe you are doing that but I would just remind you to keep to the question of the future of telecommunications.

—The telecommunications industry has such huge potential—whether it be with respect to the Internet, electronic commerce or basic access and equity to the services that it provides. Therefore, telecommunications is fundamentally important as a policy tool for governments. I spoke in my first speech to this place about information and access to information being a determinant of power in our community. That is why the ability for governments to have telecommuni cations as a mechanism with which to introduce social policy—be it in relation to access and equity to those technologies—is a fundamental tenet of what I believe constitutes good and reasonable government.

SPEECH.PARA: Australia is so uniquely placed to take us forward into the next century and lead the way that I am fearful that the recent directions taken will take us in a different direction. For example, in the recent US election campaign, we saw President Clinton make a major announcement as part of that campaign—an initiative concerning the role of the Internet in classrooms, the role of the Internet in people's homes, and the strategy that he was going to put in place via a legislative mechanism similar to our universal service obligation to take those services to the people. We then heard the President in the House of Representatives chamber in this place restate his commitment to the developing IT sector—the industry that he saw would be one of the primary growth sectors of our whole region.

I put it to the Senate that, in the context of the current debate surrounding telecommunications, with all the political intrigue, with all the side issues and all the motivations that have brought us to this point, we should remember that we are talking about the communications system in this country. We are talking about the telecommunications industry and its future. I believe that industry has much more to offer this place and much more to offer Australia than a short‐term financial return. As a government, the coalition has a responsibility for delivering those outcomes to the Australian people.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: University of New South Wales: Closure of St George Campus

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tierney, Sen John

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise tonight to place on record my strongest condemnation of the decision by the University of New South Wales to close the St George campus at Oatley in southern Sydney. This is a wilfully destructive decision that strikes in particular at primary teacher education, as well as other courses in southern Sydney. It is shameful that the University of New South Wales has abandoned in particular a respected and quality teacher education program. It has removed the capacity to train 600 primary school teachers. In coming years we will be facing a shortage in this field.

SPEECH.PARA: The Vice‐Chancellor of the University of New South Wales, Professor John Niland, announced that the St George campus will be closed to save the university $20 million. This cut by the University of New South Wales is their contribution to the $680 million in federal government budget cuts for higher education over the coming three years.

I do not walk away from the need for the University of New South Wales to save money. They, like all the other 37 universities, must make a contribution to budget savings. But universities are required to approach this task with care and responsibility in finding new income and in making cost savings and efficiencies in all departments.

The University of New South Wales has taken a slash and burn approach. It is the laziest approach of all. They have opted for a sole vertical cut of $20 million. They have amputated two schools and a whole campus and abandoned teacher education. The use of these student places is now to be transferred to other parts of the University of New South Wales.

This university has taken the opportunity to rid itself of the final amalgamation effects of 1989. The Senate will recall that this was the work of John Dawkins and that Labor's policy forced amalgamations on this sector. The effects of that amalgamation are still haunting the sector today.

The institution that now faces abolition was originally the Alexander Mackie Teachers College, which became the St George Institute and, under forced amalgamation, the St George campus of the University of New South Wales, even though their original preference was for amalgamation with the University of Wollongong. They must now rue the day that they did not take that other option, because joining with New South Wales has in effect led to their demise.

It has destroyed a part of our education system that has a reputation for excellence. The St George campus has a name for quality in teacher education. Its students command a very high tertiary entrance rank and it attracts students of high quality. Its graduates are sought after. All of this is now to be lost.

In addition to the students whose teacher training is being disrupted, other losers from this decision are, firstly, the teaching profession, because it has lost a college with a very fine reputation, one of the three most preferred institutions by New South Wales primary student teachers. That is to be abandoned at a time when Australia's present surplus of teachers is about to become a very serious shortage.

To take 600 places out of teacher education at this point of the demand cycle for teachers is utterly senseless. A looming significant shortage has been identified in the training of teachers in the years ahead, particularly by an independent researcher, Barbara Preston, who has done a study on the supply of teachers in Australia. She has calculated that the current national surplus of teachers is 2,600, but that is expected to turn quickly to a shortfall of 4,700 by the year 2000.

You do not produce teachers instantly, overnight. They usually require up to about four years training. So the training for that shortage in the year 2000 should be beginning right now. They are predicting that the shortage in 2000 will, by 2003, blow out to a shortage of 7,000, yet they are closing a whole campus. With evidence of this major teacher shortage crisis on the horizon, the decision by the University of New South Wales has invited inevitable and justified public condemnation, and I echo that condemnation.

Secondly, the people of southern Sydney are the other major losers in this. This callous decision by the University of New South Wales has taken away the only higher education preference in southern Sydney. When this goes, there will be nothing between Kensington and Wollongong. There will be no higher education offered in the federal electorates of Cook, Barton, Hughes and Watson, an area which, with its other drawing areas, has a population of a million people. That is comparable in size to Perth and also to Adelaide.

I mentioned earlier that the University of Wollongong had expressed interest at the original amalgamations in having the St George campus as part of their university. The only glimmer of hope on the horizon is if the University of Wollongong does that. That would be an excellent outcome because the University of Wollongong is a first‐class university. In the original quality assurance rounds it ended up in the same band as the University of Sydney.

That amazed us all at the time but I spent a full day at the University of Wollongong and I found that, of all the universities I have visited, it was one of the most impressive in its programs, its research and vision. So, hopefully, the University of Wollongong could take over the rather large gap left by the University of New South Wales and, in effect, become a university for southern Sydney, servicing areas in higher education from Wollongong to Rockdale.

It is sad that it has come to the abandonment of a fine institution like the St George institute, one with a fine reputation and an excellent tradition, all because of the very lazy management practice of the University of New South Wales—the very same university that was happy to take over the St George campus and its 900 EFTSUs in 1990, only now to abandon the campus, its staff and students and swipe the 900 student places.

That action in earlier centuries would have been called piracy. You capture the ship, St George campus, which they did in 1990; you make the crew and the passengers, that is the staff and the students, walk the plank; and you make off with the loot, which is the 900 EFTSU places. The actions of the council of the University of New South Wales at St George in this matter are morally reprehensible and socially irresponsible, and to quote Professor Alan Watson from the St George campus:
While universities rightly claim freedom from government interference, they have a responsibility to the community to provide personal and fundamental services, such as teacher education.
The University of New South Wales council is failing southern Sydney and teacher education by this decision. They stand condemned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Allison, Sen Lyn

TALK.START.PARA: —I might say before I begin how glad I was to hear Senator Tierney make remarks about the teacher shortage. That is something I had intended to raise myself. However, he seems to make no connection between that and the cuts that his government has imposed on universities, but blames it on the Dawkins reforms, which is interesting. I would like to remind him that he is in government now and is in a position to influence for change.

SPEECH.PARA: But the reason I rise tonight is to speak on the matter of telecommunications and the national code. I spent some time today examining the responses of the Minister for Communications and the Arts (Senator Alston) to various of my questions recently in relation to the exemptions telecommunications carriers enjoy from local and state planning regulations. There are a number of issues here which require elaboration and even correction.

Firstly, there is the question of whether it would be reasonable, in the light of widespread concern in the community and in local government, for the government to remove those exemptions right now. It suits the minister's purposes to say that councils would veto a telecommunications system of national importance and that they cannot be trusted. It also suits him to suggest that, in his words, `Senator Allison has the gall, or the unmitigated ignorance, to put out a release suggesting that there is no basis for claiming legal liability'. He went on to invite me to take a good look at myself, et cetera. I will not indulge in the sort of rhetoric which he uses but I do need to respond.

The legal advice to which the minister refers was provided by the Parliamentary Library Law and Public Administration Group. The question I asked the library was: can the Commonwealth parliament end the telecommunications carrier's immunities from state and local government laws before 1 July 1997? We sought that advice following the minister's claim that the government had not sought legal advice, in spite of the fact that liability was so often quoted as one of the reasons the minister could not remove those exemptions. It is particularly interesting that the minister should say just yesterday:

You clearly are not interested in the legal implications of decisions that are taken in this area but we are, and the advice we have had is that it would not be proper for the Commonwealth to expose itself to liability in that way.

I hope that the minister has at least sought legal advice, and I will be asking him to table it in the Senate as soon as possible. In the meantime, the Australian Local Government Association has sought legal advice. That advice was:

. . . there is nothing in the Telecommunications Act which prevents the Minister from changing the provisions of a National Code by revoking an existing code and determining a replacement code. In fact this is the means permitted by the Telecommunications Act for changes to be made to the National Code.

Subject to some specific exceptions which are identified below, we consider that neither the Parliament or the Executive Government can have any liability for the consequences of a change in the law (ie change to legislation, regulations or other instruments under legislation) to any person or corporation.

It is an axiomatic constitutional principle that, subject to the Constitution only, the Commonwealth Parliament has an unfettered and unrestricted power to make laws with respect to the peace, order and good government of the Commonwealth in relation to the matters specified in the Constitution. There is no doubt that Parliament may confer power on a Minister to determine regulatory controls as it has done by Section 117 of the Telecommunications Act, and such controls have the force of law.

It is our opinion that the principles applied in equal effect in respect of changes to the law (including changes to regulatory controls) which are affected by other instruments that are enacted, made or determined pursuant to legislation. There is no reason to differentiate between regulations and such other instruments.

So the government is not liable for the cost of changes it might make to codes or legislation as it affects telecommunications carriers any more than it is to chicken meat producers who might have their industry wiped out by the government's decision to import chicken from Asia or elsewhere. The government cannot be sued by those businesses who will suffer financially from the lowering of the research and development allowances, for instance. Disability support pensioners cannot sue the government for the fact that it takes away one‐third of their rent assistance because they live in shared accommodation.

The solicitors who prepared this advice for the ALGA suggested the government be asked a number of questions. These are the questions that I will put on notice to the minister shortly. Their summary of advice was:

In our opinion, subject to the existence of any agreement or conduct by the Commonwealth Government which may give rise to an action at common law or for breach of a statutory duty or obligation, there are no restrictions on the extent to which a National Code may be changed by a replacement code.
If the minister has indeed had advice which is contrary to the two opinions I have already cited, it would be useful for us to hear what that is.

I hope this advice also indicates to the government what their liability might be in the event that action is taken against the government by those feeling increasingly disadvantaged by the government's failure to protect them. Perhaps the minister should ask his advisers whether class action might be successful in the case in Mitcham in Adelaide which I will outline.

Vodafone proposes to construct a 36‐metre tower in the Mitcham community court and announced that construction will begin on or before 18 December. This tower will be just 40 metres from the Mitcham kindergarten and even closer to the local library and a facility for nursing mothers. The family which wrote to me said the tower will be 60 metres from the bedrooms of their children aged five, six and 10. They have already been to protest rallies in Mitcham this week, both of which were covered extensively by radio and television. I have to advise the Senate that this community in Adelaide is most distraught. They are distraught because their kindergarten will almost certainly close as a result of this tower.

I am told that the Mitcham community court is a beautiful area of gardens and gum trees, but it will become a no‐go zone for parents. Parents know that it may not be safe to have their children for many hours and on a daily basis in such close proximity to a mobile phone tower. They are asking: why is it that the government set aside $4.5 million to conduct research into the effects of electromagnetic radiation? Why is it that the new code will indicate that it is not safe to have kindergartens within 100 metres of a mobile phone tower after 1 July, but on 18 December it will be quite okay for their tower to be just 60 metres away? The Mitcham Council has proposed alternative sites but Vodafone refuses to negotiate. And why should they? The telecommunications act does not require them to take the slightest notice of councils or communities.

What do these people do as a result? Do they sell up and move? Will the government pay for the inevitable decrease in the value of their house? What assurances do they have that a house somewhere else will not be invaded by another tower or perhaps by several carriers on the one tower? These people say their frustration is intense and I can well understand that. But it is a pity that the government cannot.
I want to return to the minister's remarks yesterday. He said:

If you ask me why it is that we did not proclaim the earlier legal advice it is probably because you have been going around telling people like the Australian Local Government Association that you would move to disallow it.
I think the minister here was confusing legal advice with the code. He went on:

In other words, any attempts that we might make to actually tighten the code to provide greater protection would be the subject of a disallowance motion in this chamber. If that is not your position I would very much welcome you saying . . .

It is fair to say that that is an example of very muddled thinking on the part of the minister. What he seems to be saying is that the government did not press ahead with the last draft code because he expected us to disallow it. Of course we would disallow it. It had no more protections and some would say it had even less than the code which it would have replaced.

Those who could decipher code mark II were in general agreement that it should indeed be disallowed. Perhaps if the minister had adopted more of the 57 recommendations made by Austel, the code would have had more teeth and afforded more protection. We have yet to see the telecommunications national code mark III. If the best the minister can do is to change the colour of aerial cables to grey, and underground at intersections, we might disallow it as well.

I did say to the ALGA that we will move amendments to this legislation to remove the exemption altogether and we will be doing this during the committee stage of the Telstra (Dilution of Public Ownership) Bill 1996 tomorrow. We will do that again when the post‐1997 telecommunications legislation comes up early next year. We will continue to draw the government's attention to this issue until something is done. The minister has had representation from many individuals and many organisations on this issue, not least of which from the ALGA. The ALGA put to the government a number of proposals about a regulatory framework for proper planning processes. They have suggested a round table conference where carriers, councils and gov‐

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Senator Sherry

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Treasurer upon notice, on 17 July 1996:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Will the Government's proposed Retirement Savings Account (RSA) products have to meet the full prudential requirements of the Superannuation Industry Supervision legislation, including the full trusteeship provisions.
(2)(a) Will both banks and life offices be able to offer RSAs under the one regulatory regime; and (b) will that regime include the full trusteeship supervision.
(3) Will there be a limit on the amount that an RSA will be able to accumulate before having to be rolled over into another superannuation product.
(4) Will RSAs provide a rate of return higher than, equal to, or less than that currently offered by a standard industry superannuation fund.
(5) Will the level of fees payable on an RSA be higher than, equal to, or less than that currently paid on a standard superannuation fund.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Short, Sen Jim

TALK.START.PARA: —The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) In order to enhance competition and choice in superannuation, the Government has decided to allow banks, building societies, credit unions and life insurance companies to provide superannuation without a trust structure in the form of Retirement Savings Accounts. The supervision of RSAs will consist of:

Relevant prudential supervision for institutional soundness. For banks, building societies and credit unions, RSAs will form part of the deposit base of institutions and will be treated as such for prudential purposes by the Reserve Bank of Australia and the Australian Financial Institutions Commission. The RSA business of life insurance companies will be subject to supervision by the Insurance and Superannuation Commission (ISC), but will not require a trust structure. ISC functional supervision for compliance with retirement income and other superannuation standards. RSAs will be subject to the same retirement income standards as other superannuation products, including those applying to contributions and payment of benefits.
(2)(a) and (b), see the response to (1) above.

(3) It will be mandatory for RSA providers to advise account holders of alternative `balanced portfolio' products offering potentially higher returns over the longer term, when their account balances reach $10,000. However, there will be no restriction on RSA balances exceeding this limit. The Government wishes to ensure that people's retirement incomes are maximised but recognises that for some people RSAs may be the appropriate choice, particularly for those close to retirement who may prefer a minimal risk savings vehicle.

(4) The return on RSAs will reflect their `capital guaranteed' nature. It is expected that `balanced portfolio' products, including those offered by industry funds, potentially will offer higher returns over the longer term. But particularly for those with small amounts of superannuation, such as itinerant and casual workers, wishing to minimise risk, RSAs will provide additional choice in the superannuation market.

(5) The level of fees applying to RSAs will be a commercial decision for the RSA provider, subject to the member protection rules, as is the case for other superannuation funds. The introduction of RSAs will provide additional competition in the superannuation industry, thereby putting downward pressure on fees and charges.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 18 September 1996 (Hansard page 3392) Senator Conroy asked me a question without notice concerning unit trusts.

PARA.TAB: Senator Conroy asked:

ANSWER.PARA: Has the Minister's attention been drawn to problems in investor protection for unit trusts? What is the government's view as to the most appropriate regulation of the interests of investors? Is the minister aware of the divergent views on this subject of those in the investment funds industry?

PARA.TAB: The Treasurer has provided the following information in answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: Unit trusts are currently regulated by the prescribed interests provisions of the Corporations Law. Division 5 of Part 7.12 of the Corporations Law provides that prescribed interest schemes, unless specifically excluded from the operation of the fundraising provisions of the Law, must adopt a particular statutory structure. That structure is two tier in that it requires an independent trustee or representative and an independent management company for a scheme or unit trust. The funds or assets of any scheme are vested in the trustee or representative and the scheme is managed on a day to day basis by the management company.

At the end of the 1980s and the start of the 1990s, some unit trusts, particularly unlisted property trusts, faced difficulties. In some cases, unitholders lost large sums of money, and the industry generally suffered a loss of investor confidence. It was in that context that, on 24 May 1991, the then Attorney-General, the Hon Michael Duffy MP, directed the Law Reform Commission and the Companies and Securities Advisory Committee ('the Review') to carry out a thorough examination of the regulatory framework for prescribed interests and `like collective investment schemes'.

The Review reported in July 1993. The Review concluded that no re-working of the current system for regulating unit trusts could overcome its inherent problems of divided powers and responsibilities and the attendant legal complexity and uncertainty. The Review's fundamental recommendation was that there be a single scheme operator, or responsible entity, in relation to each scheme. All other recommendations largely revolve around and build on the single responsible entity concept.
An exposure draft Collective Investments Bill, which essentially followed the approach recommended by Review, was released by the previous
Government for 3 months' public exposure in December 1995.

The Government is aware that there are a number of interested groups who believe that the draft Bill does not represent the best way to supervise collective investment schemes (as unit trusts are referred to in the draft Bill) and that there is yet to emerge a broad agreement on the best method for supervising this element of the market. The Government has encouraged key industry participants to consult with each other as a means of reaching an agreed outcome. While it is disappointing that those consultations have not yet produced a consensus, the Government believes that they have been useful in airing the issues surrounding the regulatory regime proposed by the draft Bill, and in canvassing possible options to, or modifications of, that regime.

The Government will shortly consider those options in detail, with a view to deciding the future direction of the proposed collective investments reforms. The Government wishes to satisfy itself that any legislation that it puts forward in this area strikes the right balance between providing effective investor protection and facilitating an efficient financial and investment market for managed funds in Australia.
